Attending the dinner tonight were more than 1,200 staff members of the Customs and Excise Department and a number of retired Customs officers as well as some Customs attaches stationed in Hong Kong.
19991127_012.e:
Hong Kong to boost technology investment

As a cosmopolitan city, Hong Kong is keen to boost investment in technology and promote innovation.

This must go hand in hand with the establishment of a sound regime to ensure that intellectual property rights are properly protected.

The Financial Secretary, Mr Donald Tsang, made the remarks today (Saturday) when addressing a passing-out parade at the Customs and Excise Training School.

"Apart from improving our legislation, the key to protection of intellectual property rights is effective law-enforcement," he noted.

He pointed out that the Customs and Excise Department had always been dedicated in combating offences involving intellectual property rights.

"Your recent success has upheld Hong Kong's trading integrity at the international level and will certainly contribute to our long term economic development," Mr Tsang said.

He also noted that efforts of Customs officers against the illicit trade of dutiable goods at all levels had also achieved marvellous records pertaining to the protection of government revenue.

"You have risen to the challenges posed by the more complex illegal syndicates with effective enforcement strategies and an extensive intelligence network.

This has successfully contained the problem on illegal trade of dutiable cigarettes and hydrocarbon oil," he told the officers at the parade.

In order to strengthen co-operation with the international community on the anti-smuggling front, the SAR Government entered into a Customs Co-operation Agreement with the European Union in May this year, he went on.

"This will certainly further enhance your enforcement actions against cross-boundary smuggling activities," he added.

Mr Tsang, in conclusion, appealed to the new recruits to keep pace with the time and enhance their skill and knowledge to equip themselves for the challenges ahead, to sustain the momentum of the Department's good work, and to contribute to the stability and prosperity of the community.

Taking part in today's parade were 43 probationary inspectors and 64 probationary Customs officers.

Photo:The Financial Secretary, Mr Donald Tsang, taking the salute at a passing-out parade at the Customs and Training School.
20000303_021.e:
Customs Cooperative Arrangement signed

The Customs General Administration (CGA) of the People's Republic of China and the Hong Kong Customs and Excise Department have early this week signed a Customs Co-operative Arrangement which is aimed at strengthening the cooperation and mutual administrative assistance between the two Customs administrations.

Mr John Tsang Chun-wah, Commissioner of Customs and Excise represented the Department and Mr. Mu Xin-sheng, Deputy Commissioner of Customs General Administration represented the CGA to sign the Arrangement.

The Arrangement was formulated in accordance with the "Memorandum of Understanding on Co-operation" signed by both administrations in Beijing in August 1998.

In signing the Arrangement, both administrations follow the principles of the Basic Law and the framework of "One Country, Two Systems".

The signing of the Arrangement is another excellent example to demonstrate Hong Kong Customs Department's status as a separate customs territory.

The Arrangement provides a framework for both administrations to strengthen cooperation in the fight against smuggling; illicit drug trafficking and in the protection of intellectual property rights.

Besides, it sets out the mode of cooperation and the arrangements of mutual administrative assistance in other Customs related areas.

After signing the Arrangement, both administrations will exchange intelligence of cross-boundary smuggling, drug trafficking and copyright piracy, conduct joint anti-smuggling operation, organise visits and training programmes and conduct feasibility studies to simplify Customs clearance procedures and on the exchange of information through the electronic data interchange.

During their stay in Hong Kong, the delegation of Customs General Administration paid a courtesy call on the Secretary of Trade and Industry, Secretary for Security and Commissioner of Police.

They also visited the Customs and Excise Training School and the Customs Anti-Smuggling Marine Base.

The Customs General Administration delegation left Hong Kong today (Friday).
19990612_011.e:
Working procedures under constant review

The management of the Hong Kong Customs has been constantly reviewing the working procedures in order to minimise the chance for corruption.

This was said today (Saturday) by the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, Mr John Tsang Chun-wah, when inspecting a passing-out parade at the Customs and Excise Training School.

"Despite a few ICAC cases in which Customs officers were convicted, I am certain that the department remains honest and clean as a whole," Mr Tsang stressed.

He told the new recruits that he had directed the senior officers to attach importance to the well being of subordinates with a view to guarding against corruption and maintaining their good conduct.

The department had been working closely with ICAC in numerous collaborative efforts in combating against and preventing corruption, Mr Tsang added.

He said the Customs and Excise Department was a forward-looking, modern and progressive disciplined service.

"Since I took up the post of Commissioner, I have been deeply impressed by the high efficiency and professionalism being displayed by my colleagues," he said.

He noted that the department undertook a wide range of responsibilities, including collection and protection of revenue on dutiable goods, anti-smuggling and anti-narcotics work, protection of intellectual property rights and consumer interests, protection of legitimate trade and industry, trade controls and upholding of Hong Kong's trading integrity.

"The marvellous record we have gathered in these aspects has contributed a lot to maintaining Hong Kong's status as an international commercial and trading centre," he went on.

Mr Tsang, in conclusion, appealed to the new recruits to bear in mind that upholding the law and facilitating trade were their dual missions.

"While performing your duties, you have to be diligent, active and decisive.

What's more, you must strive for honesty and integrity in a bid to maintaining the good image of the department," he added.

Taking part in today's parade were 105 probationary Customs Officers.
19990909_011.e:
HK Customs fully committed to IPR protection

The Customs and Excise Department is fully committed to intellectual property rights (IPR) protection and will continue doing everything possible to maintain Hong Kong as a pirate-free zone.

The assurance was given by the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, Mr John Tsang Chun-wah, when addressing a luncheon of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce today (Thursday).

Mr Tsang, while outlining Customs work in curbing the rampant piracy activities, said, "I am very happy to tell you that we have blinded the pirate in the remaining eye.

The piracy situation is now under control."

He noted that the extent of CD piracy in Hong Kong was shrinking rapidly due to the hard work of the largest dedicated professional enforcement unit in the world.

"We take a two pronged enforcement strategy directed at the supply side and the retail end of the pirated CD business in our community," he said.

The Prevention of Copyright Piracy Ordinance came into force in August last year, requiring CD factories to operate under Customs licence.

"Having been assured of the legitimacy of our licensed factories, our investigation teams would turn to concentrate their energy on the underground plants," Mr Tsang noted.

He pointed out that since last September, Customs officers had cracked 11 underground CD factories and seized 18 production lines worth some $100 million.

"Without a local source, supply of pirated CDs to the local market now comes mainly from nearby areas, as evident by the upsurge in our interceptions made at the airport, land and marine boundaries," he went on.

So far this year, Customs officers had intercepted some 800,000 CDs at these boundary points, he noted.

"We are also putting tremendous pressure on pirated CD retail outlets in notorious shopping arcades," he said.

Apart from the 300 odd officers of the Intellectual Property Investigation Bureau, the Department has set up a 185-member Special Task Force to tackle the piracy problem on the street level.

The Special Task Force, drawing resources from other Customs formations to make up a 300 strong team on any major outing, launched its first territory-wide anti-piracy operation on June 30, Mr Tsang said.

"Up to the end of August, just in a mere two months' time, some 750 shops have been raided, over 600 people arrested, and two million pirated products seized," he added.

He noted that due to the heightened enforcement pressure against the sale of pirated CDs, officers of the Special Task Force had encountered increasing resistance by illicit operators.

Mr Tsang, however, maintained that the resistance would not affect morale of the officers but helped to strengthen their resolve.

Speaking on police involvement in tackling the retail sale of pirated and counterfeit goods, Mr Tsang said Customs had a close working relationship with the Police.

"Joint operations are mounted from time to time with raids at shopping arcades and hawking areas.

In addition, the Police and Customs have a standing arrangement of exchanging intelligence on IPR violations on a weekly basis," he added.

He noted that the use of repeated enforcement actions in the notorious black spots had proved its effectiveness.

"We have now broken the back of the illicit business in the popular areas.

Vendors of pirated CDs have been forced out of their mainstream bases to operate underground, or to resort to very short-term leases in long vacated premises.

"We intend to do even more on the legislative side to enhance our enforcement," he stressed.

The proposals, he cited, included amendments to make unauthorised recordings in cinemas an offence, to broaden the definition of infringing activities to include anything other than those intended for personal and domestic purposes, to incorporate copyright and counterfeiting offences into the Organised and Serious Crimes Ordinance for the purposes of attracting heavier penalties and forfeiture of monetary proceeds from such illegal activities.

"We are also considering other amendments which will help facilitate enforcement.

Obviously, the degree of severity of these measures would have to be acceptable to the public," he said.

On courts punishment, Mr Tsang said, "our courts also consider that IPR protection is critical for the protection of our society."

He added they had handed down heavy sentences to underline their resolve.

"Recent sentences reached as high as 39 months of imprisonment and $1.04 million of fine.

Both cases concerned manufacturing of infringing CDs," he noted.

Turning to the role played by the industry in protecting intellectual property, Mr Tsang emphasized that the success of their strategy rested with the commitment of the industry.

Customs was the sole enforcement agent for the statutory offences, he explained, adding that the primary responsibility for the protection of the rights rested invariable with the property rights owners who could take civil litigations against unauthorised exploitation of those rights.

"We maintain our already close working relationship with the industry," he said.

Customs has been managing the Anti-Piracy Reward Scheme funded by the industry since 1998 and some $1.3 million of reward money has been paid so far for information leading to successful prosecutions.

The Commissioner said the industry had been very supportive in general in helping the Department verify the authenticity of the seized CDs and provide the necessary administrative support in criminal prosecution.

"In June this year, we have jointly launched with the Business Software Alliance the Genuine Software Action Campaign to give recognition to organisations with good internal software management," he continued.

He noted that the programme had generated a great deal of interest in the community.

Mr Tsang noted that the piracy problem could not be uprooted by mere stringent enforcement alone.

"Incessant demand from the public will sustain the illicit trade, thereby nullifying the enforcement efforts and bringing irrevocable damage to Hong Kong's economy and reputation," he explained.

The long-term solution, therefore, rested with education in changing people's mentality, and in raising respect for intellectual property, he concluded.
19990904_007.e:
HK Customs praised for its good work

The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, today (Saturday) praised the Hong Kong Customs for its good work, which had contributed greatly to the society.

Mr Tung said this when inspecting the Customs and Excise Department's Departmental Review to mark its 90th Anniversary at the Customs and Excise Training School in Tuen Mun.

He noted that the Department had taken vigorous actions against rights infringement activities and had established close links with mainland land international law enforcement authorities as well as the relevant authorities to protect intellectual property rights.

"The Department's success in law enforcement has helped upholding the law and order of Hong Kong.

The fine balance that it has maintained between law enforcement and trade facilitation has enhanced our competitiveness and strengthened our position as one of the finest commercial centres in the world," Mr Tung said.

More importantly, he noted that the Department had proven to the world through its unrelenting boundary control and active participation in the international customs arena that Hong Kong remained a separate customs territory after its return to China, and that the concept of "one country, two systems" had been implemented successfully in Hong Kong.

"With the approach of the 21st Century, we commit ourselves to developing Hong Kong into a centre of innovation and technology," Mr Tung went on.

To achieve this goal, he pointed out that the Customs and Excise Department shall continue to play an important role in the protection of intellectual property rights.

The history of the Customs and Excise Department can be traced back to its predecessor, the Preventive Service, which was set up in 1909 with a small establishment of 26 Revenue Officers.

Over the past nine decades, Hong Kong has transformed from a seaport into a leading international commercial centre.

The Department has also undergone considerable expansion in both its establishment and scope of responsibilities.

With an establishment of 5,200 strong staff members, the Customs and Excise Department is now a major Department under the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, committed to the enforcement of 48 different pieces of legislation.

Taking part in today's Departmental Review were 257 Customs officers from various Commands of the Department.

Photo: The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, inspecting the Customs and Excise Department's 90th Anniversary Departmental review at the Department's Training School in Tuen Mun
19990126_010.e:
Significant contributions by HK Customs

The Customs and Excise Department contributes significantly to law and order and the economic well-being of Hong Kong.

This was said today (Tuesday) by the President of the Legislative Council, Mrs Rita Fan, when addressing the 1999 International Customs Day launched by the Hong Kong Customs.

"The Department detects and prevents illegal movements of goods into or out of Hong Kong, and protects and collects revenue on dutiable commodities," Mrs Fan noted.

In addition, the Hong Kong Customs provided efficient import and export clearance services to legitimate trade, suppressed narcotics trafficking and drug abuses, enforced protection on intellectual property rights, consumer interests in product safety, weights and measures and other trading standards, she added.

"I am impressed with the professionalism and dedication of officers of the Hong Kong Customs in performing these duties," she said.

Mrs Fan noted that the celebration of the International Customs Day was held in Hong Kong because Hong Kong was a staunch supporter of the World Customs Organisation (WCO), and Hong Kong Customs actively took part in international customs activities and supported international customs co-operation.

In recognition of Hong Kong Customs' contributions, the WCO elected Hong Kong a member of of its Policy Commissioner for two years in July 1998.

The 1999 International Customs Day is the second remarkable event launched by the Hong Kong Customs since Hong Kong became a Special Administrative Region of China.

Hong Kong became a full member of the WCO in 1987 and this is the 12th year it has celebrated the International Customs Day.

The annual event is a means of promoting Customs co-operation and forging closer links among Customs officials of different Customs Administrations.

More than 300 guests, including members of the Executive and Legislative Councils, senior government officials, counsels-general and foreign Customs attaches, and top executives from trade and business organisations, attended today's reception at the Customs and Excise Service Senior Officers' Mess.
19980117_001.e:
HK plays active role in protecting intellectual property rights 

As an important financial and trading centre in the world, Hong Kong has been playing an active role in the protection of intellectual property.

The Chief Executive, Mr TUNG Chee Hwa, said this today (Saturday) at the passing-out parade of the Customs and Excise Training School.

Mr Tung noted that after the establishment of the Special Administrative Region, Hong Kong continued to function effectively as a separate customs territory under the existing trading systems and committed itself to the successful implementation of the "one country, two systems" concept.

"The Customs and Excise Department undertakes a wide range of responsibilities, including revenue collection, anti-narcotics and anti-smuggling work, protection of intellectual property rights and consumer interests, trade facilitation as well as trade controls," he said.

The Department, which is also responsible for all operation for the detection of pirated and counterfeit goods, works closely with overseas law-enforcers as well as trademark and copyright owners in its fight against acts of infringement.

"The service of the Department in recent years has been outstanding particularly in the area of protection of copyright and trademarks," he noted.

Mr Tung told the officers at the parade that he was confident that they would continue to step up their action in combating piracy and counterfeiting for the protection of intellectual property rights.

"I am also pleased to note that your Department is in process of modernisation in areas such as information technology and human resources management.

New computer systems are being installed.

Equipment has been upgraded for greater safety and better duty performance," Mr Tung said.

He noted that arrangements have also been made for the building of new customs launches and that Customs Headquarters building was on the drawing board.

"All these point to the fact that the Department is a progressive and forward-looking organisation, moving forward into a new era and will continue to play an important role in the Special Administrative Region," Mr Tung concluded.

Thirty-one probationary inspectors and 106 probationary Customs officers took part in the parade today.
19990904_008.e:
Chief Executive's speech at Anniversary of Customs and Excise Department

Following is the full text of the speech by the Chief Executive of the HKSAR, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, at the Departmental Review in celebration of the 90th Anniversary of the Customs and Excise Department today (Saturday):

Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, officers on parade,

It gives me great pleasure to take part in today's Departmental Review, which marks the 90th Anniversary of the Customs and Excise Department.

The smart turnout and dignified bearing of the officers on parade just now have not only reflected their own merit as a group of well-trained disciplinary officers, but also brought great pride and honour to the Department as a whole.

The history of the Customs and Excise Department can be traced back to its predecessor, the Preventive Service, which was set up in 1909 with a small establishment of 26 Revenue Officers.

Over the past nine decades, Hong Kong has transformed from a petty seaport into a leading international commercial centre.

The Department has also undergone considerable expansion in both its establishment and scope of responsibilities.

With an establishment of 5,200 strong staff members, the Customs and Excise Department is now a major department under the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, committed to the enforcement of 48 different pieces of legislation.

Despite the ever-increasing workload over the years, the Customs and Excise Department has made outstanding achievements in the discharge of its multifaceted duties, including the protection of revenue on dutiable commodities, the detection of drug trafficking and smuggling, the protection of intellectual property rights and consumer interests, the exercise of import and export controls as well as customs clearance of travellers and goods.

Without the concerted efforts of all members of the Department, its past achievements would not have been possible.

The good work of the Customs and Excise Department has in fact contributed greatly to our society.

The Department's success in law enforcement has helped upholding the law and order of Hong Kong.

More importantly, the Department has proven to the world through its unrelenting boundary control, active participation in the international customs arena and sustained efforts to maintain its independence and autonomy in the control of strategic commodities that Hong Kong remains a separate customs territory after its return to China, and that the concept of "one country, two systems" has been implemented successfully in Hong Kong.

With the advent of the 21st Century, we commit ourselves to developing Hong Kong into a centre of innovation and technology.

To achieve this goal, the Customs and Excise Development shall continue to play an important role in the protection of intellectual property rights.

Full utilisation of high-tech products and respect for intellectual property rights are both essential to the social and economic development of Hong Kong as a whole.

To protect intellectual property rights, the Customs and Excise Department has taken vigorous actions against rights infringement activities and has established close links with mainland and international law enforcement authorities as well as the relevant industries.

The Customs and Excise Department has secured high regard for its effectiveness and efficiency locally as well as in the mainland and throughout the world.

On the auspicious occasion of its 90th Anniversary, I am pleased to extend to the Department my sincere congratulations and take great pride in all the past achievements it has made.

As we move towards the 21st Century, I believe that the Department will carry forward its good tradition and continue its endeavours to provide the community with highly efficient service and contribute to the stability and prosperity of Hong Kong.

I have full confidence that with the joint efforts of all its staff members, the Department will remain highly responsive to the changing environment with sustained determination to stand challenges and achieve higher goals through self-improvement.

Thank you very much.
19990302_020.e:
Expansion of Customs responsibility

The scope of responsibility of the Customs and Excise Department has greatly expanded in the last two years, in particular in the fight against copyright piracy.

Equally notably were the checking of illegal transshipment of textiles and garments and enforcing product safety standards.

This was stated today (Tuesday) by the Commissioner of Customs and Excise, Mr Lawrence Li Shu-fai, when addressing a farewell parade at the Customs and Excise Training School.

More than 300 customs officers from various commands took part in the parade to bid farewell to Mr Li, who will be retiring this month.

"Our establishment has also expanded from 4,273 in 1997 to today's 5,196 to cope with our work which has increased both in volume and in complexity," said Mr Li.

He told the officers in the parade that they were a professional and conscientious workforce that contributed to the stability and economic well being of Hong Kong.

He also outlined significant progress of the department in the last two years.

This included the relocation from Kai Tak to the New Airport at Chek Lap Kok, the development of a new air cargo clearance system to enhance their efficiency and to improve their customer service and the operation at the River Trade Terminal to provide customs clearance service for cargo imported by river trade vessels.

"We laid the foundation stone for the Kwai Chung Customhouse scheduled for completion next year.

We started publishing an in-house news bulletin.

We formed a Retired Officers' Association.

"We are at an advanced stage of establishing an education fund for our children, which is expected to be finalised before the end of this year," he said.

He pointed out that other examples of the progress included the establishment of a marine base at Stonecutters Island, the expansion of Narcotics Dog Unit and the purchase of six new customs launches and two mobile x-ray examination systems for containers.

"I feel happy to have spent my entire career with the Customs and Excise Department in which I have served for 35 years and of which I was the Commissioner since 1996," he noted.

Mr Li, in conclusion, stressed that he was confident that professionalism and enthusiasm displayed by the officers would ensure that the department continued to develop.

LQ14: Charitable institutions under IRD

Following is a question by the Hon Christine LOH Kung-wai and a written reply by the Secretary for the Treasury, Miss Denise Yue, in the Legislative Council today (Wednesday):

Question :

I have received reports that a number of social organisations had their charitable body status removed by the Administration.

In this connection, will the Administration inform this Council :

(a) whether it has changed the qualifying criteria for charitable bodies;

(b) which and how government bureaux and departments are involved in the assessment of charitable bodies;

(c) of those organisations that had their charitable body status removed in the last two years and the basis for removing such status;

(d) of the number of charitable bodies currently being reassessed for their status; and

(e) whether it has assessed how the reassessment will benefit the Administration and the community ?

Reply :

Section 88 of the Inland Revenue Ordinance (IRO) (Cap. 112) provides tax exemption for charitable institutions.

The term "charitable institution" is however not separately defined in the IRO.

In considering whether an organisation can be accepted as a charitable institution for tax exemption purposes under the Ordinance, the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) has applied the meaning given to the term in English case law.

Based on an authoritative court decision, purposes that may be accepted as charitable can be categorised as follows -

(i) relief of poverty;

(ii) advancement of education;

(iii) advancement of religion; and

(iv) other purposes of a charitable nature beneficial to the community not falling under any of the preceding categories.

IRD has all along adopted the above criteria in determining whether an organisation can be accepted as a charitable institution for tax exemption purposes.

With regard to part (a) of the question, we have not changed the criteria for recognising charitable institutions under section 88 of the IRO recently.

However, since 1990 we have not been granting tax exemption status to overseas charities unless the charities concerned establish themselves in Hong Kong.

We are presently reviewing the tax exemption status previously granted to overseas charities and will withdraw the exemption if the charities are not established in Hong Kong.

With regard to part (b) of the question, IRD is responsible for recognising charitable institutions or trusts for the purpose of granting exemption under the IRO.

The Department will examine, among other things, the governing instrument of the organisation concerned.

In particular, it will scrutinise the object clause, income clause and dissolution clause to ensure that all the objects of the organisation are charitable and that there are adequate safeguards to prevent the channelling of funds for non-charitable purposes.

To confirm that the objects of organisations are still charitable and their activities are compatible with their objects, the Department will review the recognised charitable organisations in cycles of approximately four years.

With regard to part (c) of the question, during the financial years 1996-97 and 1997-98, tax exemption was withdrawn in 117 cases.

Any removal of names from the list of approved charities due to the withdrawal of tax exemption granted is published in the Government Gazette at quarterly intervals.

An updated list of all approved charities is gazetted annually.

Tax exemption will be withdrawn under various circumstances including -

(i) the organisation has not replied to the IRD's enquiries arising from the periodic review;

(ii) the organisation is carrying out an act which is not authorised by its governing instrument;

(iii) the organisation has ceased its activities or is dormant; or

(iv) the organisation has been dissolved or wound up.

With regard to part (d) of the question, as of now, IRD is reassessing the status of 134 charitable organisations.

With regard to part (e) of the question, it is necessary to review the charities periodically so as to ensure that only those entities recognised as charitable organisations under the IRO should be granted tax exemption.

Where it is considered that a recognised institution can no longer be regarded as a charitable institution for purposes of the IRO, the tax exemption previously granted will be withdrawn.

Upon the withdrawal of tax exemption, the organisation concerned will be subject to the provisions of the IRO in respect of its tax liability, if any.

19990330_009.e:
All gear up for changeover of ferry franchise

The Transport Department today (Tuesday) announces that gearing up for the changeover of franchised ferry services currently operated by Hongkong and Yaumati Ferry Company Limited (HYF) is approaching the final countdown.

The transition will take place shortly after midnight on March 31 following the expiry of the franchise of HYF.

In reviewing the progress to-date, a spokesman for the department said: "Details of the logistics on the transitional arrangements have been finalised.

"These include the phased handing-over of piers and the setting up of a coordination centre to monitor the changeover."

The Transport Department will activate a special Operation Coordination Centre (OCC) at its headquarters from 6 pm tomorrow to 9 am the next morning and from 4 pm to 8 pm on April 1.

The spokesman said the coordination centre would maintain a close liaison with ferry operators and related government departments to ensure a smooth transition.

"In addition, the department will deploy observation teams to major ferry piers to monitor service levels and passengers' demand on the first day of the changeover.

"More than 60 TD staff will be involved in monitoring the transition.

"The department will put in their best effort to ensure a smooth transition and a satisfactory continuation of ferry services to meet passengers' demand," he added.

The current franchise of HYF will expire by the end of this month.

A total of 16 outlying islands, new town and inner harbour ferry routes, including the Central - Hung Hom ferry service now operating by "Star" Ferry Company Limited, were offered for open tender last year in eight packages.

All outlying island services, except those serving the Lamma Island, and the North Point - Hung Hom and Kowloon City ferry route will continue to be operated by HYF.

The Yung Shue Wan and Sok Kwu Wan services will be operated by Hong Kong and Kowloon Ferry Company Limited (HKK).

The Central - Tsim Sha Tsui East ferry route will be operated by Discovery Bay Transportation Services Limited.

The "Star" Ferry will run the Hung Hom - Central and Wan Chai route while Tune Mun ferry services will be operated by Shun Tak Ferries Limited.

As the sole bidder for the North Point - Kwun Tong service failed to meet all essential tender requirements, this inner harbour ferry route will be cancelled from April 1.

All ferry routes will be operated as licensed services for a period of three years starting from April 1 to March 31, 2002.

"Overnight services will be provided to serve residents of Cheung Chau, Mui Wo and Peng Chau.

"For the outlying islands, ferry services will be strengthened with the provision of more ferry trips and a mixture of both fast and slow vessels to cater for demands of different passengers," the spokesman said.

The number of trips serving Cheung Chau will be increased from 58 to 80 while those plying between Mui Wo and Peng Chau will be strengthened from 49 to 60 and from 46 to 53 respectively.

There will also be more trips for Yung Shue Wan (from 46 to 60 trips) and Sok Kwu Wan (from 20 to 22 trips) by HKK.

The spokesman noted that there would be considerable changes in the timetable, operating hours, piers as well as fares for the new licensed ferry routes after March 31.

The new berthing points of the affected ferry routes are as follows:

* Lamma Island routes : Central Pier No.5

* Tuen Mun routes : Central Pier No.4

* Cheung Chau route : Central Pier No.6

* Mui Wo/Peng Chau route : Central Pier No.7

* Hung Hom-North Point route: Hung Hom (North) Pier

* Hung Hom-Central/Wan Chai route : Hung Hom (South) Pier

* Wan Chai-Hung Hom route: Wan Chai East Pier

The spokesman reminded passengers, especially holiday makers, that they should check carefully in advance details of the sailings they want to take.

"Passengers are also advised to arrive at the piers earlier in the initial period of the new operation to allow themselves to react to any unforeseen delay," he added.

Operational details of the new licensed services are available at the home page of the Transport Department (http://www.info.gov.hk/td) as well as that of the HYF (http://www.hkf.com).

Distribution of timetables at different ferry piers has begun from March 23.

To further assist passengers, special enquiry hotlines have been set up by the Transport Department and five ferry companies (see Annex A).

"With concerted effort from all sides, we are confident that smooth transition can be attained and satisfactory services can be provided for the travelling public," the spokesman said.

19980317_004.e:
Govt approves new franchise for Star Ferry 

The Chief Executive in Council today (Tuesday) approved the grant of a new franchise to "Star" Ferry Company, Limited (Star Ferry) conferring upon the Company the right to operate the Central - Tsim Sha Tsui route and the Wan Chai - Tsim Sha Tsui route for ten years, and the Central - Hung Hom route for one year.

"The decision is made having regard to the ferry policy and Star Ferry's performance," the Government spokesman said.

Ferries provide an essential link to the outlying islands where land transport alternatives are not available.

They also provide a useful alternative in relieving pressure on the road system between Central and the new towns.

In the inner harbour, ferries play a supplementary role.

Ferry services in Hong Kong are mainly provided by two franchisees - Hongkong and Yaumati Ferry Company Limited (HYF) and Star Ferry.

Recreational services, special services such as vehicular services for dangerous goods vehicles, and other non-essential services are provided by licensed operators, whose licences are granted by the Commissioner for Transport.

"As regards Star Ferry's services, the two Tsim Sha Tsui routes carry a substantial number of passengers and are widely perceived by both tourists and the local community as part of Hong Kong's heritage.

The Council considered that the two routes should be preserved and approved the grant of a ten-year franchise," the Government spokesman said.

"As for the Central - Hung Hom route, it mainly provides a supplementary service as alternative land transport is available.

In order to allow the Government more time to review this route together with the other Hung Hom ferry services being operated by HYF, whose franchise will expire on March 31, 1999, we have decided to let Star Ferry continue to operate the Central - Hung Hom route for another year to tie in with the expiry of the franchise of the HYF Hung Hom routes."

"We have an open mind as to the future mode of operation of the Hung Hom routes and will review these services later this year.

In reviewing the operation of these services, we will of course take into account the travelling needs of local residents, the commercial viability of these routes and the need to improve the operating efficiency of these services," he continued.
20000113_008.e:
Transfer of HYF's ferry licences to NWFF on 15 January 2000

The licensed ferry services for Cheung Chau, Mui Wo, Peng Chau and between North Point and Hung Hom/ Kowloon City currently operated by the Hongkong and Yaumati Ferry Co. Ltd. (HYF) will be taken over by New World First Ferry Services Ltd. (NWFF) with effect from 1.30 am on January 15, 2000.

A Transport Department (TD) spokesman said: "To maintain normal operation and allow spare vessels for the 8 ferry routes, NWFF will deploy a fleet of 26 vessels to run its services.

To ensure a smooth transition, there will not be any change to the service schedules or fare levels of the 8 routes during the initial period of operation."

TD will set up an Operation Co-ordination Centre (OCC) at its Headquarters on 14 and 15 January 2000 as well as on 17 January 2000 to monitor the ferry changeover and the ferry operation on the first weekday after the changeover.

A standby team will be on duty in the intervening period.

The OCC will be supported by TD's Site Observation Teams at the ferry piers.

There are contingency plans to support smooth operation of ferry services particularly in the initial period of ferry operation.

There will be spare vessels to operate supplementary sailings if necessary.

NWFF will also deploy more pier staff in the initial period of operation for passenger control and counting purposes.

Tests have also been conducted on the ticketing system to ensure proper functioning.

To keep inconvenience to the minimum, mobile Octopus fare collecting machines will be deployed for fare collection should there be a breakdown of the Octopus machine.

"Transport Department will closely monitor the operation of ferry services and will work closely with NWFF," the spokesman said.

"Passengers are reminded that the new ferry operator should be allowed time to settle down and identify passenger needs before considering appropriate changes to the ferry services."
19980723_002.e:
Invitation to indicate interest in ferry operation

The Transport Department invites operators to indicate whether they are interested in taking up 12 ferry routes currently operated by Hongkong and Yaumati Ferry Company Limited (HYF) from April 1, 1999.

The franchise for HYF to operate these routes will expire on March 31 next year.

Speaking on the invitation, a spokesman for the department said: "The Government is now actively negotiating with HYF on the terms of its new franchise.

"However, if progress is unsatisfactory, the Government may consider tendering out ferry services in a number of packages.

"The invitation to indicate interest is to gauge market's response in operating these routes."

The 12 routes, comprising mainly services for the outlying islands, Tuen Mun and the inner harbour, are grouped into seven packages.

The packages are:

* Package A: Central - Cheung Chau

Inner-islands (Peng Chau - Mui Wo - Chi Ma

Wan - Cheung Chau)

* Package B: Central - Mui Wo

Central - Peng Chau

* Package C: Central - Yung Shue Wan

Central - Sok Kwu Wan

* Package D: Central - Tuen Mun

* Package E: Tsim Sha Tsui East - Central

* Package F: North Point - Kwun Tong

North Point - Hung Hom

North Point - Kowloon City

* Package G: Wan Chai - Hung Hom

The spokesman noted that the invitation is not a tender exercise.

It is issued on a non-committal basis and will not prejudice current negotiations with HYF.

"The Government aims to conclude the negotiation with HYF as soon as possible so as to ensure ferry services, particular those essential routes serving the outlying islands, will be maintained," he added.

Interested parties may indicate interest in operating one or a combination of several packages.

They are required to submit information on the companies' experience and competence in operating ferry services as well as the vessels available for deployment by April 1, 1999.

"HYF is also welcome to indicate its interest," the spokesman said.

Forms and details of the ferry services can be obtained from the Transport Department, Room 4021, 40th floor, Immigration Tower, 7 Gloucester Road, Wan Chai, Hong Kong.

All submissions, clearly marked with "Indication of Interest in Operating Ferry Services" on the envelope, should reach the department at the above address by noon on August 15, 1998.
19981103_009.e:
Outlying islands ferry service licences awarded

The Commissioner for Transport, Mrs Fanny Law, today (Tuesday) announced that the licences to operate various outlying islands ferry routes would be awarded to Hongkong and Yaumati Ferry Company Limited (HYF) and Hong Kong & Kowloon Ferry Limited (HKK).

These ferry licences are for a period of three years, starting April 1, 1999 to March 31, 2002.

A total of eight routes, grouped into three packages, were offered for open tender in September.

HYF will provide ferry services under Package I and II, while HKK will operate routes under Package III.

Package I comprises ferry services between Cheung Chau - Central, Cheung Chau - Kowloon Point (excursion route) and an inter-islands route.

Package II is made up of services between Mui Wo - Central; Mui Wo - Kowloon Point (excursion route) and Peng Chau - Central.

Package III covers Yung Shue Wan - Central route and Sok Kwu Wan - Central route which serve mainly residents of the Lamma Island.

Speaking at a press conference on the tender results, Mrs Law said: "The tender exercise has attracted a good turnout.

"It enhances competition and serves to widen the trawl for the Government to locate the most suitable operators for outlying islands ferry services."

The Transport Department had received altogether 10 bids from six companies when the tender closed on October 12.

An inter-departmental assessment committee chaired by a Deputy Commissioner for Transport had been set up to study the tenders.

Other members included representatives from the Transport Department, Marine Department, Home Affairs Department, Department of Justice and the Independent Commission Against Corruption.

The Tender Assessment Committee evaluated tenders on the basis of:

* the level and quality of services proposed;

* fares and passenger facilities proposed;

* suitability and quality of vessels proposed;

* the corporate and financial capabilities of the tenderers;

* the quality and fares of freight services proposed; and

* proposed marine contingency plans.

Mrs Law noted that the two successful tenderers are experienced operators in providing ferry services in Hong Kong.

At present, HYF is running 12 franchised ferry routes and six licensed services, while HKK takes on three licensed ferry services.

"Both HYF and HKK have committed in their bids the provision of quality ferry services at reasonable fares for passengers.

"New vessels will be purchased.

The number of trips will be increased while journey time will be reduced with the employment of more high speed vessels.

"Ferry services for the outlying islands, which are essential due to a lack of land transportation alternatives, will be much improved, while fares will remain at levels similar to those of existing ones," Mrs Law said.

For instance, fare for each single trip to Cheung Chau, Mui Wo and Peng Chau from Central by fast ferries will be reduced from $24 to $20 in 1999 and $21 in 2000.

On the employment of HYF staff, Mrs Law pointed out that HYF would retain most of its existing staff for operating these new licensed ferry services.

"HKK will recruit a number of HYF staff to fill all posts required to operate their new licensed services.

"The number of staff to be recruited by HKK should not be less than those currently deployed by HYF for the same ferry services," she added.

Mrs Law assured the public that the Government would provide all necessary assistance for both companies in gearing up their operation to commence services in April next year.

"We trust that HYF and HKK will cooperate with each other in ensuring a smooth transition.

"Early meetings between the two operators will be arranged to discuss and firm up essential detailed arrangements," she said.
19990316_007.e:
Changes in Ferry Services on 1 April 1999

The Transport Department announces today the operational details of the outlying island, new town and inner harbour licensed ferry services on April 1, 1999 and reminds passengers of the new timetables and fares of these services.

"After the expiry of the current franchise on March 31, HYF's outlying island, new town and inner harbour ferry services as well as "Star" Ferry's Central - Hung Hom service will be operated as licensed services by five ferry operators : HYF, "Star" Ferry, Hong Kong and Kowloon Ferry Company Limited (HKK), Discovery Bay Transportation Services Limited (DBTSL) and Shun Tak Ferries Limited," a spokesman said.

"There will be considerable changes in the timetable, operating hours as well as fares on these services."

All the outlying island services, except the Yung Shue Wan and Sok Kwu Wan services, will continue to be operated by HYF after March 31.

The Yung Shue Wan and Sok Kwu Wan services will be operated by HKK.

These services to the Lamma Island will operate from Central Pier No. 5.

The first ferry trip operated by HYF on April 1, will depart at 12.30 am from Central Pier No. 6 to Cheung Chau, while the first ferry trip operated by HKK will depart at 12.30 am from Central Pier No. 5 to Yung Shue Wan.

"Overall speaking, more ferry trips will be provided to Cheung Chau (from 58 to 80 trips), Mui Wo (From 49 to 60 trips) and Peng Chau (from 46 to 53 trips).

With the changes in timetable and with a mixture of fast and slow ferries service, passengers are advised to check carefully the sailings they want to take.

In addition, overnight trips will be provided to these outlying islands.

The number of trips for the Yung Shue Wan (from 46 to 60 trips) and Sok Kwu Wan services (from 20 to 22 trips) will also be increased."

For the new town and inner harbour services, the operating hours will be similar to the existing services, but some of them will operate from different piers after March 31, e.g.

Shun Tak's Tuen Mun service will operate from Central Pier No. 4, "Star" Ferry's two Hung Hom services will operate from Hung Hom (South) Pier and HYF's Hung Hom - North Point service will operate from Hung Hom (North) Pier.

Passengers can later find the detailed timetable, operating hours and fares of all these licensed services at TD's Homepage (http://www.info.gov.hk/td/) as well as the homepage of HYF (http://www.hkf.com).

Distribution of timetables on ferry piers will begin on March 23, 1999.

"As explained above, some of the ferry services will operate at different piers after March 31.

Though clear directional signs will be provided, passengers are advised to check carefully to ensure boarding the night service.

Given the considerable changes to the operational details, passengers are also advised to check carefully the timetable, operating hours and fares of the ferry services before they plan their trips," the spokesman said.

"Although the transition of ferry services is expected to be smooth, passengers should arrive at the piers earlier in the initial period of the new operation and allow themselves more time to react to any unforeseen delay," he said.

The Transport Department will operate a coordinating centre to ensure a smooth transition of ferry services.

The centre will be activated on March 31, 1999 and oversee the initial operation of the new services.

19981120_015.e:
Eight bids for new town/inner harbour ferry services

The Transport Department has received eight bids from six tenderers for licences to operate various new town and inner harbour ferry routes.

A total of five packages of ferry services were offered for open tender on October 30.

Details of the tenders received are as follows:

(1) Package A: (one bid)

* Central - Tuen Mun

* Central - Tuen Mun - Sha Lo Wan - Tai O (excursion

service)

(2) Package B: (two bids)

* Central - Tsim Sha Tsui (East)

(3) Package C: (no bid)

* North Point - Kwun Tong

(4) Package D: (two bids)

* Ferry service(s) for North Point, Hung Hom and

Kowloon City

(5) Package E: (three bids)

* Ferry service(s) for Hung Hom, Wan Chai and

Central

Speaking on the tender exercise which was closed at noon today (Friday), a spokesman for the department said: "New town and inner harbour ferry routes are largely supplementary services.

"The objective of the tender exercise is to let the market determine the viability, fare and service levels of these routes."

An inter-departmental assessment committee chaired by a Deputy Commissioner for Transport has been set up to study and evaluate the tenders.

The committee comprises representatives from the Transport Department, Marine Department, Labour Department, Civil Engineering Department, Home Affairs Department and the Independent Commission Against Corruption.

The Tender Assessment Committee will assess tenders on the basis of:

* fares and level of service proposed;

* suitability and quality of vessels proposed; and

* corporate and financial capability of the tenderer.

The spokesman noted that the department is satisfied with the overall response to the tender invitation.

"It reflects considerable market interest in the operation of inner harbour ferry routes even in face of strong competition from cross harbour bus services and the Mass Transit Railway.

"Selection exercise is expected to be completed by next month," the spokesman said.

Ferry services under new operators will commence operation in April next year.

However, as there is no bidder for the North Point - Kwun Tong route, this ferry service will cease after its current franchise expires on March 31, 1999.

"Patronage of the North Point-Kwun Tong ferry route is low and there are convenient road and rail transport alternatives.

"Therefore, discontinuation of the services should not have any significant impact on passengers and road traffic.

"The Department will monitor closely the situation and strengthen parallel bus services if necessary," the spokesman added.
19981215_014.e:
Inner harbour ferry service licences awarded

The Transport Department today (Tuesday) announced that licences to operate various inner harbour ferry routes would be awarded to Discovery Bay Transportation Services Limited, Hongkong and Yaumati Ferry Company Limited (HYF)and "Star" Ferry Company Limited.

These ferry licences are for a period of three years, from April 1, 1999 to March 31, 2002.

A total of eight new town and inner harbour ferry services, grouped into five packages, were offered for open tender on October 30.

These services are largely supplementary services with convenient land transport alternatives.

The objective of the tender exercise is to let market forces determine their viability, fare and service levels.

The Transport Department received altogether eight bids from six companies when the tender closed on November 20.

Discovery Bay Transportation Services Limited will be providing the Central - Tsim Sha Tsui East service under Package B, HYF will operate the North Point - Hung Hom and Kowloon City services under Package D, and "Star" Ferry Company Limited will run the Hung Hom - Central and Wan Chai services under Package E.

As for Package A, a spokesman for the department said there was only one bidder for the package, which comprised the Central - Tuen Mun ferry service and an excursion route serving Central, Tuen Mun, Sha Lo Wan and Tai O.

"We are still discussing with the sole bidder the vessel types to be deployed for this service.

As there is only one bidder for Package A and most importantly, we would want to provide the successful bidders of the other inner harbour services with as much time as possible to gear up for their operation, the assessment for Package A will be conducted separately," he said.

"The package will be granted to the tenderer subject to its meeting the tender requirements," he added.

There was no bidder for the North Point - Kwun Tong service under Package C.

"The North Point - Kwun Tong service is a loss-making service where patronage has been steadily declining over the past few years.

Since patronage is low and convenient alternatives including MTR and buses are readily available, there should not be any significant impact on passengers or land traffic if the ferry service ceases operation.

"We will monitor the situation and strengthen parallel services if necessary."

An inter-departmental assessment committee chaired by a Deputy Commissioner for Transport has been set up to assess the tenders.

Members included representatives from the Transport Department, Marine Department,Labour Department, Civil Engineering Department, Home Affairs Department, and the Independent Commission Against Corruption.

The successful tenderers have been chosen on the basis of the level of service to be provided, the fares to be charged, the quality of vessels and passenger facilities, and the corporate and financial capability of the tenderers.

All three successful tenderers are ferry operators experienced in providing ferry services in Hong Kong.

"Through competitive tendering, the market has found the levels of fares and services which could make the ferry services viable.

These levels are in general comparable with, and in some cases the fares are lower than, the existing ones," the spokesman said.

"For the Hung Hom Package, the proposed adult fare will be the same for the two routes - Hung Hom to Wan Chai and Hung Hom to Central.

Compared to the existing fares, the fares for the Hung Hom - Wan Chai route will be similar while the fares for Hung Hom - Central route will be higher.

"The current fares for the Hung Hom - Central route (now run by 'Star' Ferry) have been artificially suppressed through cross-subsidisation from 'Star' Ferry's other operation under the current franchise.

The service is not viable on the basis of the existing fare structure, and the tender result simply reflects what the market could accept.

"Even with the new fares, travel by ferry between Hung Hom and Central, and between Hung Hom and Wan Chai will remain the cheapest public transport mode," he added.

Transition is expected to be smooth in April 1999, with HYF retaining most of its staff for the North Point services, and "Star" Ferry retaining all of its staff for the Central - Hung Hom service.

For the other services, "Star" Ferry and Discovery Bay Transportation Services Limited will make a first offer to HYF's existing staff to fill all available vacancies.

"The Government will provide all necessary assistance for the successful tenderers to gear up for operation to commence on April 1 next year," the spokesman said.
19980915_006.e:
Review of HYF's franchise

The Chief Executive-in-Council today (Tuesday) directed that the present negotiations with the Hongkong and Yaumati Ferry Company Limited (HYF) and the Hong Kong Ferry (Holdings) Limited (HKF) on the pier development package at Central proposed by the companies should cease.

The Chief Executive-in-Council also directed that HYF's present outlying islands, inner harbour and new town services, together with the Central to Hung Hom service operated by the "Star" Ferry Company Limited, should be grouped into different packages and put to public tender as licensed services.

Announcing the decision of the Chief Executive-in-Council, a government spokesman said HYF and HKF were requested on July 21, 1998 to give their written acceptance of the general terms of the pier development and ferry services package by the middle of August 1998.

HYF and HKF confirmed on August 14, 1998 that they did not accept the terms.

HYF proposed to de-link ferry operations from the pier development project and indicated interests in operating selected segmented routes insofar they were financially viable.

Speaking on the issue, the spokesman said, "Our immediate priority is to ensure continuity of ferry services, in particular the services to the outlying islands which have no land transport alternatives, should be maintained and further improved after HYF's current franchise expires on March 31, 1999.

"Having regard to the changing pattern of ferry patronage and continuous improvement in land transport infrastructure, we consider that the more flexible mode of operation by way of a licence, which is normally granted for a period of three years, should be adopted to ensure provision of essential ferry services on the one hand, and to allow swift adjustment to the changing ferry services market on the other.

"Given different outlying islands may have different characteristics in terms of patronage, and service and vessel requirements, we decide to divide the six outlying islands routes into different packages and tender them out as licensed services to attract good operators who would like to focus on specific routes but might otherwise be deterred from entering into the market because of its size or the scale of investment required.

The approach would allow the Administration to widen the trawl for the best available operators.

"There is a strong interest in the market for ferry operations in Hong Kong.

A total of 18 companies, including HYF, have submitted returns expressing an interest in operating different packages.

"Taking into account the commercial viability and geographical distribution, the six outlying islands services will be grouped into the following packages for a public tender - Central to Cheung Chau and Inter-islands services, Central to Mui Wo and Peng Chau, and Central to Yung Shue Wan and So Kwu Wan.¡¨

HYF's current franchise will expire on March 31, 1999 and the successful tenderer(s) will be required to operate the outlying islands services from April 1, 1999.

A gazette notice inviting tender submissions on these services will¡@be published on Friday (September 18, 1998), with tender closing at 10 am on October 12, 1998.

HYF and other operators would be free to put in their bids.

"In order to take care of HYF's staff that may be left redundant upon expiry of HYF's current franchise, we will make it a tender condition that if the successful tenderer(s) need to recruit new crew members and pier staff, a first offer of employment to the relevant employees of HYF to fill up the vacant posts available must be made on employment terms and conditions no less favourable than those prevailing in the ferry industry of Hong Kong," the spokesman said.

As regards the inner harbour and new town routes, it is the Administration's policy to rationalise these services since they largely provide supplementary services and there are convenient land transport alternatives.

They would be tendered out as licensed services in different packages and market forces will determine their viability, fare and service levels.

Apart from HYF's six franchised inner harbour and new town services, the franchise of the existing Star Ferry's Central - Hung Hom service will also expire on March 31, 1999.

"Taking into account the commercial viability and geographical distribution, the new town and inner harbour routes will be grouped into five packages for a public tender: Hung Hom to Central and Wan Chai; North Point to Kowloon City and Hung Hom; Central to Tuen Mun; Central to Tsim Sha Tsui East; and North Point to Kwun Tong.

"Priority will be given to the tendering of the six outlying islands services and a separate public tender for the new town and inner harbour will be conducted shortly.

"In arriving at the decision to go out for public tender, the Executive Council has considered carefully the need to ensure continuous ferry services to the outlying islands after March 31, 1999, HYF's submissions, the interests expressed by other operators, the desirability of enhancing healthy competition as well as the Administration's recommendation.

To tender out HYF's franchised services in different number of packages is considered by the Council as the most suitable option in the public interest," the spokesman said.
20000322_005.e:
Fare revision of licensed ferry services on 1 April 2000

The fares on 11 licensed ferry services will be revised with effect from 1 April 2000 in accordance with the licence conditions for the operation of these services.

Three ferry operators viz.

New World First Ferry Services Ltd. (NWFF), "Star" Ferry Co. Ltd. (SF) and Discovery Bay Transportation Services Ltd. (DBTSL) have notified the Government that they will charge new fares on 11 licensed ferry services with effect from 1 April 2000 in accordance with the conditions of their ferry service licences.

The rate of increase ranges from 30 cents to $1.00.

For example, the adult fares in respect of six outlying island ferry routes serving Cheung Chau, Mui Wo, Peng Chau and Chi Ma Wan will be increased by 40 cents to $1.00 depending on the route, vessel type, class of travel and day of the week, while those on five cross-harbour ferry services will be increased by 30 to 50 cents.

"The new fares were specified in the relevant tender submissions for these routes which stipulated the fares for both the first and the second year of operation of the services.

These were taken into consideration in the overall tender assessment and subsequently formed part of the licence conditions," a Transport Department spokesman said.

"The new fares were made known to the public when the ferry service licences were granted in late 1998.

The licences took effect on 1 April 1999.

"In the case of NWFF which took over the operation of 8 licensed ferry services from the Hongkong and Yaumati Ferry Co. Ltd. in January 2000, the prevailing terms and conditions of these licences including the provision for new fares for 1 April 2000 apply equally to NWFF", the spokesman confirmed.

The operators will put up notices at ferry piers of the routes concerned about one week in advance to advise passengers of the new fares.

Passengers may also call the hotlines of the respective operators to obtain details -

- New World First Ferry Services Ltd. at 2131 8181

- "Star" Ferry Co. Ltd. at 2367 7065

- Discovery Bay Transportation Services Ltd. at 2987 7351

19990324_036.e:
Talks on Rendition "Useful"

The Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, has held a "very useful" round of expert discussions on rendition with the Mainland authorities during her visit to Beijing.

"The experts on both sides had a frank exchange of views and gained a deeper understanding of each other's prevailing systems," she said.

Speaking to reporters today (Wednesday) wrapping up her three-day visit to Beijing, she said that both sides acknowledged that given the immense differences in the legal and judicial systems in the Mainland and the HKSAR, the subject is very complicated.

"Both sides are fully committed to exploring a practicable option of arrangement which may be acceptable to both the Mainland and the HKSAR, and to having it put in place as soon as possible.

"We shall need to continue our discussions.

At this stage, we cannot envisage when we would be able to conclude an agreed arrangement with the Mainland.

We hope to hold another round of discussion shortly," Mrs Ip said.

¡§In formulating an arrangement with the Mainland, we would take into account views expressed by the public and legislators.

Any eventual arrangement must be acceptable to the people of Hong Kong.

"The Legislative Council will be consulted on the proposed rendition arrangement after completion of the discussions with the Mainland authorities.

Any legislative proposal to give effect to the rendition arrangement will have to be scrutinised by the council before it is passed into law," she went on.

Apart from meeting senior officials from the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council, who assisted in co-ordination of the expert discussions, Mrs Ip made courtesy calls on the Ministry of Justice and the Supreme People's Court.

She also made use of the opportunity to meet the Director of the Bureau of Entry and Exit Administration, Mr Xu Ganlu.

The Court of Final Appeal's judgment on the right of abode issue was discussed.

The Secretary for Security was accompanied on her Beijing trip by officials from the Security Bureau, the Police, the Department of Justice and the Constitutional Affairs Bureau.

She will return to Hong Kong tomorrow (Thursday).
19990321_002.e:
Rendition talks to be held in Beijing

The Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, will lead a delegation to Beijing tomorrow (Monday) to hold discussions with the Mainland authorities on rendition arrangement.

"The delegation comprises representatives from the Security Bureau, Department of Justice, Police and Constitutional Affairs Bureau," a Government spokesman said.

The Secretary for Security will also make a number of courtesy calls on the Mainland authorities and will return to Hong Kong on March 25.
19971231_007.e:
CS to visit Beijing 

At the invitation of the Director of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs office of the State Council, Mr Liao Hui, the Chief Secretary for Administration, Mrs Anson Chan, will visit Beijing on January 5, 1998 (Monday).

This is the Chief Secretary's first visit since the establishment of the Special Administrative Region Government.

During her stay in Beijing, Mrs Chan will exchange views with Mr Liao on subjects of mutual concern to Hong Kong and the Mainland, with a view to strengthening ties and co-operation.

The Chief Secretary will also take the opportunity to call on other senior Chinese officials.

Details are being finalised.

Mrs Chan will be accompanied by her Administrative Assistant, Mr Clement Leung; her Press Secretary, Ms Kitty Choi; Assistant Director of Information Services, Mr Mak Kwok-wah; and Principal Assistant Secretary for Constitutional Affairs, Ms Wendy Cheung.
19981223_012.e:
Talks on rendition "useful and positive"

The Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, has held useful and positive discussions with the Mainland authorities on rendition during her stay in Beijing.

"The discussions mark a good start to future talks on the subject," she said.

Mrs Ip was speaking to reporters today (Wednesday) at the end of her week-long visit to Beijing and Guangzhou.

The purpose of the visit is to hold exploratory discussions with the Mainland authorities on rendition and to pay courtesy calls on the relevant ministries and state agencies.

"The two sides have exchanged their preliminary views on rendition.

Both sides agree that there is a need to put in place a formal arrangement as soon as possible.

"We have reflected the views and concerns of Hong Kong people on the subject to the Mainland authorities and they have been understanding.

"Further talks will be held in due course," Mrs Ip said.

She explained that it would not be appropriate to disclose details of the rendition discussions while they are on-going, in the same manner as discussions were held with other jurisdictions on related subjects.

"We are now in the exploratory stage only and it is too early to talk about the final package..

In formulating an arrangement with the Mainland, we will of course take into account views expressed by legislators and the public.

"The Legislative Council will be consulted on the proposed rendition arrangement after completion of the discussions with the Mainland authorities.

Any legislative proposal to give effect to the rendition arrangement will have to be supported by the public and scrutinised by LegCo before it could be passed into law," she said.

In Beijing, Mrs Ip met senior officials from the Ministry of Public Security, the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Supreme People's Court, the Supreme People's Procuratorate and the Central Military Commission.

In Guangzhou, she paid courtesy calls on the Guangdong Provincial Public Security Department, the Provincial People's Procuratorate, the Provincial Higher People's Court, the Provincial Justice Department and the Provincial Foreign Affairs Office.

Mrs Ip was accompanied on her Mainland trip by Deputy Secretary for Security, Mr Raymond Wong; Principal Assistant Secretary for Security, Mrs Carrie Willis and Assistant Secretary for Security, Mr Albert Cheuk.

This was Mrs Ip's first visit to the Mainland since she took up the post of Secretary for Security in late August.
19980224_004.e:
Secretary for Constitutional Affairs to visit Beijing 

The Secretary for Constitutional Affairs, Mr Michael Suen, will pay a visit to Beijing between Thursday (February 26) and Saturday this week.

During his stay in Beijing, Mr Suen will call on the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council and other mainland authorities.

He will have working meetings with mainland officials on issues of mutual concern.

Mr Suen will be accompanied by the Assistant Secretary for Constitutional Affairs, Miss Rosanna Law, and Secretariat Press Officer (Constitutional Affairs), Mr Joe Cheung.
19990503_015.e:
CS to visit Beijing

A Government spokesman announced today (Monday) that the Chief Secretary for Administration, Mrs Anson Chan, will visit Beijing tomorrow (Tuesday).

Mrs Chan will take the opportunity to call on Chinese leaders and meet with officials in the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office and other organs of the Central People's Government to discuss subjects of mutual concern to Hong Kong and the Mainland.

Details are being finalised.

Mrs Chan will be accompanied by her Administrative Assistant, Mr Clement Leung; Principal Assistant Secretary for Constitutional Affairs, Ms Carol Yip; Principal Assistant Secretary for Security, Miss Cathy Chu; and Assistant Director of Information Services, Mr S Y Tam.
19991026_011.e:
Immigration Officers on Mainland Visit

The first 10-member delegation of the Immigration Department, headed by a Principal Immigration Officer, will be leaving on November 3 (Wednesday) for a study visit programme in five cities on the Mainland.

The two-week visit programme aims at enhancing understanding and co-operation with the Mainland authorities and promoting better working relations with them.

Principal Immigration Officer (Documents), Mr Choy Tak-po, accompanied by five officers and four rank-and-file members, under the arrangement of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office (HKMAO), will visit counterparts in Beijing, Fuzhou, Xiamen, Guangzhou and Shenzhen to share working experience.

Visits will be paid to the HKMAO, the Public Security Bureau, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Immigration Section of the Beijing Office in Beijing and the Foreign Affairs Office, checkpoints, as well as births and deaths registration offices in other cities.

At a briefing before the departure of the delegation, the Director of Immigration, Mr Ambrose Lee, said that following the reunification, co-operation and communication between the Department and the Mainland authorities are ever increasing.

With a view to facilitating an exchange of knowledge and experience between officers and their Mainland counterparts, we consider a regular study visit programme to the Mainland is highly desirable.

"We hope that such study visits can be organised twice a year so that more officers can participate and benefit," Mr Lee said.

The delegation will return to Hong Kong from Shenzhen on November 15 (Monday).
19990602_005.e:
Working Meeting Held in Beijing

The Secretary for Justice, Miss Elsie Leung, and the Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, this (Wednesday) afternoon held a working meeting in Beijing with officials of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office (HKMAO) under the State Council and the Legislative Affairs Commission of the National People's Congress Standing Committee (NPCSC).

"The purpose of the meeting is to go over the report submitted to the State Council earlier by the Chief Executive on the right of abode (ROA) issue," the Secretary for Security told reporters in Beijing after the meeting.

"The State Council is considering the report.

If our request for interpretation of Basic Law articles relevant to the ROA issue by the NPCSC is accepted, the report will be put to the NPCSC," she said.

Among the Mainland officials present at the meeting this afternoon were HKMAO Director Liao Hui and Vice Chairman of the NPCSC Legislative Affairs Commission Qiao Xiaoyang.

Immediately after the meeting, the Secretary for Justice departed for the airport.

She will be back in Hong Kong late this evening.

Mrs Ip, meanwhile, will stay in Beijing for another day to follow up the question of helping Hong Kong people detained in the Mainland.
19980219_008.e:
FS to visit Beijing 

At the invitation of Mr Liao Hui, Director of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council, the Financial Secretary, Mr Donald Tsang, will visit Beijing on February 23 and 24.

This is the Financial Secretary's first visit to Beijing after the Handover.

During his visit to Beijing, the Financial Secretary will make courtesy calls to the Vice-Premier and Minister of Foreign Affiars, Mr Qian Qichen and Director Liao.

The Financial Secretary will also meet with the Minister of Finance, Mr Liu Zhongli; the Governor of People's Bank of China, Mr Dai Xianglong; and Chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission, Mr Zhou Zhengqing.

The Financial Secretary will discuss with the officials the latest developments in the Asian financial markets and the impact of the financial turmoil on the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR).

He will also take the opportunity to brief them on the first Budget of the HKSAR.

Details of his visit programme are still being worked out.

Mr Tsang will be accompanied by his Administrative Assistant Mr Thomas Chow, Press Secretary Ms Kitty Choi and Assistant Secretary for Constitutional Affairs Miss Rosanna Law.
19980106_003.e:
Second day of CS's Beijing visit 

The Chief Secretary for Administration, Mrs Anson Chan, today (Tuesday) met with Vice-Premier Qian Qichen at Diaoyutai State Guesthouse.

The Director of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office, Mr Liao Hui, also attended the meeting.

Mr Qian welcomed the visits of senior officials of the SAR government to Beijing.

He said this would effectively enhance the communication between the central government and the SAR.

Vice-Premier and Mrs Chan also discussed the operation of the SAR government and the civil service since the handover.

Vice-Premier said the civil service had achieved a stabilising effect in the transition period, and praised the SAR officials in handling the financial turmoil properly.

After the meeting, Vice-Premier and Mrs Qian hosted a dinner at Diaoyutai State Guesthouse for Mrs Chan.

Before meeting with Mr Qian, Mrs Chan had an 80- minute talk with the Director of Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council, Mr Liao Hui.

They exchanged views on the development of the SAR since its establishment six months ago.

In the meeting, Mr Liao reiterated that under the "one country, two systems" principle, the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office definitely would not interfere with the affairs of the SAR.

On the establishment of the HKSAR office in Beijing, Mrs Chan said: "I expressed to the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office our wish to set up the HKSAR office in Beijing as early as possible.

Director Liao said that, according to the Basic Law, the establishment of the HKSAR office and its scope of work would be decided by HKSAR Government.

The Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office would offer practical assistance when necessary."

"In order to set up the HKSAR office as soon as possible, we are going to rent premises before a permanent location is sought."

"The Constitutional Affairs Bureau is actively formulating a proposal on the scope of work and staffing of the office."

Earlier today, Mrs Chan paid a courtesy call on National People's Congress Standing Committee Secretary- General, Mr Cao Zhi, at the reception hall of the Great Hall of the People.

At the meeting, Mr Cao Zhi briefed Mrs Chan on the functions of the National People's Congress (NPC) as the highest organ of power in China.

Mr Cao Zhi said there were five years before the Hong Kong representatives to the NPC would be elected.

During this period, the advice of the public will be seriously considered, with a view to making the arrangements of the next election more satisfactory.

In the afternoon, Mrs Chan met the Deputy Director of Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council, Mr Wang Fengchao, at his office.

Director-General of Department of Social and Cultural Affairs of the HKMAO, Mr Zhao Bingxin; Director-General of Department of Economic Affairs, Mr Zhang Liangdong, and Director-General of Department of Political Affairs, Mr Xu Ze, also attended.

Mrs Chan and Deputy Director Wang Fengchao discussed subjects of mutual concern to Hong Kong and the Mainland including avian flu and mainland-born children with right of abode in Hong Kong.

Deputy Director Wang expressed his concern on the development of avian flu.

Mrs Chan briefed HKMAO officials on the latest situation in Hong Kong and thanked the Guangdong authorities for their cooperation on assisting the SARG in improving the control system for chickens imported from the Mainland.

In addition, Mrs Chan and Mr Wang also exchanged views on the operation of "Certificate of Entitlement Scheme" for the past six months.

They both considered that the scheme operated well and agreed that the Hong Kong people's children who were eligible to right of abode should come to Hong Kong as soon as possible.
