19991213_011.e:
Chinese Dinosaurs are Coming to Town

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

You better watch out.

Fourteen Chinese prehistoric giants are coming to town!

A large-scale exhibition entitled "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" featuring magnificent dinosaur skeletons will be staged at the Special Exhibition Gallery of the Hong Kong Science Museum from tomorrow (Tuesday) to June 11, 2000.

Speaking at the opening ceremony this afternoon, the Chairman of the Provisional Urban Council's Museums Select Committee, Mr Mok Ying-fan, said that the Council had always concentrated its effort in popularising science and its related activities.

"We presented the 'Dinosaur Alive' and 'Prehistoric Giants' exhibitions in 1993 and 1996 respectively.

These two exhibitions on robotic dinosaurs had been very well received.

This year, 14 genuine dinosaur fossils from China will be displayed," Mr Mok said.

Mr Mok said these exhibits were selected from the fine collections of Beijing Natural History Museum, Chongqing Natural History Museum and Zigong Dinosaur Museum.

They included the Mamenchisaurus, the one with the longest neck in the dinosaurs' family; the Huayangosaurus, known as the very primitive stegosaurus; and the Tuojiangosaurus, the dinosaur which had the largest number of bony plates.

"A precious collection of fossil specimens uncovered in China will also be featured, ranging from the ancient animal and plant fossils, fossils of dinosaur bones, skull, teeth, eggs to the footprints of dinosaurs," he noted.

"In terms of scale, this is the largest exhibition of dinosaur fossils ever held in China.

Even if we make a trip to the Mainland museums, we would not be able to see so many fossil specimens at one time," he added.

Also officiating at the opening ceremony were the President of Guangdong Southern Natural Museum, Mr Zhang Jingyuan; the Secretary of Zi Gong Municipal Committee, Mr Wang Dongzhou; the Assistant Director, Head of Publicity And Cultural And Sports Department of the Xinhua News Agency (Hong Kong Branch), Mr Sun Nan Sheng; the Deputy Secretary-General of Chinese Association of National Science Museums, Professor Zhen Shuonan, and the Deputy Director of Urban Services (Culture), Ms Choi Suk-kuen.

Surrounded by the prehistoric forest settings, visitors will have the opportunity to explore the dinosaurs' lives in their habitat.

They can also play the role as a fossil detective to identify the differences between carnivorous and herbivorous dinosaurs in the "Fossil Detective" game.

In addition, they can challenge themselves on the knowledge of dinosaurs in the "Dinosaur Quiz" computer game.

To supplement the exhibition, various extension activities such as popular science lectures, fun science experiments, Chinese dinosaurs paper cutting demonstration and film shows will be held in the Museum during the exhibition period.

This large-scale exhibition is presented by the Provisional Urban Council in association with the Chinese Association of Natural Science Museums and the Guangdong Southern Natural Museum.

It is one of the major events of the two Municipal Councils to celebrate the new millennium and also a Spotlight Hong Kong Event supported by the Hong Kong Tourist Association.

The Hong Kong Science Museum is located at 2 Science Museum Road, Tsim Sha Tsui East.

Admission fee for the exhibition is $30 (for both permanent exhibitions and "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" exhibition), and $10 (for "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" exhibition only), with half-price concessions for senior citizens, people with disabilities and full-time students.

Admission for permanent exhibitions is free on Wednesdays but this does not apply to "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" exhibition.

The Museum will open from 1 pm to 9 pm daily except on Mondays and the first two days of Lunar New Year when the Museum is closed, and from 10 am to 9 pm on Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays.

The Museum will be closed at 5 pm on Christmas Eve (December 24) and Lunar New Year's Eve (February 4).

The website of the Science Museum is at www.usd.gov.hk/hkscm/.

For enquiries, please call 2732 3232.
19990427_002.e:
Masterpieces from France shown at HK Museum of Art

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

A large scale exhibition entitled "Masterpieces - The Origins of Modern Art in France 1880-1939" will be open to the public at the Hong Kong Museum of Art from tomorrow (Wednesday) until June 23, 1999.

A rare display of the original works by top masters and a panorama of the evolution of art concepts and art forms from the late 19th century to the early 20th century, the exhibition features 75 masterpieces of French paintings and sculptures.

Speaking at today's (Tuesday) opening ceremony, Chairman of the Provisional Urban Council Dr Ronald Leung Ding-bong said this event was the first exhibition of such scale to be held in Hong Kong.

"The exhibition features magnificent works by renowned artists including Monet, Cezanne, Gauguin, Rodin, Matisse, Picasso, Kandinsky and others whom you may have read in art history books but have not seen their actual works in Hong Kong, "Dr Leung said.

"They represent art movements like Impressionism, Post-Impressionism, Fauvism, Cubism, Surrealism, and Abstract Art," he noted.

"To complement such an important exhibition, an invitation show - 'Homage to the Masters' will be held.

About 30 Hong Kong artists working on different media will participate in this show," he said.

The staging of the exhibition in Hong Kong near the end of the present century is of special significance.

Besides viewing the original works by French masters, local audience will be able to appreciate a comprehensive survey on the origins of western art of the century and trace their influence on the development of modern art all over the world.

The masterpieces are on loan from the prestigious collections of over 20 museums and private collections including Musee de Grenoble, Musee d'Orsay and Musee National d'Art Moderne Centre Georges Pompidou.

The exhibition is a major event of "Le French May" and also a "Spotlight Hong Kong" event supported by the Hong Kong Tourist Association.

It is jointly presented by the Provisional Urban Council, the Consulate General of France, Hong Kong and Alliance Francaise, and supported by Associated Francaise d'Action Artisique, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, France.

This exhibition is guest curated by the Chief Curator of Musee de Grenoble, Mr Serge Lemoine.

Officiating at today's ceremony were the Consul General of France, Hong Kong, Mr Jerome Pasquier; the Vice-President of the Commission of Finances of the National Assembly, France, Mr Yves Tavernier; and Director of Urban Services, Miss Elaine Chung Lai-kwok.

In conjunction with the exhibition, the Museum provides a variety of educational and extension activities for teachers and students.

A fully illustrated catalogue which provides detailed information on the exhibition has been produced and will be on sale at the gift shop of the Museum.

Members of the public are welcome to visit the Museum's website at http://www.usd.gov.hk/hkma/ to browse the highlights of the exhibits.

20000127_015.e:
Baroque Italian Paintings on Show at Museum of Art

An exhibition of the beautiful fruits of human imagination and artistry - "Classical Italian Painting - Guercino and His School" was opened this (Thursday) afternoon.

Thirty-one masterpieces by Italian Baroque painters of 17th century are on display in the Orient for the very first time.

The exhibition will be opened to the public at the Hong Kong Museum of Art from tomorrow (January 28) to March 5, 2000.

The officiating guests of the opening ceremony were Secretary for Home Affairs, Mr David Lan and Consul General of Italy, Mr Pietro Giovanni Donnici.

Speaking at the ceremony, Mr Lan noted that it was very kind of the National Gallery of Art in Rome to bring gems of its prestigious collection to Hong Kong in celebration of the Millennium.

"The Hong Kong Museum of Art, now under the newly established Leisure and Cultural Services Department, has established an international reputation of fostering cultural exchanges," Mr Lan said.

"Though the Museum's collection is predominantly Chinese, it regularly cooperates with various consulates and cultural institutions to bring in major international art exhibitions for the people of Hong Kong,"

"This year, in addition to the Classical Italian Painting Exhibition, the Museum will present exhibitions on contemporary French art from Nice, Japanese art from the Tokyo National Museum, new Chinese art from the United States and Buddhist sculptures from the Mainland.

This programme of international exhibitions will contribute to the continued development of Hong Kong as the cultural hub of Asia," Mr Lan added.

In the full glory of Renaissance, western art in the 15th and 16th centuries was evoked by humanism, when people were enlightened with a new vision to religion and the universe.

Evolved from the late Renaissance movement, the art of Baroque reached its peak in the 17th century.

This style of art is characterized with dynamics, movement and fervour expressed in chiaroscuro and intensified dramatic lighting.

Originating in Italy, the art of Baroque also flourished in many European countries and stayed in the spotlight for over a century.

The artistic style of Baroque was also reflected in sculpture, architecture, music and literature.

Baroque master Guercino, Giovan Francesco Barbieri, (1591 - 1666) was a major successor of Carracci Academism of the Baroque period and a renowned painter in Bologna, Italy.

His works inherited Raphael's fine equilibrium and harmony as well as Carravagio's chiaroscuro and naturalistic expression, with a direct reference to the main stream of Baroque art in Rome and Venice.

In addition to Guercino's works, the exhibition also features representative works by artists of the Bologna School including Carracci Brothers, Reni, Lanfranco and Domenichino in order to fully illustrate the artistic achievements of the Bologna School in the early 17th century Baroque movement.

Distinguished works such as "Saul Versus David" by Guercino; "Flora with Putti" by Francesco Albani and "The Burning of Troy" by Alessandro Tiarini will also be shown.

The 31 masterpieces are selected from the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, Palazzo Barberini and institutes in Italy.

Jointly presented by the Leisure and Cultural Services Department and the Consolato Generale d'Italia Hong Kong, the exhibition is organised by the Hong Kong Museum of Art and the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, Palazzo Barberini.

Also officiating at the ceremony were Director of Leisure and Cultural Services, Mr Paul Leung Sai-wah; President of the Italian Cultural Society of Hong Kong 'Dante Alighieri', Dr Leo Lee; Storico dell'arte Direttore, Galleria Nazional d'Arte Antica, Palazzo Barberini, Dr Rossella Vodret and Chief Curator, Hong Kong Museum of Art, Mr Gerard Tsang.

To coincide with the exhibition, a children painting corner and a reading corner are specially set up in the gallery.

A gallery talk will be held tomorrow (Friday) afternoon from 5.30 pm to 7 pm at the Special Gallery of the Museum with Dr Rossella Vodret as the speaker.

Enquiries for the talk can be made on 2734 2156.

The Museum of Art is located at 10 Salisbury Road, Tsim Sha Tsui.

Admission fee for this exhibition is $10, with half-price concessions for senior citizens, people with disabilities and full-time students.

A total of 31 masterpieces by famous Italian Baroque painters of the 17th Century will be featured.

The Museum of Art is located at 10 Salisbury Road, Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon.

For enquiries, please call 2721 0116.

19990211_009.e:
Drug Treatment Centres Registration Scheme will be Introduced

The Acting Commissioner for Narcotics, Ms Mimi Lee, told the LegCo Panel on Security today (Thursday) that the Government intends to introduce a scheme to make it a statutory requirement for a person to apply to the Director of Social Welfare for registration, if he intends to operate an establishment providing voluntary residential care, treatment and rehabilitation services for four or more drug abusers.

The main purpose of the scheme is to improve the standard of drug treatment and rehabilitation services and to ensure that patients will receive such services in a properly managed and secure physical environment.

The scheme will also impose uniform control on drug treatment and rehabilitation centres, thus removing the apparent policy inconsistency that centres currently providing voluntary residential medical detoxification and rehabilitation services are subject to statutory control, while centres providing similar services except medical detoxification are not subject to any control.

To register, a centre must comply with the requirements of building services and fire safety as stipulated by the Buildings and Fire Services Departments respectively.

The applicant must also fulfil the "fit" person criteria, which will stipulate that in the ten years prior to registration, the applicant must not have undergone any drug treatment programme and committed any serious offence, including drug offences, such as manufacturing, trafficking and possession.

Ms Lee said that the registration scheme "will not seek to impose too much control on the services currently provided by drug treatment and rehabilitation centres.

The licensing authority will ensure that the centres will continue to enjoy the autonomy of staff employment within the limits of current guidelines applicable to them."

The scheme will affect 13 existing agencies which operate 40 treatment and rehabilitation centres, including half-way houses providing residential care services to drug abusers.

"The registration scheme will be implemented in two phases.

Phase I will only affect the drug treatment and rehabilitation centres currently subvented by the Government.

They will be given a grace of period of four years to prepare for registration.

"Phase II will affect the centres which are not subvented by the Government", said Ms Lee.

"The Narcotics Division has been liaising with various charitable funds to alert them of the possible demand from these centres for funding the upgrading works in order to meet the registration requirements", she added.

The proposal of the registration scheme was put to public consultation from May to October 1998.

All views collected were in support of the proposal.

The Government will proceed with the drafting of the enabling legislation for the registration scheme in the remainder of 1999, with a view to introducing the Bill to the Legislative Council in its next session.

Subject to the passage of the enabling legislation which will replace the existing Drug Addicts Treatment and Rehabilitation Ordinance (Cap 326), it is expected that the scheme will come into operation in the latter half of 2000.
20000408_011.e:
Beat Drugs Fund Grants $16 million in Support of 29 Anti-Drug Projects

The Governing Committee of the Beat Drugs Fund, chaired by the Secretary for Security, has approved grants of $16.39 million for 29 anti-drug projects this year.

The Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, who is also a member of the Governing Committee, said, "The number of drug abusers aged below 21 dropped by 13.6 per cent from 2829 in 1998 to 2 443 in 1999.

Despite the continuing drop in recent years, we recognise that youths-at-risk are a highly vulnerable group and deserve the full attention of all those working in the anti-drug field."

"To prevent our younger generation from abusing drugs, education and publicity is an on-going campaign; and any relaxation in efforts might have adverse consequences," Mrs Lo added.

In considering this year's applications for the Fund, the Governing Committee attached importance to those aiming to steer youths-at-risk away from drugs.

Amongst the 29 projects approved this year, 22 are related to drug prevention education and publicity ($10.72 million), five to treatment and rehabilitation ($2.98 million)and two to research ($2.69 million).

An amount of $2.08 million was granted to conduct a pioneering longitudinal research on the development and validation of a drug prevention programme in Hong Kong.

Youths-at-risk aged between 10 to 15 in selected areas including Tuen Mun and Kwun Tong will be invited to take part in the project.

Participants will be taught on the adverse effect of drug abuse, social and personal skills to help them identify and resist peer influence to use drugs.

Parents, teachers and community leaders will be involved in helping the participants.

Evaluation will be made at the end of the project to trace the change in attitude towards drugs among these youths.

"This is the first research project to be funded by the Beat Drugs Fund.

The study will be useful in developing a package of drug preventive programmes for anti-drug workers in Hong Kong," Mrs Lo said.

Another project targeting at youths-at-risk is a "Mentoring Program" which involves parents, teachers and volunteers in steering young drug abusers away from drugs.

Amongst the treatment and rehabilitation related projects, $1 million was granted to a project called "Art Therapy Treatment Programme" run by an anti-drug worker in the medical field.

The project aims to promote a new treatment method for drug addiction.

Under this project, more services for drug addicts and their family members and training for anti-drug workers and volunteers will be provided.

All the projects have been considered by the Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) and its Sub-committees on Preventive Education and Publicity, Treatment and Rehabilitation, and Research in consultation with the relevant government departments before they were recommended to the Governing Committee for decision.

Since its establishment in 1996, the Beat Drugs Fund has sponsored a total of 145 projects with $56.72 million in grants.

The number of projects will increase to 174 and fund disbursed to $73.11 million, following this year's allocation.
19990802_006.e:
Anti-drug work poses challenge

One of the major challenges facing the world is trafficking in illicit drugs and related organised crimes, said the Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, at a major conference on drug dependence today (Monday).

Speaking at the opening of "1999 Hong Kong and Mainland Conference on Drug Dependence" at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, Mrs Lo added: "New technology not only has shortened distance, but also greatly increased production of synthetic drugs and enabled them to be transported from one place to another.

Drug syndicates have become increasingly internationalized and their operations increasingly complicated.

As a result, the challenges facing governments over the world are getting bigger and bigger."

Briefly introducing the present drug abuse situation in Hong Kong, Mrs Lo said the number of reported drug abusers had been on the decrease since 1995.

There were about 16 000 reported drug abusers in 1998, and 5 527 in the first quarter of 1999, representing a drop of 11 per cent compared with the same period in 1998.

Hong Kong adopted a multi-proned approach in combating the problems of drug trafficking and drug abuse through law enforcement, international co-operation, treatment and rehabilitation, preventive education and publicity, as well as research, Mrs Lo continued.

In law enforcement, Hong Kong had enacted sound legislation to control the supply, manufacture and storage of dangerous drugs and psychotropic substances, and to prevent chemicals from being used for manufacturing dangerous drugs.

The Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) Ordinance enabled the Government to trace, freeze and confiscate drug traffickers' drug proceeds, and spelt out various measures to combat money laundering activities.

The Organised and Serious Crimes Ordinance was being amended to require money changers and remittance agents to take anti-money laundering measures.

Mrs Lo pointed out that Hong Kong adopted a multi-modality approach for treatment and rehabilitation to meet the needs of drug abusers with different backgrounds.

"This year, we'll propose legislation to require treatment and rehabilitation centres providing voluntary residential services to register in order to raise the standard of their services.

We are currently reviewing the success of the methadone treatment programme.

In the review, we'll explore the feasibility of supplementing or replacing methadone with other drugs," she added.

Looking ahead, Mrs Lo said that posing a challenge to anti-drug work would be the crisis to be brought about by mass production of synthetic drugs, youngsters abusing psychotropic substances at places of public entertainment and other places,as well as the problems of female drug abusers.

Officiating at the opening of the conference, the Hon Dr Rosanna Wong, Member of the Executive Council, said that strengthening liaison and exchanges in anti-drug work between Hong Kong and the Mainland was essential to the long term co-operation in tackling drug problems.

"I believe that anti-drug work and latest developments in the Mainland and Hong Kong can be explored in depth at this conference, and can benefit from your experience for further improvement to existing services and measures," she told the participants.

Over 200 anti-drug policy administrators, law enforcers, academics and professionals all over China attended the five-day conference, which is the first of its nature and scale held in Hong Kong after the Handover.

Participants from China include Mr Yin Dakui, Vice-Minister, Ministry of Health; Mr Shao Mingli, Deputy Secretary General, State Drug Administration; and Mr Wang Kang, Deputy Secretary General, National Narcotics Control Commission.

Organised by the Department of Psychiatry of the Chinese University of Hong Kong, the conference features the main theme of "Challenges and Opportunities: Multi-Modality Approach in Substance Abuse".

The conference was financed with grants from the Beat Drugs Fund.

Since its establishment in 1996, the fund has financed 145 anti-drug projects with grants of $55.16 million.
19990425_009.e:
Youths-at-Risk of Substance Abuse and Families of Abusers Given Priority in This Year's Beat Drugs Fund Projects

The Governing Committee of the Beat Drugs Fund, chaired by the Secretary for Security, has approved grants of $6.93 million for 17 anti-drug projects targeting at youths-at-risk and $9.2 million for 11 projects supporting families of drug abusers and families in general, amongst a total of $17.78 million to be granted to 48 projects this year.

In considering this year's applications for the Fund, the Governing Committee attached importance to those aiming to steer youths-at-risk away from drugs.

"We note that the number of drug abusers aged below 21 has been on the decrease in recent years - it dropped by nearly 11 per cent from 3 149 in 1997 to 2 805 in 1998.

Despite this, we recognise that youths-at-risk are a highly vulnerable group and deserve the full attention by all those working in the anti-drug field.

"To prevent our younger generation from abusing drugs, education and publicity is an on-going campaign; and any relaxation in efforts might have adverse consequences," said the Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, who is also a member of the Governing Committee.

Notable amongst the approved projects for youths-at-risk are the $2.5 million proposal to be organised by the Hong Kong Federation of Youth Groups featuring preventive education and guidance for 2 500 high-risk youths from primary and secondary schools, as well as from youth centres in Tsuen Wan and Kwai Tsing districts; and the $2.3 million project by the Hong Kong Christian Service targeting at 3 000 youths-at-risk, including school drop-outs and unemployed young people, with a view to minimising their exposure to social and moral danger which could lead to substance abuse.

Besides youths-at-risk, the Governing Committee recognises that families are also an important target for anti-drug education.

Notable projects supported are the $950,000 programme by the Hong Kong Lutheran Social Services to provide a variety of activities for parents and their children, and the $820,000 programme by Wu Oi Christian Centre for drug abusers and their family members.

Amongst the 48 projects approved this year, 39 are related to drug preventive education and publicity ($12.88 million) and nine to treatment and rehabilitation ($4.9 million).

Amongst the grants for treatment and rehabilitation projects, the biggest one - $1.26 million - went to the Christian New Being Fellowship's project for adolescent drug abusers.

The project aims to lead these abusers to ultimate rehabilitation through participation in high-technology, innovative and productive work so as to develop their work role and work aspiration, which are prerequisites to successful vocational pursuit and re-integration into society.

All the projects have been considered by the Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) and its Sub-committees on Preventive Education and Publicity, Treatment and Rehabilitation, and Research in consultation with the relevant government departments before they were recommended to the Governing Committee for decision.

Meanwhile, members of ACAN and the Sub-committees continue to monitor the progress of the projects financed by the Beat Drugs Fund, and visited two such projects last week.

The members first visited a half-way house operated by Operation Dawn in Prince Edward Road, and saw how it was given a new look following renovation financed by the Beat Drugs Fund.

The party then proceeded to a hostel of the Society for the Rehabilitation of Offenders for a briefing on counselling service for ex-drug abusers.

The Society has employed a peer counsellor to provide the service with grant from the Fund.

Since its establishment in 1996, the Beat Drugs Fund has sponsored a total of 98 projects with $38.53 million in grants.

The number of projects will increase to 146 and fund disbursed to $56.31 million, following this year's allocation.

19980306_007.e:
Number of reported drug abusers dropped in 1997 

The number of drug abusers reported to the Central Registry of Drug Abuse (CRDA) in 1997 totalled 17,555, a drop of 10.8 per cent over the 19,671 reported in 1996, according to CRDA statistics presented to the Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) today (Friday).

Speaking at ACAN's quarterly meeting, the Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, said that young drug abusers reported in 1997 had also dropped by 14.3 per cent compared with 1996.

"A total of 3,135 drug abusers aged below 21 were reported in 1997 as compared with 3,656 in 1996."

Mrs Lo pointed out that CRDA statistics showed that the overall number of reported drug abusers dropped in 1997.

"In 1994, we had 20,327 reported drug abusers of all ages, and 4,289 drug abusers aged below 21.

The figures dropped to 17,555 and 3,135 respectively in 1997," she said.

She went on to say that more encouraging was the fact that the number of reported drug abusers aged below 21 had also decreased since 1994.

"In 1994, there were 4,289 reported young drug abusers, but the figure dropped to 3,988 in 1995, 3,656 in 1996 and 3,135 in 1997."

However, CRDA statistics showed that the reported number of psychotropic substances abusers appeared to be on the rise, she added.

"There were 3,451 reported psychotropic substance abusers of all ages in 1997, compared with 3,388 in 1996 and 2,618 in 1995.

As regards psychotropic substance abusers aged below 21, 1,269 abusers were reported in 1997, compared with 1,357 in 1996."

Mrs Lo pointed out that there was a small decrease in the number of female drug abusers in 1997 when 2,216 abusers were reported, compared with 2,429 in 1996.

ACAN noted that the downward drug abuse trend in 1997 was consistent with the downward movement of drug-related factors such as reported crimes, persons receiving treatment and admissions to drug treatment agencies.

Notwithstanding this observation, a thorough study on factors affecting the drug abuse trend in Hong Kong was recently commissioned by ACAN with a view to identifying the underlying factors that affect the size, complexity and characteristics of the drug abuse population in Hong Kong.

The study will be completed by 2000.

On preventive education, Mrs Lo said that more resources would be devoted to stepping up the beat drugs campaign despite the drop in the number of drug abusers figures.

She said that ACAN's Preventive Education and Publicity Sub-committee had adopted the following themes for education and publicity programmes for 1998/99:

(i) to heighten awareness of the undesirable consequences of abusing drugs, no matter 'hard' or 'soft';";

(ii) to educate the public, in particular young people, that drug abuse is not the solution to any problem, and to equip them with life skills; and

(iii) to emphasise the positive effects of staying drug-free.

"The budget for the 1998/99 preventive education and publicity programmes amounted to about $5.1 million," Mrs Lo said.

Within that budget, $1.3 million will be used for updating videos for anti-drug education talks for secondary and primary 6 students, and producing a new video for a new talk for primary 5 students.

A sum of about $1 million had been budgeted for producing publicity programmes through the electronic media; printing publicity posters and leaflets; and placing advertisement on television, radio, buses and MTR stations.

In addition, $2.86 million have been earmarked for organising various preventive education programmes and subsiding District Fight Crime Committees, District School Liaison Committees and community organisations in carrying out anti-drugs publicity activities.

ACAN was also informed by a Social Welfare Department's representative at the meeting that the Subventions and Lotteries Fund Advisory Committee had supported the Government to grant $16.12 million to subvent the services provided by four non-medical voluntary drug treatment and rehabilitation agencies for the 1998/99 financial year.

The four agencies are the Barnabas Charitable Service Association, the Christian New Being Fellowship, the Finnish Missionary Service Ling Oi Youth Centre and the Operation Dawn, all of which will also be granted a total subvention of $1.26 million to cover their expenses for the month of March in the 1997/98 financial year.

The decision on subventions followed a government evaluation study of the services provided by non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation agencies with a view to including them in the subvention system.
19980430_016.e:
Registration of non-medical detoxification centres proposed

The Government will tomorrow (Friday) launch a public consultation exercise on a proposed registration scheme for non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres.

The consultation will last until 30 June 1998.

The Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, explained that existing drug treatment and rehabilitation centres which provide medical detoxification are registered as nursing homes by the Department of Health under the Hospitals, Nursing Homes and Maternity Homes Ordinance (Cap.165).

The regulatory controls imposed on these medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres as nursing homes include, among others, the accommodation, staffing and equipment used or to be used in such centres which should be fit for the purposes intended.

However, centres which adopt a non-medical approach in the treatment and rehabilitation of drug abusers are not subject to any registration control.

"There are about 11 non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres in Hong Kong.

It is observed that most of them are accommodated in stone or wooden huts in remote areas.

Some of them are also not fitted with proper electricity and water supplies.

Thus, they would be subject to building, fire safety or environmental health risks should accidents happen," Mrs Lo said.

"The management and operation of such centres also vary," she added.

Taking into account these observations, the Government proposes and the Action Committee Against Narcotics supports that a registration scheme should be introduced for non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres, in order to:

* ensure drug patients undergo treatment and rehabilitation in a properly managed and secure environment to safeguard their well-being;

* protect the rights and welfare of drug patients who, like other drug patients in medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres, are subject to psychological stress and physical health problems when undergoing treatment and rehabilitation.

The staff and treatment approaches adopted by these centres should, therefore, be competent/relevant in providing services to them; and

* enable the Government to keep a register of the non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres and to impose requirements and standards for their operations as necessary.

To ensure broadly the same registration standards to be applied to all drug treatment and rehabilitation centres, Mrs Lo said the proposed registration requirements to be introduced for non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres would be similar to those provisions of Cap.165 which currently apply to medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres.

The major registration requirements will include the following:

* a person in charge of a drug treatment and rehabilitation centre will need to apply to an authority for registration if the centre provides residential care, treatment and rehabilitation service for drug abusers;

* registration of an applicant is subject to the conditions that the drug treatment and rehabilitation centre under application complies with fire safety and building safety requirements as prescribed by the Director of Fire Services and the Director of Buildings respectively (the preliminary requirements have been set out in the consultation document); and

* the applicant is fit for operating a drug treatment and rehabilitation centre.

(A definition of 'fitness' has been included in the consultation document).

Failure to comply with the registration requirements or operating a drug treatment and rehabilitation centre without a registration certificate will be liable to a fine of $1,000 and/or imprisonment for three months.

The registration scheme for non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres will be implemented in phases.

"We consider it not practical to require all of them to be registered at once since most of them will need substantial physical upgrading to meet the proposed registration requirements.

In this respect, they are, no matter subvented or non-subvented, welcomed to apply to the Lotteries Fund for upgrading their facilities or accommodation to meet the necessary requirements," Mrs Lo said.

The first phase of the registration scheme will cover those non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres which receive subvention from the Social Welfare Department.

Other non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres will be covered in a subsequent phase as some of them might wish to seek other sources of funding.

As regards the registration procedures, Mrs Lo said all operators of non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres would be required to notify the registration authority of their operation within three months after commencement of the enabling legislation.

They will be granted exemption certificates which will provisionally exempt them from registration until such certificates are revoked.

For these non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres covered in the first phase, their exemption certificates will be revoked 48 months after the end of the notification period.

During this grace period, they are encouraged to obtain a registration certificate from the registration authority as soon as they are ready.

If they fail to obtain a registration certificate by the end of the grace period, they will have to cease operation.

As regards those non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres set up upon or after the commencement of the enabling legislation, the operator will need to apply for registration before starting to provide such services.

Non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres not covered in the first phase will also be granted exemption certificates.

The timing of implementation of the registration scheme for them will be decided in the light of experience gained as these centres have their unique circumstances.

"The registration authority for non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres will be the Social Welfare Department.

A new piece of legislation will be proposed to empower the Department, as the registration authority, to register an applicant in respect of non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres and to enforce the requirements of the registration scheme," Mrs Lo said.

Any views on the registration scheme will be carefully considered by the Government before putting forward the legislation on the proposed registration scheme.

Comments may be sent in writing to the Narcotics Division, 23rd floor, High Block, Queensway Government Offices, 66 Queensway, before June 30, 1998.

Copies of the public consultation paper on the proposed registration scheme are available at the Narcotics Division and the District Offices.

The consultation paper can also be viewed on the Narcotics Division's Homepage at www.info.gov.hk/nd/.
19990927_011.e:
New Initiatives Despite Fall in Number of Reported Drug Abusers

There is a continuing downward trend in the reported numbers of drug abuse cases and young drug abusers in Hong Kong in the first half of 1999.

Speaking at the meeting of the Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) today (Monday), the Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, said, "we are pleased to note that the downward drug abuse trend since 1995 persisted in the first half of 1999".

In this period, a total of 9,928 drug abusers were reported to the Central Registry of Drug Abuse (CRDA), representing a drop of 7.1% from 10,683 persons in the same period last year.

Of the 9,928 drug abusers reported in first half of the year, 1,445 or 14.6% were aged under 21.

This represents a decrease of 17% over the 1,740 young drug abusers in the first half of 1998.

There were also 1,203 female drug abusers reported to the CRDA, representing a drop of 5.7% compared with the corresponding figure in 1998.

The number of newly reported drug abusers in the second quarter this year also fell 11.2% from 856 in the same period last year to 760.

However, reported abusers on ice increased 5% in the first half of 1999 from 504 in the same period last year to 513 while those on Triazolam rose from 368 in the first half of l998 to 405 in the first six months this year, representing a 10.1 percentage point increase.

Mrs Lo attributed the general downward drug abuse trend to the joint efforts by the Government and non-government organisations involved in the anti-drug field, while not losing sight of the increase in the abuse of some kinds of drugs.

"The Government has adopted a five-pronged strategy in combating drug trafficking and abuse, which covers law enforcement, preventive education and publicity, treatment and rehabilitation, research and international co-operation," Mrs Lo said.

Mrs Lo said that the Government will further strengthen its efforts in fighting the drug problems with even greater involvement of the community despite the general falling trend in the number of reported abusers.

With this in mind, ACAN suggested a number of new initiatives.

Amongst them is the establishment of a drug information and exhibition centre to centralise information on drugs and support community involvement programmes in the drug field.

Mrs Lo said that the roof garden at the Queensway Government Offices Low Block would be converted into the exhibition hall of the centre.

Graphic displays, replicas of drugs and interactive exhibits will be featured.

There will also be thematic displays which are changed periodically, displays on topical issues relating to drug abuse and forthcoming anti-drug programmes.

ACAN also recommended other measures to enhance partnership with the community on anti-drug work.

The Youth Volunteer Group of ACAN will be revamped to attract more volunteers from different sectors of society, and work of the group will be more diversified.

On drug treatment and rehabilitation, the roadmap for the next three years is being drawn up in consultation with the agencies in the drug field.

The plan will examine the present provision of drug treatment and rehabilitation facilities and services in Hong Kong, and will guide future plans in this area.

The plan is also tied to the current review of Methadone Treatment Programme, the largest voluntary programme subscribed by opiate drug abusers so far.

The objectives, scope and effectiveness of the programme are now being vigorously reviewed.

Possible clinical trials of new drugs in detoxification and relapse prevention will be considered in the review.

Reflecting on the experience of the ACAN visit to Singapore in June this year, members considered that the objective of enhancing cross-fertilization of ideas and exchanges of information between Hong Kong and Singapore on anti-drug work had been well achieved.

ACAN is in fact applying references to Singapore's naltrexone trial, partnership programmes and volunteer programmes actively.
19990829_012.e:
Research on Treatment Strategies for Drug Abusers Commissioned

The Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) Research Sub-committee has decided to commission two major research on treatment and rehabilitation for drug abusers in Hong Kong in 1999.

The Research Sub-committee invites research proposals from tertiary institutions, non-government organizations and government departments on a yearly basis.

The objective of such research is to assist the Government and ACAN to study various aspects relating to drug abuse for the formulation of anti-drug policies and programmes.

The first research project endorsed by the Research Sub-committee in 1999 is an in-depth study on the chronic drug abusers, and methadone patients in particular.

The study was commissioned to The Chinese University of Hong Kong, and aims to find out the underlying causes for the chronic abuse of illicit drugs and the relapse into drug addiction after detoxification and rehabilitation.

Commenting on the research topic, a spokesman of the Narcotics Division said, "It is considered that there is a demonstrated need for such a project, as relapse into drug addiction following detoxification and rehabilitation has been an issue of great concern for policy-makers and workers in the anti-drug field."

"It is hoped that the findings of the study will help the Government and ACAN develop effective treatment strategies for chronic or frequently relapsed drug abusers, and look into what modifications should be made to the existing methadone programme.

"Among the reported cases in the Central Registry of Drug Abuse, over 75% of them are old cases and more than half of them are cases from methadone treatment programme.

"This coincide with the observation that relapse is an acute problem for those who have a long drug addiction history, in particular methadone patients," he added.

The research costs about $1 million and is expected to take three years to complete.

The second research project, commissioned to the Kwai Chung Hospital and The Chinese University of Hong Kong, is a study on the motivational strategy for engaging early drug abusers for treatment.

The study aims to assess the current methods of persuading drug abusers, especially early drug abusers, to seek treatment and to evaluate the effectiveness of motivational strategy.

"It is recognized in psychiatric field that, drug abuse cases which are identified early usually stand a better chance of recovering in full, while late ones normally have more severe or perhaps life-long psychiatric damage," the spokesman said.

"Therefore, it is considered that more efforts should be made to persuade early drug abusers to seek treatment.

"The findings of the study are expected to cast light on how to motivate more drug abusers to come forward for treatment," he added.

The project costs about $300,000 and will take one year to complete.

In 1998, the Research Sub-committee had commissioned 10 studies, among which two have been completed, and 8 are still in progress.

In the 1998/99 financial year, the Government devoted a total of $8.3 million to drug research-related work.
19990729_008.e:
ACAN Members Find Singapore Visit Fruitful

The Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) will consider the recommendations made by its members who paid a fact-finding visit to witness Singapore's anti-drug policies and strategies in action last month.

A delegation of 17 unofficial members of ACAN and its three sub-committees, accompanied by five officials from Department of Health, Social Welfare Department and Narcotics Division, spent four days in Singapore, studying how Singapore tackles its drug abuse problems through legislation, law enforcement, preventive education, treatment and rehabilitation, as well as aftercare services.

The delegation had exchanged with members of the National Council Against Drug Abuse (NCADA), Singapore's counterpart of ACAN and officials from the Ministry of Home Affairs, the Central Narcotics Bureau and the Prisons Department.

It had also visited various voluntary organisations in the drug field, and private companies which are taking part in a partnership programme with the Singapore Government on drug preventive education.

ACAN Chairman, Professor Lee Shiu-hung, who led the delegation, said members observed that the trip had been useful especially in strengthening international cooperation in the anti-drug area.

In preventive education and publicity, members were impressed by the Partnership Programme for a Drug-free Singapore.

They also reaffirmed the present direction taken by the Narcotics Division in actively involving the community in anti-drug work, and proposed that the Division should align the community more closely, e.g. by inviting advertising companies and the media to contribute to large-scale anti-drug campaigns.

Members considered that involving volunteers in spreading anti-drug message was one of the best ways to involve the community.

In this regard, Prof. Lee pointed out that the Action Committee Against Narcotics was revamping the Youth Volunteer Group, and would encourage people from different sectors to contribute to anti-drug work.

Noting Singapore's badge scheme to encourage students to spread anti-drug messages, members have recommended that the Narcotics Division should consider a similar scheme to pay recognition to students who made significant contribution to the anti-drug cause.

For treatment and rehabilitation, members recommended that cross referral between various modalities in Hong Kong should be strengthened.

Given the Singapore experience in using "naltrexone" in relapse prevention, members suggested that it might be worthwhile for Hong Kong to consider the possibility of launching clinical trial using naltrexone as well as other new drugs in the context of the methadone treatment programme review.

Referring to Singapore's aftercare programmes of helping drug addicts to find jobs, members have suggested introducing similar programmes in Hong Kong to strengthen vocational training for drug addicts.

They also recommended giving employers some incentives to employ ex-addicts to help the latter reintegrate in the society.

In conclusion, members suggested that, due to social and political differences between Singapore and Hong Kong, not all Singapore anti-drug policies and strategies can be directly transplanted to Hong Kong.

However, the visit was fruitful and stimulating, and was very beneficial for future planning of anti-narcotic policies in Hong Kong.

19990226_001.e:
Joint operation to flush out illegal immigrants

A territory-wide operation against illegal immigration jointly mounted by the Police, Immigration Department and Labour Department has resulted in the arrests of 50 people.

The operation is part of the Government's continuous effort to flush out illegal immigrants.

The 20 suspected illegal immigrants arrested by the Police have been referred to the Immigration Department.

Those found to be illegal immigrants will be repatriated.

A Government spokesman reiterated today (Friday) that there was no question of any amnesty for illegal immigrants.

"Our latest operation should drive home the point that there will be no change to this policy.

Anyone foolish enough to believe otherwise is only cheating oneself," he said.

The spokesman stressed that apart from continuous checks throughout the territory, there was no let-up in anti-illegal immigration efforts at the border.

"A high state of vigilance will continue to be maintained by the Police and the security forces both at the land and sea borders," he said.

During the 24-hour operation ended at 5 am today, the Police stepped up their identification spot checks in public places and carried out checks at suspicious locations throughout the territory.

As a result, a total of 20,106 persons were stopped for identification checks.

During the operation, Immigration investigators visited 24 residential premises, four business establishments and 10 construction sites.

Twenty men and 10 women were arrested for suspected breaching of immigration offences.

Among the arrestees, 18 two-way permit visitors, one Filipino and one Chinese were found breaching the condition of stay.

Five Hong Kong residents were arrested for aiding and abetting the breach of condition of stay while one was arrested for aiding and abetting false representation to an immigration officer.

One two-way permit holder was arrested for producing forged identity card.

One Chinese was arrested for false representation, and one was caught for illegal remaining.

One Hong Kong resident was arrested for employing a person who is not lawfully employable.

On the labour front, inspectors of the Labour Department visited 3,143 establishments to weed out any illegal immigrants who may be working there and to check that employers fulfil their legal obligation of keeping proper records of their employees.

A total of 7,234 employees had their proof of identity checked and four establishments were found unable to provide a record of employees for inspection.

The spokesman reminded employers that they could be fined up to $350,000 and jailed for up to three years if they were found to be employing illegal immigrants.

19980119_007.e:
Provisional voter registers being compiled 

The Registration and Electoral Office (REO) is working flat out to process the data collected from new applicants and previously registered electors now that the registration drive for the 1998 Legislative Council elections has been concluded.

The objective is to compile provisional registers of electors/voters and omissions lists before the middle of next month for the public to check their registration particulars, the Chairman of the Electoral Affairs Commission, Mr Justice Woo Kwok-hing, told the media today (Monday).

Members of the public will then have an opportunity to raise objections or lodge appeals regarding any entry or omission before February 21, he said.

Cases of objections and claims will be referred to the Revising Officer, who is a member of the Judiciary, for determination.

His decisions will be reflected in final registers to be published before March 15.

It is estimated from the total number of forms received that the total electorate of geographical constituencies has gone up from 2.53 million to 2.77 million.

This represents a registration rate of nearly 70 per cent.

"A significant proportion of the estimated 3.96 million eligible electors in Hong Kong will be able to vote in the May elections to choose Legislative Councillors of their choice," Mr Justice Woo said.

The exact figure will be known when the provisional register is published next month.

Out of the 580,000 voter registration forms for the geographical constituencies received, it is estimated that half of them are from new electors.

The remaining are reports of change of residential address.

"These updates will enable the REO to put together a much more accurate electoral roll," Mr Justice Woo said.

"Now that we have confirmed the whereabouts of about 290,000 previously registered electors who have moved, they will certainly be able to receive our notice to remind them to go to the polls on May 24," he added.

Releasing registration figures for functional constituencies and the corresponding Election Committee subsectors, Mr Justice Woo was encouraged to see a sevenfold increase in the number of applications as compared with the figure on December 30.

More than 25,100 applications for functional constituencies have been received from 12,700 individuals and 12,400 bodies.

In addition, on the basis of information available, 123,000 individual electors and 3,800 corporate electors have been informed by notifications that they are registered if they do not raise objections.

Put together, the functional constituency figures amount to more than half of the potential electors.

A majority of the registered corporate electors (more than 12,100) can cast their votes because they have appointed authorised representatives.

For the seven Election Committee subsectors without an equivalent functional constituency, 4,200 individuals and 140 bodies have been informed by notifications that they are registered if they do not raise objections.

More than 1,300 new applications have been received.

Altogether more than 480 authorised representatives have been appointed to vote.

Mr Justice Woo observed that some functional constituencies had seen especially good response towards the end of the exercise.

Examples are the Labour, Tourism, Finance, Agriculture and Fisheries, Transport and Insurance functional constituencies.

"Even response from eligible electors in five new functional constituencies - the Sports, Performing Arts, Culture and Publication; Import and Export; Textiles and Garment, Wholesale and Retail, and Information Technology - has improved significantly," he said.

Mr Justice Woo thanked all residents and organisations who had contributed to the smooth completion of the voter registration drive.

"The 30,000 students, teachers and co-workers who knocked on the doors of every family during the week from December 6 also deserve our thanks," he said.

"Not only have they helped people at their home sign up as electors, they have brought the message about the first Legislative Council elections in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region to every corner of the territory," he said.

An omissions list containing the names and residential addresses of electors who have died or are no longer eligible to be included in the register will also be made public.

A spokesman for the Registration and Electoral Office (REO) urged registered electors to check whether their registration particulars had been correctly recorded on the register.

They may call the hotline - 2891 1001 or enquire by fax - 2891 1180.

"Electors may raise objections or make claims regarding any discrepancies found on the register or the omissions list by submitting a notice to the REO in person by April 29.

"Cases of objections and claims will be referred to one of the six Revising Officers for hearing.

Their decision will be reflected in the final register to be published on May 25.

"Only electors whose names are listed on the final register are entitled to vote in the Legislative Council elections in September," the spokesman said.

He reminded registered electors who had moved to inform the REO of their new address by April 29 so that their records could be updated on the final register.

"Electors will be allocated to a polling station near their home address listed on the final register," he said.

Also published for public inspection will be two registers and two omissions lists - the provisional register of electors and omissions list for functional constituencies, and the provisional register of voters and omissions list for Election Committee subsectors.

The provisional register and omissions list for geographical constituencies will be available for public inspection at:

* the REO, 10th floor, Harbour Centre, 25 Harbour Road, Wan Chai; and

* 18 District Offices (that part of the register relevant to the respective geographical constituencies)

The provisional registers and omissions lists for functional constituencies and the Election Committee subsectors will be available at:

* the REO, 10th floor, Harbour Centre, 25 Harbour Road, Wan Chai; and 10th floor, Guardian House, 32 Oi Kwan Road, Wan Chai; and

* the five District Offices in Central and Western, Yau Tsim Mong, Kwun Tong, Sha Tin and Tsuen Wan.

The provisional register for geographical constituencies shows that the size of the electorate has increased by about 223,000 or 7.9 per cent, from 2.832 million in 1999 to 3.055 million this year.

A total of 248,584 of them are new electors.

The addresses and records of 313,448 electors have been updated while 25,868 electors who died or were disqualified have their names removed.

The distribution of electors in the five geographical constituencies is:

Hong Kong Island 627,391

Kowloon West 426,665

Kowloon East 518,344

New Territories West 791,791

New Territories East 691,049

Total: 3,055,240

The number of registered electors for the 28 functional constituencies has increased from 137,698 to 175,608.

Among them, 160,488 are individuals and 15,120 corporate bodies, which have appointed 13,682 authorised representatives.

The size of the electorate of the 35 Election Committee subsectors has increased from 143,435 to 179,026.

A total of 163,389 of them are individuals and 15,637 corporate bodies.

A total of 14,130 authorised representatives have been appointed.
19980212_005.e:
Provisional elector registers ready for inspection 

Members of the public who have signed up as electors for this year's Legislative Council elections are invited to check their registration particulars in the 1998 provisional registers, which will be published tomorrow (Friday).

Omissions lists containing the names of former electors who are no longer eligible to be included in the registers will also be published for public inspection.

"Anybody who has registered as an elector should take a look at the registers in the coming week to ensure that his name is included," the Chairman of the Electoral Affairs Commission, Mr Justice Woo Kwok-hing, told a press conference.

"This will be his last chance to make sure that he may take part in the first Legislative Council elections of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region," he said.

"Members of the public will have up to next Saturday (February 21) to raise objections, make claims or request for corrections regarding any entry on the registers or the omissions lists," he added.

Cases of objections and claims will be referred to one of the eight Revising Officers, who are members of the Judiciary, for determination before February 28.

Their decisions will be reflected in the final registers to be published before mid-March.

The provisional register for geographical constituencies shows that the total electorate has increased by 264,000, from 2.531 million to 2.795 million.

The figure is the result of an addition of 307,000 new electors and the deletion of 43,000 former electors who are no longer eligible to remain on the register.

A total of 341,000 electors' records have been updated in this voter registration exercise, mainly involving changes of address.

"That means about 70 per cent of the potential electors may go to the polls on May 24," he said.

The distribution of electors in the five geographical constituencies is:

Hong Kong Island 596,219

Kowloon West 411,429

Kowloon East 483,949

New Territories West 708,420

New Territories East 595,233

According to the provisional register for the 28 functional constituencies, the electorate totals 139,000, representing about 60 per cent of the potential electors.

About 127,000 of them are individuals while the remaining 12,000 are corporate electors.

About 10,000 authorised representatives have been appointed.

As for the 35 Election Committee subsectors, more than 139,000 people have registered as voters.

This represents a registration rate of about 57 per cent.

Among them, about 127,000 are individuals and the remaining 12,000 are corporate voters.

More than 10,000 authorised representatives have been appointed.

The provisional register for the geographical constituencies is available for inspection at:

* the Registration and Electoral Office, 10th floor, Harbour Centre, 25 Harbour Road, Wan Chai; and

* 18 District Offices (that part of the register relevant to the district)

The provisional registers for the functional constituencies and the Election Committee subsectors are placed at:

* The Registration and Electoral Office, 10th floor, Harbour Centre, 25 Harbour Road, Wan Chai, and 10th floor, Guardian House, 32 Oi Kwan Road, Wan Chai; and

* Five District Offices in Central and Western, Yau Tsim Mong, Kwun Tong, Sha Tin and Tsuen Wan.

Any person who wishes to inspect the registers is required to fill in a form and show his identity card.

A registered elector may call hotline 2891 1001 or make enquiries via fax (2891 1180) to check his own registration particulars.

Objections or claims must be lodged by February 21 in a specified form in person at the office of the Electoral Registration Officer, 10th floor, Harbour Centre, Wan Chai, or 10th floor, Guardian House, 32 Oi Kwan Road, Wan Chai.

"Using any information in the registers for non- election related purposes or any misuse is an offence punishable with a maximum fine of $5,000 and imprisonment for six months," Mr Justice Woo said.
20000306_016.e:
Public support for LegCo voter registration urged

The following is issued on behalf of the Electoral Affairs Commission:

The Registration and Electoral Office has received 305,000 application forms for voter registration and report of change of residential address of registered electors since a voter registration drive started on January 17.

An initial assessment finds that more than half of the forms are from residents applying for registration for the first time and nearly 40 per cent of the new electors are young people aged between 18 and 25.

"The Commission is pleased to see more and more young people sign up as electors.

Any Hong Kong permanent residents turning 18 before May 25 this year who ordinarily reside in Hong Kong are eligible to register," the Chairman of the Electoral Affairs Commission, Mr Justice Woo Kwok-hing, said during a visit to the Electoral Information Centre.

Home Affairs Department staff have visited 1.8 million families or 90 per cent of all the households in Hong Kong to help eligible electors fill out registration forms and to verify and update the records of registered electors on the electoral roll.

"We need the support of residents to help make the Legislative Council election fair, open and honest.

The more public participation, the better."

"It is a fundamental right of a permanent resident to vote and to stand for election in accordance with law.

Sign up as an elector before March 16 so that you can vote or even run in the election."

"Registered electors who have moved should report their new address to the Registration and Electoral Office by April 29 if they wish to vote in the constituency where they live and vote at a nearby polling station," he said.

Turning to voter registration for functional constituencies, the Registration and Electoral Office has made use of a notification procedure to help 32,000 electors register automatically on the basis of information in hand, such as membership lists of trade and professional bodies.

In addition, 4,400 application forms have been received so far.

In general, electors registered for a functional constituency will be registered in the corresponding Election Committee subsector.

Some may choose to register in any one of the four subsectors that have no corresponding functional constituencies if they are eligible.

At present 2.83 million electors are registered on the geographical constituency register, 138,000 on the functional constituency register and 143,000 on the Election Committee subsector register.

Mr Justice Woo said provisional registers of electors and omissions lists for 2000 would be published for public inspection on April 14 and members of the public would have two weeks to seek corrections or make appeals.

The provisional registers will be made available for inspection at the Registration and Electoral Office and local District Offices.

Telephone enquiries can also be made on 2891 1001.

Final registers will then be published by May 25.

During the visit to the Centre, Mr Justice Woo and the two Commission members, Mr Norman Leung and Dr Elizabeth Shing, made public the design of a set of two commemorative cards.

The two cards will be mailed to every registered elector of geographical constituencies together with their poll card in early September to thank them for signing up as electors and to remind them to vote on September 10.

Explaining why the cards are given to electors before they vote, Mr Justice Woo said: "The souvenir will be mailed to the home of every registered elector before polling day.

Everybody will hopefully be pleased with getting the two cards and be reminded to go to the polls."

"We do not have to estimate how many cards are to be delivered to each of the 500 polling stations.

There will not be disputes about the cards among voters and polling staff, who can concentrate their efforts on polling arrangements and serve electors better," he said.

The Electoral Information Centre has just been refurbished with brand new computer games, display panels and videos explaining the election systems of and arrangements for the Legislative Council elections.

More than 800 students from 16 schools have visited the Centre since it was opened last November.

The Centre is on the 10th floor, Guardian House, 32 Oi Kwan Road, Wan Chai.

It is open to the public from 9 am to 5 pm from Monday to Friday, and from 9 am to noon on Saturday.

Guided tours are arranged for groups.

Bookings may be made by calling 2891 1001 or faxing to 2519 7596.
19990224_021.e:
Electors reminded to check registration particulars

Registered electors will have until next Monday (March 1) to check their registration particulars and to make corrections or lodge appeals regarding any entry on the 1999 provisional registers of electors.

"It is particularly important for electors to make sure that their residential address is accurately recorded so that they may vote at the polling station near their home," a spokesman for the Registration and Electoral Office (REO) said.

He reminded people who had moved to report their new address to REO by March 1 to enable this updated information to be recorded on the final registers, which will be published by the end of March.

"Only electors whose names are listed on the final register for geographical constituencies are entitled to vote in the District Councils elections in November," he said.

Members of the public who wish to raise objections or lodge appeals regarding any entry or omission on the registers should visit REO in person before 5 pm on March 1.

Cases of objections and claims will be referred to the Revising Officer, a member of the Judiciary, for determination.

His decision will be reflected in the final registers.

As proposed in the District Councils Bill, a register of voters listed according to District Council constituencies will be published in September.

The provisional registers and the omission lists are open for public inspection during office hours at the following places:

* the Registration and Electoral Office on the 10th floor, Harbour Centre, 25 Harbour Road, Wan Chai (for provisional registers and omissions lists for geographical/functional constituencies);

* District Offices (for provisional register and omissions list for the geographical constituency relevant to that particular district); and

* the Registration and Electoral Office on the 10th floor, Guardian House, 32 Oi Kwan Road, Wan Chai and District Offices of Central and Western, Yau Tsim Mong, Kwun Tong, Tsuen Wan and Sha Tin (for provisional register and omissions list for functional constituencies).

Registered electors may check their registration particulars by calling the REO hotline - 2891 1001 or via fax to 2891 1180.
19971201_004.e:
Voter registration drive in full swing 

The Registration and Electoral Office (REO) is in top gear conducting a large-scale voter registration exercise in the territory in preparation for the first Legislative Council elections of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region next May.

The 60-member Legislative Council will be made up of 20 seats to be returned from five geographical constituencies through direct elections, 30 seats from 28 functional constituencies and 10 seats from the 800-member Election Committee, which will be formed through subsector elections in early April 1998.

Briefing the media today (Monday) on the progress of the exercise, the Chairman of the Electoral Affairs Commission, Mr Justice Woo Kwok-hing, said that to make the elections a success, the paramount task now was to sign up as many electors as possible and to update the electoral roll.

"We are moving full steam ahead to compile three separate provisional registers for public inspection in mid-February: one for the five geographical constituencies, one for the 28 functional constituencies and the other for the subsectors," he said.

As a result of a redrawing of the boundaries of geographical constituencies, starting from this month, over 2.5 million electors already on the electoral roll for geographical constituencies will be informed by mail of the new constituency they belong.

Those who have not received such advice later this month are requested to write to the REO or call its hotline - 2891 1001 - without delay.

Electors should tell the REO of any change to their address or any correction to their particulars.

About 30,000 voter registration ambassadors will be mobilised by the Home Affairs Department from December 6 to 12 to make door-to-door visits to every household across the territory.

To expedite voter registration for functional constituencies and Election Committee subsectors, the REO has already sought membership lists from major organisations, chambers of commerce, trade and professional bodies and relevant institutions.

A simplified procedure, called registration by way of notification, has been introduced to enable the Electoral Registration Officer (ERO) to register eligible functional constituency electors/subsector voters on the basis of information in hand so that they need not apply for registration.

For example, if a person has already been registered in a functional constituency, he will receive a notification from the ERO informing him of the functional constituency and the subsector in which he will be registered.

If he has been registered as an elector in a geographical constituency but not in any functional constituency although he is eligible to be registered in one, he may receive a notification from the ERO informing him that he is provisionally registered in that functional constituency and its corresponding subsector, or an appropriate subsector.

Notification letters are being sent to about 150,000 such eligible electors.

This will be followed by the sending of appeal letters to those who have not yet been registered.

Mr Justice Woo especially urged eligible electors in eight new functional constituencies to sign up as early as possible.

The eight new functional constituencies are: Agriculture and Fisheries; Insurance; Transport; Sports, Performing Arts, Culture and Publication; Import and Export; Textiles and Garment; Wholesale and Retail; and Information Technology.

In addition, the Labour functional constituency will have one more seat in the 1998 elections.

A seminar will be held at the Theatre of the City Hall Low Block in the afternoon of December 11 to further explain registration procedures to eligible functional constituency electors and voters for sub-sectors of the Election Committee.

Mr Justice Woo has written to bureau chiefs to seek their assistance in appealing to relevant organisations to take part in the seminar.

Staff of the Home Affairs Department will visit major organisations later this month to remind them to advise their members to register before the deadline closes on January 16.

Details of registration procedures for functional constituencies and subsectors can be found in a booklet of guidance notes compiled by the REO.

The booklet is now available at the REO on the 10th floor, Harbour Centre, 25 Harbour Road, Wan Chai and on the 10th floor, Guardian House, 32 Oi Kwan Road, Wan Chai; district offices all over the territory and the web site,

"http://www.info.gov.hk/reo/index.htm".

Two final registers containing the names of electors who are entitled to vote in the geographical and functional constituencies will be published in mid-March.

A final register of members of the Election Committee will be published within seven days after the results of the subsector elections are published.
19990211_018.e:
1999 provisional registers of electors published

The 1999 provisional registers of electors for the geographical and functional constituencies will be published tomorrow (February 12).

Registered electors may check their registration particulars set out on the provisional registers up to March 1.

"The provisional register for geographical constituencies contains more than 2.83 million names this time.

The recent voter registration campaign has trawled more than 91,700 new electors, and records of about 150,430 electors have been updated," a spokesman for the Registration and Electoral Office said.

"We are pleased to note that 46,140 young people aged between 18 and 25 have responded to our appeal and registered as electors during the campaign," the spokesman added.

He urged all registered electors to check if their names were included on the registers and to make sure that their residential addresses were correct.

"Only those whose names are on the register may cast their votes in the District Councils election to be held in November this year," he said.

As proposed in the District Councils Bill, a register of voters listed according to District Council constituencies will be published two months before the election.

The omissions lists, which contain the names of persons who are no longer eligible to have their names included on the registers, will also be published for public inspection up to March 1.

There are about 54,600 names contained in the 1999 omissions list for geographical constituencies.

These include mainly electors who have deceased and those who are no longer residing in the registered address.

These names will be deleted from the register and the persons concerned will not be able to vote.

Members of the public may make corrections, raise objections or lodge appeals in person regarding any entry or omission on the registers with the Registration and Electoral Office before 5 pm on March 1.

Cases of objections and claims will be referred to the Revising Officer, a member of the Judiciary who will conduct hearing on each case.

The decision of the Revising Officer will be reflected in the final registers to be published by the end of March 1999.

Registered electors may check their registration particulars by calling at the Registration and Electoral Office hotline - 2891 1001 or via fax to 2891 1180.

The provisional registers and the omissions lists are available for public inspection during office hours at the following places:

* the Registration and Electoral Office on the 10th floor, Harbour Centre, 25 Harbour Road, Wan Chai (for provisional registers and omissions lists for geographical/functional constituencies);

* District Offices (for provisional register and omissions list for the geographical constituency relevant to that particular district); and

* the Registration and Electoral Office on the 10th floor, Guardian House, 32 Oi Kwan Road, Wan Chai and District Offices of Central and Western, Yau Tsim Mong, Kwun Tong, Tsuen Wan and Sha Tin (for provisional register and omissions list for functional constituencies).
19980313_009.e:
