19990521_002.e:
Call to maintain personal hygiene to prevent EV-71 infection

The Department of Health (DH) called upon members of the public to maintain personal hygiene to prevent enterovirus infection with the approach of the summer season.

The appeal was made by DH's Consultant, Community Medicine, Dr Mak Kwok-hang following report of a suspected fatal case of Enterovirus-71 (EV-71) infection involving a two-year-old boy who was admitted to hospital on May 14 and passed away subsequently.

Initial laboratory result just available today (Friday) indicated that the boy had EV-71 infection.

Dr Mak pointed out that EV-71 is a kind of virus that occur worldwide and asymtomatic infections are common.

There is seasonal trend with most cases occurring in summer months.

According to international experience, EV-71 infection is not an uncommon disease in children.

Affected patients will develop fever, mouth ulcers and rash on the limbs.

The disease is usually self-limiting and complete recovery is the rule.

However, severe forms of EV-71 infection affecting the brain and the heart can occur but are rare.

The mode of transmission is predominantly faecal-oral route but the virus can also be spread through droplets or direct contact with respiratory secretions.

The best prevention is to maintain good personal hygiene.

He said that the Government had set up a sentinel surveillance system since mid-June 1988 to monitor hand-food-mouth disease, which is one of the manifestations of enterovirus disease.

In 1998, there were 60 confirmed cases of EV-71, five of whom had neurological complications.

In 1999, there were so far four confirmed cases of EV-71.

All patients made full recovery while the latest suspected case was the first fatal case reported.

Although the reported cases of hand foot and mouth diseases remained at a low level in the past few weeks, Dr Mak called upon members of the public of take preventive measure to prevent enteroviral infection.

For the current case, the Department of Health had initiated control measures at the affected nursery and home.

Health education had also been given.

To prevent EV-71 infection, members of the public should:

* Wash hands before eating and after going to toilet, changing diapers.

* Cover mouth and nose when coughing and sneezing.

* Maintain good air circulation.

* Clean thoroughly toys or appliances which are contaminated by nasal or oral secretions.

* Parents are advised to seek medical advice if their children developed symptoms of hand foot mouth disease.

* Children suffering from the infection should stay at home and avoid contacting other children until illness is over.

For more information, members of the public can call the Department's health education hotline: 2833 0111.
19980718_005.e:
Update on Enterovirus 71 (July 18)

No cases of the severe form of Enterovirus 71 (EV-71) had been confirmed since the Department of Health (DH) introduced a surveillance system in mid-June to monitor Hand-Foot-Mouth disease which is a manifestation of EV-71, a DH spokesman said.

As at today (Saturday), 11 cases of EV-71 had been confirmed and 16 cases were listed as suspected ones pending laboratory test confirmation.

All the patients had recovered and been discharged.
19990527_005.e:
EV-71 update

Laboratory result available today (Thursday) confirmed that the suspected fatal case of Enterovirus-71 (EV-71) announced by the Department of Health last Friday (May 21) had EV-71 infection.

A spokesman for the Department said that the case involved a two-year-old boy who died on May 14.

This was the first fatal case reported in Hong Kong since a surveillance system on hand-foot-mouth disease was set up in the territory in June last year.

Laboratory result also confirmed that the three-year-old sister of the diseased boy had EV-71 infection.

The sister had fully recovered earlier.

This brings the total number of EV-71 cases in Hong Kong this year to six cases.

One patient (mentioned above) had died and all others made full recovery.

In 1998, there were 60 confirmed cases of EV71 infections, five of whom had neurological complications but there was no fatality.

In the meantime, gene sequencing test found the sample of EV-71 virus isolated from the deceased boy belonged to a strain previously seen in Malaysia and Taiwan.

The spokesman said that the preventive measures for various strains of EV-71 are the same.

Good personal hygiene is the best prevention.

While the Department of Health and the Hospital Authority would closely monitored the situation, control measures and health education had been instituted at the boy's nursery, the spokesman said.

He reminded members of the public to maintain good personal hygiene such as washing hands after using toilets, changing diapers and before taking meals.

Parents are advised to seek medical advice if their children developed symptoms of hand-foot-mouth disease including fever, mouth ulcers and rash on the limbs.

They should keep their children at home until the illness is over.
19980713_005.e:
Update on Enterovirus 71 (July 13)

No cases of the severe form of Enterovirus 71 (EV-71) had been confirmed since the Department of Health (DH) introduced a surveillance system in mid-June to monitor Hand-Foot-Mouth disease which is a manifestation of EV-71, a DH spokesman said.

As at today (Monday), six cases of EV-71 had been confirmed and nine cases were listed as suspected ones pending laboratory test confirmation.

All the patients had recovered and been discharged.
19980715_014.e:
Update on Enterovirus 71 (July 15)

No cases of the severe form of Enterovirus 71 (EV-71) had been confirmed since the Department of Health (DH) introduced a surveillance system in mid-June to monitor Hand-Foot-Mouth disease which is a manifestation of EV-71, a DH spokesman said.

As at today (Wednesday), seven cases of EV-71 had been confirmed and 14 cases were listed as suspected ones pending laboratory test confirmation.

All the patients had recovered and been discharged.

19990204_025.e:
HOS Resale Restriction Relaxed

Resale restriction period for Home Ownership Scheme (HOS)/Private Sector Participation Scheme flats will be shortened to enhance the attractiveness of HOS and help promote mobility of flats, both in the open market and the secondary HOS market.

It is intended that through activities in the secondary HOS market, more rental flats can be recovered for allocation to needy families.

The approval to relax the existing resale restrictions was given today (Thursday) by the Housing Authority's Home Ownership Committee (HOC).

The relaxation is also intended to tie in with the arrangements under the Tenants Purchase Scheme by bringing in a uniformed and consistent approach in resale restrictions for the two schemes.

Owners can sell their flats in the open market, subject to payment of a premium proportionate to the original discount, after five years from first assignment.

This will replace the existing 10-year resale restriction rule.

A spokesman for the Authority said: "The Authority will not buy back flats after the five-year restriction period since these flats can be sold in the open market."

Besides, HOS flats could be put on sale in the HOS secondary market a year earlier following the relaxation that allows owners to sell their flats, between two to five years of first assignment, to sitting public rental housing tenants and Waiting List applicants at a negotiated price without the payment of premium.

Another option for these HOS owners is to apply to sell their flats back to the Authority at assessed market value less the original discount.

"This is a revised basis for determining buy-back price of HOS flats which relates the price assessment to the original discount the purchasers enjoyed at the initial purchase,"

"The new provision, which replaces the original HA practice of buying back at prevailing HOS price, will be a more equitable arrangement particularly in light of the various discounts rates used in different phases of sale," the spokesman added.

Also with the relaxation, the Authority would accept offers of buy-back at original price from owners whose property is within two years of first assignment.

Following the approval, actions will be taken to amend the Schedule to the Housing Ordinance to provide legal teeth to the new resale criteria.

Meanwhile, the HOC also reviewed the management fees for 102 HOS estates, approving to freeze the rates for 80 of them and increase those of another 21 after considering the financial position of the courts' management funds.

The spokesman said, "With the joint efforts of the departmental staff and the property management agents, we have succeeded in maintaining handsome surplus for 80 estates where the current fee levels can be frozen for another fiscal year."

At present, all HOS estates are managed by private management agents under the supervision of the Housing Department.

Management fees are used to cover management and maintenance expenses and are charged on a cost-recovery basis.

The average management fee per square meter is $9.14 for all HOS estates.

The monthly management fees for 21 HOS estates, however, will be revised to range from $399 to $710 a month, a slight increase in $2 to $32 per flat.

The increase, to be effective for a year from 1 April, is considered necessary to maintain a healthy financial position of the management funds.

The Committee also noted that the Supervision Cost, charged by the Housing Department to cover the cost of supervisory staff and administrative overheads in the management fee, will be frozen at $30.30 per flat per month in the next financial year for the third consecutive year.
19990930_030.e:
New Measures To Enhance Singletons' Accessibility to Public Housing

A three-pronged approach is being considered by the Housing Authority to enhance the accessibility of non-elderly single persons to public rental housing (PRH) and subsidised home ownership.

As a first step, the Authority's Rental Housing Committee (RHC) approved at today's (Thursday) meeting to allow singleton clearees who satisfy the rehousing eligibility criteria the same access to public rental housing irrespective of their age.

Later on, the Home Ownership Committee (HOC) will decide whether to expand the coverage of home ownership schemes to single persons, and whether to allow unmarried family members to delete from the home ownership records if they want to apply for subsidised housing separately.

A spokesman for the Authority said while enhancing single persons' accessibility to public housing, the new initiatives can also help shorten their waiting time.

They are introduced in response to the pledges made in the Long Term Housing Strategy White Paper and the 1998 Housing Policy Booklet.

He said in allocating public housing resources, priority has always been given to households with greater needs.

Single persons, except the elderly, are currently not accorded with preferential treatment as a result of the shortage of small flats.

At present, the average waiting time for PRH for non-elderly single persons is nine years, and singleton squatters aged below 50 who are affected by Government clearance operations are not allowed to opt for self-contained PRH flats.

Single persons also have limited access to subsidised home ownership schemes.

"As time evolves, it is necessary to review the eligibility criteria for non-elderly single persons in view of an increased supply of housing production in the coming years and the yearning for home ownership amongst the community," the spokesman explained.

To meet the new demand in PRH, the Authority will increase the supply of 6,000 additional small flats by converting 1,600 3-Bedroom flats scheduled for completion up to 2003/04 into self-contained small flats and reviewing the production and flat mix for housing projects to be completed after 2003/04.

In addition, the Authority will continue to arrange trawling exercises to create suitable small vacant flats to supplement the supply.

As to home ownership, the Authority's HOC is studying proposals to accept White Form (WF) applications from single persons for Home Ownership Scheme/Private Sector Participation Scheme (HOS/PSPS), and singleton applications as well as WF applications from non-nuclear families for Home Purchase Loan Scheme (HPLS).

The HOC will meet in November to decide on the matters.

They will also discuss the following items in relation to the proposals:

--to set the monthly income and net asset limits for WF singleton applicants for HOS/PSPS/HPLS at $15,500 and $350,000 respectively.

--to allow both WF and Green Form (GF) singletons under HOS/PSPS and Green Form (GF) applicants under the Secondary Market Scheme to buy flats up to 50 sq.m. (2-Bedroom flats).

--to set the loan/subsidy amount of HPLS for single persons at half of the present rates, i.e. $200,000/$250,000 loan or $1,700 monthly subsidy for WF and $300,000/$400,000 loan or $2,550 monthly subsidy for GF.

Subject to approval by relevant Committees, these initiatives will take immediate effect except for WF applicants to join HOS/PSPS in HOS Phase 21B to be launched at the end of this year.

For HPLS, single persons can apply in the next exercise.

The spokesman stressed that the new initiatives will have minimal impact on the housing pledges for households of other sizes as there is an increased housing production in the coming years.

At today's meeting, the Rental Housing Committee also noted the progress on the enforcement action against unauthorised installation of air-conditioners in rental estates.

In Stage Two of the three-year exercise, a total of 9,269 cases were handled between November 1998 to July 1999, in which almost 99% have been rectified.

Stage Three, the final stage of the exercise, will commence in October to cover about 12,500 unauthorised window-type air-conditioners scattered in 61 estates.

A case by case approach will be adopted to assist tenants in rectifying their installations.

Notice-to-Quit will be served on those tenants who ignore warnings and show no intention to rectify.
20000419_012.e:
More Choices for HOS Secondary Market Buyers

The following is issued on behalf of Hong Kong Housing Authority:

With effect from April 15, 2000, flats sold under the first phase of the Tenants Purchase Scheme (TPS) can be resold under the Home Ownership Scheme's (HOS) Secondary Market Scheme (SMS).

Green Form buyers can now have more choices in flat type and court location in the SMS.

To tie in with the corresponding relaxation in HOS, one-person families will be allowed to buy flats of any size.

The number of Home Ownership Scheme/Private Sector Participation Scheme flats eligible for sale in the SMS reached 209 000 by the end of March 2000.

Together with the TPS units, the total number of flats eligible for the SMS will be much larger.

The annual turnover for this market in 1999/2000 was 3 524 units.

With wider choice in flat type and location, more transactions can be expected in the SMS.

The six estates under TPS Phase 1 which was launched in April 1998, include Wah Kwai Estate in Aberdeen, Fung Tak Estate in Wong Tai Sin, Heng On Estate in Ma On Shan, Wan Tau Tong Estate in Tai Po, Cheung On Estate in Tsing Yi and Kin Sang Estate in Tuen Mun.

The two-year resale restriction period for flats sold under the first batch of assignments expired on 15 April 2000 and more than one thousand flats will be eligible for sale in the SMS by the end of April this year.

The HOS Secondary Market was established in June 1997 to enable HOS units to be resold after entering the third year.

Owners can sell their flats to Green Form buyers without paying premium to the Housing Authority.

Green Form buyers include tenants of public housing estates and qualified residents of temporary housing areas, cottage areas, transit centres and holders of Green Form Certificates issued by the Housing Authority.

They will subsequently assume the responsibility of paying premium when they wish to sell the flat in the open market.

Successful Green Form applicants for the Home Purchase Loan Scheme can also use the loan to buy SMS flats.

For those who choose a flat priced below the loan amount, they will be given a monthly subsidy instead of the interest free loan.
19980723_004.e:
Mortgage Subsidy Scheme to assist Home Ownership

The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:

Public housing tenants affected by the Housing Authority's (HA) Comprehensive Redevelopment Programme (CRP) will be given a subsidy to purchase 'transfer' block flats or Home Ownership Scheme (HOS) flats, under a new scheme endorsed by the Authority's Home Ownership Committee (HOC) today (Thursday).

The Mortgage Subsidy Scheme (MSS) will be implemented from HOS Phase 20A onwards.

Tenants affected by CRP within three years are eligible to purchase HOS flats with this monthly subsidy which lasts for a period of six years.

"The scheme is one of the new initiatives announced in the 1998 Long Term Housing Strategy White Paper to help achieve the 70% home ownership target as the Chief Executive pledged in his Policy Address in 1997," a spokesman for the Authority said.

"Having regard to the price difference of various flat sizes and the affordability levels of affected tenants, two sets of subsidy rates will be introduced," the spokesman said.

For those purchasing one-bedroom, two- bedroom or three-bedroom flats, a total amount of $162,000 will be offered over six years. " They will be paid $3,000 every month for the first two years, $2,250 for the second two years, and $1,500 for the final two years," he said.

A subsidy of $81,000 will be given to the purchasers of small household flats -- $1,500, $1,125, and $750 monthly at 2-year intervals.

"To deter speculation, owners who resell their flats either to the HA or in the secondary market during the subsidy period are required to repay to the Authority the full amount of subsidy received," the spokesman said.

"This restriction will be lifted after the six years of subsidy," he added.

"Tenants paying market rents are not eligible for the mortgage subsidy but allowed to purchase the flats," he added.

A pilot scheme is selected in the Valley Road Estate CRP Phase 1 which is scheduled for clearance early next year.

Two blocks comprising 300 units in the new estate at Homantin South Phase 1 are earmarked as transfer blocks for sale.

Another block with 184 units is reserved to cater for additional demand of the tenants.

Affected tenants will be invited to apply next month.

The spokesman stressed that sufficient rental units would be allocated to the affected tenants who opt to continue to rent.

The HOC today also approved the average selling prices of flats to be sold in the pilot scheme.

Small household flats are sold at $578,400, i.e. $21,500/m2 Saleable Area (SA) or $1,150/ft2 Gross Floor Area (GFA).

The average prices of one-bedroom to three-bedroom Harmony-3 flats range from $918,900 to $1,360,700, i.e. $23,500/m2 SA or $1,600/ft2 GFA.

The flats are priced on the basis of 50% discount rate.

"Flexible discount options of 40% and 60% however will not be allowed as mortgage subsidies are given, "the spokesman said.

With the assistance of the MSS, most of the households will generally spend less than 40% of their total income in housing.

The total housing cost to rent is kept at a ratio below 1.84 on average.

Flats which are not purchased by the Valley Road CRP Phase 1 tenants will be offered for sale to public housing tenants living in estates in the same district and are affected by CRP within three years with the payment of mortgage subsidy.

"Any unsold flats remained after these two rounds of sale arrangements will be put up for sale in regular HOS sale programme," he added.
19990114_009.e:
New measures to enhance recovery of PRH flats

The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:

The Housing Authority will take new measures to ensure the early recovery of public rental housing (PRH) flats under various home ownership schemes.

At present, these schemes include the Home Ownership Scheme (HOS), the Private Sector Participation Scheme (PSPS) and the Home Purchase Loan Scheme (HPLS).

The measures, applicable to all home ownership schemes to be announced after 14 January 1999, were endorsed by the Authority's Rental Housing Committee (RHC) at a meeting today (Thursday).

They will help deter tenants who tend to hold on to their PRH units after purchasing a flat under HOS, PSPS and HPLS through Green Forms.

Under the new measures, tenants who make use of Green Forms to purchase a flat under these schemes will be asked to tender notices-to-quit (NTQ) at the time of taking over their HOS/PSPS flats or effecting the assignment in the case of HPLS to terminate their tenancies and surrender the PRH flats within one calendar month.

For any extended stay after the expiry of the NTQ, the tenants concerned will be charged an occupation fee equivalent to three times the net rent plus rates.

In the case of market rent payers, the amount will be equivalent to the market rent or three times the net rent plus rates, whichever is higher.

The time ceiling allowed for PRH tenants to surrender their flats will be three months.

Any application for further extension will normally not be considered.

Exceptional cases on strong compassionate ground will have to be considered by the Regional Chief Manager/Management on individual merits.

Currently, successful Green Form applicants of various home ownership schemes are required to surrender their PRH unit within two calendar months subsequent to taking over of their new flat.

However, tenants used to put forth different reasons such as decoration/fitting-out difficulties and social/medical problems in order to extend their holding over period.

There was also no maximum of the time limit for these tenants to surrender their PRH flats.

A spokesman for the Authority said in principle, the Authority can cease subsidies to those occupiers who fail to deliver up vacant possession of the PRH flats after the expiry of the NTQ.

"It is inequitable to allow PRH tenants in possession of self-owned flats to enjoy double housing benefits for any prolonged period," said the spokesman, adding that the new time frame has already taken into account the difficulties that may arise for tenants to vacate their PRH flats within too short a period of time.

Those successful Green Form applicants of home ownership schemes announced prior to 14 January 1999 will be reminded of the need to surrender the PRH units within two calendar months.

An occupation fee equivalent to three times the net rent plus rates will be charged for any extended stay.

In the case of market rent payers, the amount will be equivalent to the market rent or three times the net rent plus rates, whichever is higher.

The spokesman said the new measures are in line with the recommendations of the Office of Ombudsman, which in an investigation unveiled that about 20 per cent (8,955) of the PRH flats surrendered by successful applicants of various home ownership schemes for the period 1992/93 to 1996/97 were recovered beyond the normal two-month time frame.

Other measures corresponding to the Ombudsman's recommendations include the enhancement of Housing Department's IT system to facilitate Estate Housing Managers and the respective District Senior Housing Managers to monitor the flat recovery situation.
19990303_059.e:
Relaxation of Resale Restriction for flats

The Chief Executive in Council approved amended resale restrictions for flats sold under the Home Ownership Scheme (HOS) and Private Sector Participation Scheme (PSPS) to bring them in line with those approved for Tenants Purchase Scheme (TPS) flats.

The TPS, which was first launched in January 1998, aimed to provide at least 250,000 families living in public rental housing to buy their flats at reasonable and affordable prices over the next 10 years.

A spokesman for the Housing Bureau said today (Wednesday) that a TPS flat owner could sell the flat in the first two years from first assignment, to the Housing Authority (HA) at the original purchase price.

"After two years from first assignment," the spokesman said, " the flat can be sold to the HA at assessed market value less the original percentage discount and credit; or to a current or prospective public rental tenant, at a negotiated price without payment of a premium.

"The flat can be sold in the open market subject to payment of a premium proportionate to the original discount at the time of purchase, after five years from first assignment," he said.

"The Government considered that the resale restrictions for HOS flats and PSPS flats should be relaxed in line with those under the TPS because these are all subsidised flat sale schemes administered by the HA," the spokesman said.

"The turnover of HOS and PSPS flats can be increased by relaxing the resale restrictions, helping to meet the demand for subsidised home ownership flats and freeing public rental flats for reallocation to people in genuine need, " he said.

Moreover, the buy back price for HOS, PSPS and TPS flats is to be revised so as to relate to the discount enjoyed by the owner at the time of original purchase, the spokesman added.

The proposal will allow an addition of 16,000 HOS and PSPS flats to be sold in the secondary market and 80,000 flats in the open market.

Amendments to the Schedule to the Housing Ordinance will be made to put these approved resale restrictions into effect.

The proposal will be submitted to the Legislative Council in mid March 1999.
19990521_034.e:
HOS resale restriction relaxed

The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:

To provide greater flexibility to Home Ownership Scheme flat owners, the ten-year resale restriction period will be shortened to five years with effect from 1st June, 1999.

According to the newly amended Housing Ordinance 1999, Home Ownership Scheme/Private Sector Participation Scheme (HOS/PSPS) flats are allowed to be sold in the HOS Secondary Market after two years from the date of the first assignment, and sold in the open market after five years.

All the HOS/PSPS flats sold from HOS Phase 3B onwards are affected by this legislative change.

At the end of May 1999, the number of HOS/PSPS flats exceeding five years from the first assignment is about 160,000 and the number of flats between two and five years is about 40,000.

Since the implementation of 10-year resale restriction in HOS Phase 3A, about 16,000 owners have paid the assessed premium and sold their flats in the open market.

The HOS Secondary Market was introduced in June 1997 and since then about 3,800 flats had been sold to public housing tenants or other eligible buyers, with more the 3,000 public housing units recovered.

This has contributed to the mobility of public housing units.

Starting from 1st June, 1999, HOS/PSPS flats within the first two years from the date of first assignment can be sold back to the Housing Authority or its nominated buyer at the original price, after deducting any unpaid mortgage and other prescribed deductible items.

During the third to fifth years from the date of first assignment, HOS/PSPS flat owners can either sell their flats to the Housing Authority or sell it in the HOS Secondary Market.

The Housing Authority will buy back the flats at the prevailing market value less the original discount percentage.

Should they choose to sell their flats in the Secondary Market, owners do not have to pay any premium, but have to apply for a "Certificate to Sell" first.

Within the five-year resale restriction period, if the Housing Authority does not exercise the option to buy back, owners can apply for premium assessment and then sell or rent the flat after paying the assessed premium.

For flats exceeding five years, owners can still sell them in the Secondary Market without paying any premium, or they can sell them in the open market after paying a premium to the Housing Authority.

It is Housing Authority's policy NOT to buy back HOS/PSPS flats which have expired the five year resale restriction period.
19991126_008.e:
Accessibility of Single Persons to Home Ownership Enhanced

The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:

Single persons are allowed to apply for various subsidised home ownership schemes, starting from the next phase of the Home Ownership Scheme (HOS)/Home Purchase Loan Scheme (HPLS).

The Housing Authority's Home Ownership Committee (HOC) approved at today's (Friday) meeting to expand the coverage of subsidised home ownership schemes to single persons.

White Form (WF) singleton applicants can apply for the HOS/Private Sector Participation Scheme (PSPS) starting from HOS Phase 21B.

WF and Green Form (GF) singleton applicants as well as non-nuclear families can also apply for the HPLS from the next phase of the HPLS onwards.

A spokesman for the Authority said the new initiatives will enhance the opportunities and choices of single persons to acquire home ownership.

The monthly income and net asset limit for WF singleton applicants for HOS/PSPS and HPLS is set at $15,500 and $350,000 respectively.

Applicants have to be able to fulfil the residence requirement in addition to satisfying the income/asset limit and no-property-ownership requirement.

Considering that single persons are allowed to apply for subsidised home ownership schemes and the relaxation of the residence requirement for Public Rental Housing, the HOC also approved to relax the existing residence requirement for WF HOS/HPLS applicants.

With effect from HOS Phase 21B and the next HPLS application exercise onwards, only the applicant will be required to have fulfilled seven years' unconditional stay in Hong Kong.

The subsidy amount to be granted to single persons under the HPLS is half of the present rates, i.e. up to $200,000 / $250,000 for an interest-free housing loan or a monthly mortgage subsidy of $1,700 for WF applicants and $300,000 / $400,000 (interest-free loan) or $2,550 (monthly subsidy) for GF applicants.

Single GF and WF applicants will be allowed to buy flats up to 50 square meter saleable (2-bedroom flats) under the HOS/PSPS.

If they want to buy a small flat (around 20 square metre saleable), they can do so according to their normal flat selection priority.

But if they want to choose a larger HOS flat, their flat selection will be placed at the end of the queue.

They have to make a decision whether to wait for the larger flats when their turn for selection of small flats is due.

GF applicants will also be allowed to buy flats up to 50 square metre saleable under the HOS Secondary Market Scheme (SMS).

The HOC also decided to allow family members, other than the owner and his/her spouse, to be deleted from the home ownership record if they want to apply for subsidised housing separately.

"To deter possible abuse, the deletion of crucial members can only be effected at least two years after the family has joined a subsidised home ownership scheme," the spokesman said.

According to the findings of the General Household Survey conducted in the second quarter of 1999, the opening up of HOS/PSPS flats and HPLS to WF single persons will benefit about 32,500 one-person households living in private properties.

"The additional demand can be met as there is an increase in public housing production in the coming years," the spokesaman added.

The HOC also decided to give a single discount instead of three flexible discount rates for future Tenant Purchase Scheme (TPS) sale exercises.

This will come into effect when TPS Phase 3 is launched.

Flexible discounts were offered in TPS Phases 1 and 2.

Since almost all TPS buyers had opted for the highest discount rate, there is no need to offer flexible discounts, the spokesman explained.
19990730_025.e:
Relaxation of HOS Resale Restriction Promotes Mobility

The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:

After the relaxation of resale restriction period of Home Ownership Scheme (HOS) / Private Sector Participation Scheme (PSPS) flats, the number of applications for premium assessment for HOS flats before putting up for sale in the open market increases sharply.

The relaxation of the resale restriction came into effect on 1 June 1999.

Owners can sell their flats in the open market, subject to payment of a premium proportionate to the original discount, after five years from the first assignment.

This replaces the 10-year resale restriction rule.

Following the relaxation, the number of HOS/PSPS flats that can be put up for sale in the open market increases from 80,000 to 160,000 by June.

529 applications for premium assessment for HOS flats were received in June, which is twice the number recorded in May.

Out of the total applications received in June, 312 applications were submitted by the owners of the HOS courts in the 6th to 10th years while 217 applications were submitted by the owners of the post 10-year HOS courts.

The relaxation also allows owners to sell their flats under the HOS Secondary Market Scheme (SMS), after two years from the first assignment, to sitting public rental housing tenants and eligible buyers at a negotiated price without the payment of premium.

At the end of May, the number of HOS/PSPS flats between the 3rd and 5th years is about 40,000.

"Through the activities in the HOS Secondary Market, Green Form applicants can acquire home ownership and more rental flats can be recovered for allocation for the needy," a spokesman for the Housing Authority said.

Up to 8 July 1999, a total of 4,533 Letters of Nomination (LN) have been issued with 4,497 transactions recorded under the SMS.

At the same time, 3,392 public rental housing flats have been recovered for allocation to needy families.

Since the Green Form applicants are allowed to make use of the Home Purchase Loan to buy flats in the HOS Secondary Market starting July 1998, the number of transactions in the Secondary Market has been increased with an average of 360 transactions each month.

As at 8 July 1999, a total of 2,832 transactions recorded under the SMS have made use of the Home Purchase Loan.
20000419_014.e:
Flat Size Restriction Relaxed for Singleton Home Purchasers

The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:

To cater for the demand of single persons for larger flats, the Housing Authority has decided to allow singleton applicants to purchase subsidised home ownership flats irrespective of the flat size when all family households have made their flat selections.

As approved by the Housing Authority's Home Ownership Committee (HOC), the relaxation will be effective from the coming Home Ownership Scheme (HOS) Phase 22A.

All singleton applicants, whether Green Form (GF) or White Form (WF), will be invited to come forward for flat selection after all the family households, including non-nuclear WF households, have made their choice.

WF applicants are however still refrained from purchasing vacant flats under the Tenants Purchase Scheme.

Application from WF single persons were accepted for the first time under HOS Phase 21B.

There was an overwhelming response from singleton applicants.

According to the then prevailing policy, they could choose to buy a Small Flat up to 28 square metres saleable in their normal turn of flat selection, or purchase a larger HOS flat up to 51 square metres saleable when all family households have completed their flat selection.

If they wanted to buy flats sold under the Morgtage Subsidy Scheme, the Buy or Rent Option Scheme or vacant flats under the Tenants Purchase Scheme, single persons could only purchase flats up to 25 square metres saleable.

Among the singleton applicants of HOS Phase 21B, only 124 purchased Small Flats and 734 succeeded in choosing flats up to 51 square metres saleable.

In order to satisfy the aspiration of single-person families for larger accommodations, the Housing Authority has decided to relax the prevailing policy.

To achieve maximum efficiency, single-person families will be required to come for flat selection in one round and eligible applicants who had not been given a chance for flat selection in Phase 21B will be exempted from vetting interviews in the coming phase of sale, provided there are no changes that may affect their eligibility, said a spokesman for the Housing Authority.

19990222_008.e:
Sustained efforts to help the unemployed

The provisional seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for the period November 1998 - January 1999 was 5.8 per cent, and the provisional underemployment rate was 3.1 per cent, according to the latest labour force statistics released today (Monday) by the Census and Statistics Department.

For the period October - December 1998, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was revised marginally downwards, from the earlier provisional figure of 5.8 per cent to 5.7 per cent, while the underemployment rate was revised upwards, from the earlier provisional figure of 2.9 per cent to 3.0 per cent.

Comparing the period November 1998 - January 1999 with October - December 1998, the increase in unemployment rate occurred mainly in the transport and manufacturing sectors.

Yet this was largely offset by the decreases seen in the decoration and maintenance and the business services sectors.

As to the underemployment rate, increases were seen in the foundation superstructure construction and transport sectors.

The unemployment and underemployment rates in the other major sectors remained relatively stable.

For the period October - December 1998, the size of the total labour force was 3,433,700, of whom 3,232,500 were employed and 201,200 were unemployed.

In the same period, the number of underemployed persons was 102,100.

For the period November 1998 - January 1999, the size of the total labour force was provisionally estimated at 3,451,000, while the number of unemployed persons and underemployed persons were provisionally estimated at 202,000 and 109,000 respectively.

The Government Economist, Mr K Y Tang said that as the economic situation remained slack recently, both the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate and underemployment rate edged up further.

On the current trend and having regard to the quieter work period shortly after the Chinese New Year holidays, the unemployment rate is likely to stay high in the near term.

Speaking at a press briefing today, the Secretary for Education and Manpower, Mr Joseph W P Wong said that as the economy of Hong Kong was still undergoing adjustment, the high unemployment rate was likely to continue for the near future.

"The employment outlook for the next few months remains uncertain and sentiments in the private sector are still cautious," Mr Wong said.

He drew attention however to some positive developments in the economic situation.

"The total tourist arrival figure had reached five million in the latter half of 1998, representing a growth of 7.5 per cent over the corresponding figure for the same period in 1997.

In December hotel occupancy rate had reached 81 per cent, which was much higher than the average of 67 per cent recorded during the early part of 1998," he said.

Meanwhile some $1.3 billion had been injected into the capital market under the Special Finance Scheme, benefiting 1,000 small and medium enterprises during the six-month since its launching in August 1998.

The number of companies which had successfully obtained a loan under the scheme increased by 27 per cent during January.

"A review is currently underway to assess the effectiveness of the scheme and to see how it can be further improved to assist SMEs to obtain finance", Mr Wong said.

He also pointed out that a number of major infrastructural projects will commence work in the next two months.

These included the Castle Peak Hospital redevelopment, the widening of Tolo Highways and the Tung Chung development.

Over 2,000 new job opportunities will be created in the process.

Despite the downturn in the economy, about 3,000 persons found jobs through the Local Employment Services of the Labour Department in January.

"The Labour Department has introduced some innovative measures to modernise and strengthen its employment services," Mr Wong said.

A new Job Vacancy Processing Centre and Telephone Employment Service Centre was opened in North Point on February 11 to provide speedy and convenient services to job seekers and employers.

The Department has also simplified registration procedures and will intensify publicity of job vacancies.

Mr Wong appealed to those people who were out of a job to make productive use of their spare time and acquire a skill which would help them secure and hold down a job.

"Employers' expectations from their employees are rising because they have to compete in a more sophisticated business world.

More demand will be placed on the skill level and productivity of their staff.

"The Employers Retraining Board (ERB) is putting in extra effort in this respect.

It helps employers to design tailor-made retraining courses which will best suit their needs and provide, where appropriate, on-the-job allowances to retrainees.

Quite a number of companies have participated in the ERB tailor-made retraining courses and the results have been rather encouraging," he said.

The ERB has adopted a new strategy to improve the quality and effectiveness of its courses and services.

Course contents have been standardised and repackaged into modular form.

Systematic and regular researches have been carried out into the manpower needs of the labour market.

To meet the demand of unemployed persons, the ERB has increased the number of its full-time training places by 80 per cent, from 18,400 in 1997-98 to 32,800 in 1998-99.

Its overall training capacity for this year has also increased by 30 per cent.

The latest initiatives of the ERB include retraining courses for information technical assistants, care home attendants, cable jointing and testing technicians, customer installation and maintenance technicians, blockwiring system implementation technicians, standbuilders, freight forwarders, etc.

These courses have been organised in response to labour market demand.

"We will take stock of the latest situation and progress of the various measures to tackle unemployment in the forthcoming Task Force meeting on Thursday," Mr Wong said.

The unemployment and underemployment statistics were obtained from a continuous General Household Survey.

The survey for October - December 1998 covered a quarterly sample of some 23,900 households or 79,400 persons, selected in accordance with a scientifically designed sampling scheme to represent the land-based civilian non-institutional population in Hong Kong.

Data on labour force characteristics were obtained from the survey by interviewing each member aged 15 or over in the households sampled.

In the survey, the definitions used in measuring unemployment and underemployment follow closely those recommended by the International Labour Organisation.

The unemployment rate is 'seasonally adjusted'.

This refers to the fact that it has been adjusted for seasonal variations in the proportion of first-time job-seekers in the labour force.

Detailed analysis of labour force characteristics is given in the report on the General Household Survey which is published four times a year.

The next report covering the quarter ending December 1998 will be on sale at the Government Publications Centre, Ground Floor, Low Block, 66 Queensway, Hong Kong, by early March 1999.

Enquiries for more detailed statistics for October - December 1998 can be directed to the General Household Survey Section (2), Census and Statistics Department at 2887 5506.

Improving Employment Opportunities

The provisional seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for the period April - June 1999 was 6.1 per cent, and the provisional underemployment rate was 2.9 per cent, according to the latest labour force statistics released today (Monday) by the Census and Statistics Department.

For the period March - May 1999, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was confirmed to be the same as the previously released provisional figure of 6.3 per cent, while the underemployment rate was revised upward to 3.0 per cent from the provisional figure of 2.9 per cent.

Comparing the period April - June 1999 with March - May 1999, decreases in unemployment rate were seen mainly in the construction, manufacturing, import/export trades, hotels, transport, real estate and insurance sectors.

As to the underemployment rate, decreases were seen in the decoration and maintenance, manufacturing, transport and restaurants sectors.

For the period March - May 1999, the size of the total labour force was 3,465,100, of whom 3,249,400 were employed and 215 700 were unemployed.

In the same period, the number of underemployed persons was 102 800.

For the period April - June 1999, the size of the total labour force was provisionally estimated at 3,476,000, while the number of unemployed persons and underemployed persons were provisionally estimated at 212,000 and 100,000 respectively.

Mr K Y Tang, the Government Economist, observed that as business conditions gradually improved, the labour market also benefited, and both the unemployment and the underemployment rates fell in the most recent period.

However, he cautioned that with more fresh graduates and school leavers entering the labour market in the next couple of months, the unemployment rate especially for younger persons would probably remain relatively high in the near term.

Speaking at a press briefing today, the Secretary for Education and Manpower, Mr Joseph W P Wong said that the unemployment rate appeared to have stabilised.

"It would be unrealistic to expect the unemployment rate to decline significantly in the coming months.

However it is at least reassuring to see some improvement in employment opportunities for our workers", Mr Wong said.

In June, the Local Employment Services (LES) of the Labour Department secured 11,300 job vacancies.

The number of successful placements for the month was over 3,800.

This figure showed an increase of 11 per cent over the previous months.

Over 12,000 new job opportunities will be created by major infrastructure and public works building projects in the coming six months.

Examples of such projects include the West Rail phase 1, MTR Tseung Kwan O extension, Kowloon Hospital Redevelopment, engineering infrastructure for the Cyberport development at Telegraph Bay etc.

Following revision to the terms of the Special Finance Scheme, an increasing number of small and medium enterprises have benefited from it.

In June, about 720 applications were approved under the scheme which represented an increase of 85 per cent over the previous month.

The amounts of loan involved exceeded $548 million, which represented a 49 per cent increase over May.

"As the unemployment rate is still at a high level, we will continue to do what we can to help workers find jobs and to train up the unemployed and first-time job seekers.

Indeed, our priority task in the coming months is to launch a comprehensive pre-employment training programme for school leavers entering the job market for the first time", Mr Wong said.

The survey for March - May 1999 covered a quarterly sample of some 24,100 households or 78,900 persons, selected in accordance with a scientifically designed sampling scheme to represent the population of Hong Kong.

Data on labour force characteristics were obtained from the survey by interviewing each member aged 15 or over in the sampled households.

In the survey, the definitions used in measuring unemployment and underemployment follow closely those recommended by the International Labour Organisation.

19980720_022.e:
Government making sustained efforts to tackle unemployment

The provisional seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for the period April - June 1998 was 4.5 per cent, and the provisional underemployment rate was 2.6 per cent, according to the latest labour force statistics released today (Monday) by the Census and Statistics Department.

For the period March - May 1998, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was revised marginally downwards by 0.1 of a percentage point from the provisional figure of 4.2 per cent to 4.1 per cent, while the underemployment rate remained the same as the provisional figure of 2.6 per cent released last month.

Comparing the period April - June 1998 with March - May 1998, the increase in unemployment rate occurred mainly in the retail, restaurants and construction sectors.

The unemployment situation in the other major sectors was relatively more stable.

As to the underemployment rate, increases were seen in the retail sector and the foundation and superstructure sectors of the construction industry, while decreases were seen in the decoration and maintenance sector of the construction industry as well as clothing and footwear sectors.

The underemployment situation in the other major sectors was broadly stable.

The latest figures indicate that some local employers continued to down-size their workforce, in view of the slackened economic growth and uncertain business outlook.

Moreover, the entry of fresh graduates into the labour market most recently has added to the overall labour supply.

In the three months ending May 1998, total labour supply was 3,327,600, of which 3,197,900 were employed and 129,700 were unemployed.

In the same period, the number of underemployed persons was 85,800.

For the period April - June 1998, the provisional number of unemployed persons was about 144,000.

The Financial Secretary, Mr Donald Tsang, who heads the Task Force on Employment, said that he was deeply concerned about the rise in unemployment rate, and was acutely aware of the difficulties facing the unemployed.

He stressed that the Government would continue to leave no stone unturned in helping the unemployed to re-enter the labour market.

"The impact of the Asian financial crisis is much more widespread and protracted for the whole region than anyone could have expected.

While being more fortunate than many of our neighbours, we are going through a painful economic adjustment period brought on largely by external factors.

High unemployment rate might remain with us for some time.

Things are likely to get worse before they get better.

We have to face up to this unpleasant reality.

However, we must not lose heart.

Our fiscal, foreign exchange, banking and corporate fundamentals are strong and employment prospects remain positive.

I am sure that we shall pull through and emerge even more competitive and robust," he said.

"The effects of the tax concessions in this year's budget plus the package of economic relief measures which the Government announced on June 22 are gradually filtering through the economy.

"At the same time, the series of measures to ease unemployment announced recently by the Task Force on Employment are also taking effect.

Indeed, some measures have been fully implemented, such as strengthening the Labour Department's Job Matching Programme, and providing a telephone job matching service and vacancy processing service for job-seekers.

The extension of the Non-Means-Tested Loan Scheme to benefit some 61,000 additional tertiary students has also been launched," he said.

"The Government has already advanced 12 public works projects which would lead to the early creation of some 1,600 jobs.

These projects and investment programmes are on course.

We are actively considering the possibility of expediting some more infrastructural projects so that more job opportunities will be available earlier," he added.

The Financial Secretary paid tribute to the Labour Department, the Vocational Training Council(VTC), the Employees Retraining Board(ERB) and other training bodies for their unstinting and continuous efforts in helping the unemployed re-enter the labour market through placement service, training, retraining and skills upgrading.

The number of job-seekers who have successfully found jobs through the Labour Department's Local Employment Service has been steadily rising from 2,540 in April to 2,980 in May, and to 3,540 in June this year.

The nine-month Certificate of Skills Training(Service Industries) Course to be jointly run by the VTC and the ERB for 1,000 unemployed has met with enthusiastic response.

Some 4,000 applications were received by close of application on July 15.

The course will start in mid-September.

Applications will also be received this week for admission to a special training programme for seafarers to be mounted jointly by the VTC and ERB.

The course is targeted at the unemployed.

In the meantime, ERB is stepping up its efforts in developing special tailor-made retraining programmes for the unemployed.

Such programmes are targetted at employers of small and medium enterprises.

The Government will put to the Finance Committee of the Legislative Council before the end of July a $2 billion special scheme to help Small and Medium Enterprises.

This will help secure employment in this important sector.

The survey for March - May 1998 covered a quarterly sample of some 23,900 households or 78,700 persons, selected in accordance with a scientifically designed sampling scheme to represent the land-based civilian non-institutional population in Hong Kong.

Data on labour force characteristics were obtained from the survey by interviewing each member aged 15 and over in the households sampled.

In the survey, the definitions used in measuring unemployment and underemployment follow closely those recommended by the International Labour Organisation.

Being 'seasonally adjusted' refers to the fact that unemployment rate has been adjusted for seasonal variations in the proportion of first-time job-seekers in the labour force.

Detailed analysis of labour force characteristics is given in the report on the General Household Survey which is published four times a year.

19990517_014.e:
Employment opportunities increase in construction sector

The provisional seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for the period February - April 1999 was 6.3 per cent, and the provisional underemployment rate was 2.8 per cent, according to the latest labour force statistics released today (Monday) by the Census and Statistics Department.

For the period January - March 1999, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate and underemployment rate were confirmed to be the same as the previously released provisional figures of 6.2 per cent and 3.0 per cent respectively.

Comparing the period February - April 1999 with January - March 1999, increases in unemployment rate were seen mainly in decoration and maintenance and the wholesale/retail trades, while decreases were seen in the transport and real estate sectors.

As to the underemployment rate, decreases were seen in the construction and transport sectors, more than offsetting the increase seen in restaurants.

For the period January - March 1999, the size of the total labour force was 3,439,600, of whom 3,226,300 were employed and 213,300 were unemployed.

In the same period, the number of underemployed persons was 104,400.

For the period February - April 1999, the size of the total labour force was provisionally estimated at 3,441,000, while the number of unemployed persons and underemployed persons were provisionally estimated at 216,000 and 98,000 respectively.

Mr K Y Tang, the Government Economist, observed that the unemployment rate, though risen further, showed some tapering most recently.

While the unemployment rates in several sectors continued to rise, those in some other sectors fell.

Concurrently, the underemployment rate, after remaining stable in the early part of this year, tended to decline.

Speaking at a press briefing today, the Secretary for Education and Manpower, Mr Joseph W P Wong, called on the unemployed not to lose heart as there were still vacancies for individual positions.

The Local Employment Services of the Labour Department was able to secure about 12,000 job vacancies in April and over 3,300 persons found jobs through this service during the month.

The Interactive Employment Services launched in March continued to gain in popularity, and the cumulative number of web surfers visiting the website has exceeded 190,000.

On the tourism front, total arrivals for April increased by 11 per cent over the same month in 1998.

The number of arrivals from our neighbours such as South Korea, Thailand, the Mainland and Japan has shown encouraging increases.

At the same time, hotel room occupancy rate improved to 80 per cent from 76 per cent in April 1998.

"A number of major infrastructural projects will commence work in the next few months, creating over 7,000 new jobs," Mr Wong said.

These projects include infrastructural works in Kam Tin, Yuen Long and Tuen Mun in connection with the KCRC West Rail, the Castle Peak Hospital Redevelopment, the Shatin Government Offices Building and the Public Health Laboratory Centre.

To prepare for the increasing demand for construction workers generated by the major infrastructural projects in the next 18 months, the Construction Industry Training Authority (CITA) has increased its training capacity for adult trainees on its full time short courses from 2,314 in the 1997/1998 training year to 4,163 in the 1998/1999 training year.

The employment prospects of the graduates of various short courses have increased alongside with the increase in training places.

Over 90 per cent of the craftsmanship/operative graduates were able to secure employment within three months of their graduation.

Over 90 per cent of the bar bending graduates found jobs at a wage of about $600 per day and over 95 per cent of the graduates of the recently introduced Construction Labour Course, requiring only 2 weeks training, were able to secure employment at an average wage of $350 per day.

The CITA plans to further increase its training capacity for short courses by 1,500 places during the 1999/2000 training year.

"The Government will work closely with the Construction Industry Training Authority to train up more local workers to meet the expected demand in the construction sector," Mr Wong noted.

In the survey, the definitions used in measuring unemployment and underemployment follow closely those recommended by the International Labour Organisation.

19991019_014.e:
Unemployment rate continues to stabilise

The provisional seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for July - September 1999 was 6.1 per cent, and the provisional underemployment rate was 3.1 per cent, according to the latest labour force statistics released today (Tuesday) by the Census and Statistics Department.

For June - August 1999, both the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate and the underemployment rate were confirmed to be the same as the previously released provisional figures of 6.1 per cent and 2.9 per cent respectively.

Comparing July - September 1999 with June - August 1999, increases in unemployment rate were observed in decoration and maintenance, transport, wholesale trade and hotels, offsetting the decreases seen in communications and business services.

As to the underemployment rate, increases occurred mainly in manufacturing, decoration and maintenance, restaurants and transport.

For June - August 1999, the size of the total labour force was 3,468,500, of whom 3,247,900 were employed and 220,600 were unemployed.

In the same period, the number of underemployed persons was 102,000.

For July - September 1999, the size of the total labour force was provisionally estimated at 3,459,000, within which, 3,235,000 were employed persons and 224,000 were unemployed persons.

The corresponding figure for underemployed persons was 109,000.

The Government Economist, Mr K Y Tang, noted that while the entry of fresh graduates and school leavers into the labour market in recent months had caused the total number of unemployed persons to rise, indications were that some of the graduates and school leavers continued to be absorbed by the jobs available.

As to the increase in the numbers underemployed, a relevant factor was the work disruption consequential to the rainy weather, particularly in the construction sector.

Speaking at a press briefing today, the Secretary for Education and Manpower, Mr Joseph W P Wong, said that employment prospects have continued to improve in the labour market.

In September, the Labour Department secured 14,000 vacancies and successfully found jobs for over 4,200 job seekers, both figures representing record high levels during the past 14 months.

From January to September 1999, the Department has helped 32,000 people find jobs, representing a 29 per cent increase over the corresponding period last year.

Around 4,000 or 73 per cent of the graduates who have completed full-time retraining courses provided by the Employees' Retraining Board have successfully found a job in April and May 1999.

This placement rate compared favourably to 70 per cent placement rate in the corresponding period last year.

Some of the recently introduced tailor-made courses such as property attendants, assistant hair stylists and knitwear sewing have achieved placement rates of over 90 per cent.

"Looking ahead, it is estimated that some 65,000 jobs will be created in the next fifteen months as a result of Government's major initiatives, infrastructural projects and other public works programme items in the next fifteen months," Mr Wong said.

Major infrastructural and public work projects that will be carried out in the next six months include the road and wetland development in Tin Shui Wai, redevelopment of Kowloon Hospital and Caritas Medical Centre, West Rail Phase I, etc.

These projects will create some 12,000 new job opportunities.

"In addition to the major infrastructural programme, many other initiatives announced in the Chief Executive's 1999 Policy Address, including the substantial investment in environmental improvement, will bring about further new job opportunities," Mr Wong said.

Meanwhile, the Youth Pre-employment Training Programme is progressing smoothly.

Up to mid October, 220 courses have been or are being held and some 4,000 trainees are undergoing training provided by the Youth Pre-employment Training Programme.

The workplace attachment phase of the Programme will start in late October.

Some 12,000 workplace attachment places have been secured from over 500 organisations.

19990419_010.e:
New training programmes in areas of employment growth

The provisional seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for the period January - March 1999 was 6.2 per cent, and the provisional underemployment rate was 3.0 per cent, according to the latest labour force statistics released today (Monday) by the Census and Statistics Department.

For the period December 1998 - February 1999, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate and underemployment rate were confirmed to be the same as the previously released provisional figures of 6.0 per cent and 3.0 per cent respectively.

Comparing the period January - March 1999 with December 1998 - February 1999, increases in unemployment rate occurred mainly in the construction, wholesale/retail trade, restaurants and hotels, and communications sectors.

As to the underemployment rate, decreases were seen in the decoration and maintenance and the transport sectors, offsetting the increase in the manufacturing sector.

For the period December 1998 - February 1999, the size of the total labour force was 3,444,800, of whom 3,238,000 were employed and 206,800 were unemployed.

In the same period, the number of underemployed persons was 103,500.

For the period January - March 1999, the size of the total labour force was provisionally estimated at 3,445,000, while the number of unemployed persons and underemployed persons were provisionally estimated at 214,000 and 105,000 respectively.

Mr K Y Tang, the Government Economist, explained that the latest rise in unemployment rate was partly due to further downsizing in the corporate sector and lay-off of temporary and casual workers by some companies after the Lunar New Year period.

At the same time, a larger number of females previously not working had entered the labour market to seek jobs conceivably for supporting family income, thereby boosting the overall labour supply.

Mr Tang observed that the increase in unemployment rate in the construction sector was partly due to the completion of several major residential development projects in the private sector.

In respect of the retail trade and restaurants, the increase in unemployment rate was attributable to lower business turnover which usually came about after the Lunar New Year period.

Mr Tang pointed out that the unemployment rate as a lagging indicator of economic activity was likely to remain at a relatively high level in the near term.

Yet some positive signs conducive to improvement in economic conditions had emerged in recent months, including notably the easing in bank liquidity and interest rates, and the rebound in share and property prices.

The measures in the Financial Secretary's latest Budget should also provide a boost.

Speaking at a press briefing today, the Secretary for Education and Manpower, Mr Joseph W P Wong, stressed that the Government would continue with its efforts to help the unemployed to re-enter the labour market.

"Many new job opportunities will come on stream when major infrastructural projects take off later this year.

The demand for construction workers in particular will increase," Mr Wong said.

Major public works projects scheduled to commence in the next six months include the Government Quarters at Fanling, the maintenance depot for the Drainage Services Department and Water Supplies Department at Lantau, the Public Health Laboratory Centre, the Shatin Government Offices Building, the customs building in container port area in Kwai Chung, the Castle Peak Hospital redevelopment, the Tseung Kwan O port development, the drainage and river training works in Fanling and Sheung Shui, and the Aberdeen, Ap Lei Chau and Pok Fu Lam sewerage works.

Together they will create about 5,000 new jobs.

"As regards the capital market, small and medium enterprises should benefit from the improvement measures proposed for the Special Financial Scheme and find it easier to secure bank loans to tie over temporary liquidity problems," Mr Wong remarked.

The Government recently completed a review of the scheme and recommended measures which aimed at encouraging lending institutions to make more use of the Scheme.

The recommendations will be considered by the Finance Committee shortly.

During the last month, an additional 244 applications involving a total loan amount of $205 million were approved under the Special Finance Scheme.

Since August 1998 when the Scheme was first launched, some $1.6 billion have been injected into the capital market, benefiting 1,300 small and medium enterprises.

"Meanwhile, the efforts we have made in improving our employment services and helping the unemployed re-enter the work force are bearing results," Mr Wong said.

In March, the Department secured 13,000 job vacancies, an increase of 93% over the number secured in February.

The number of successful placements had also exceeded 3,500.

"The interactive "Employment Website" launched on 11 March 1999 has proven to be highly popular as well as effective.

I am delighted with this significant improvement in our employment services which has enabled us to assist a wider spectrum and a greater number of job-seekers," Mr Wong remarked.

On another front, the training bodies are actively reviewing existing training programmes and developing new ones in areas of potential employment growth.

On the basis of market demand, the Employees Retraining Board is planning new full time courses for information technology assistants, Chinese medicine dispensers, shoe-making workers as well as certificate programmes on China trade.

The information technology assistant course has already started last week.

The rest of the new courses will commence within the next two to three months.

The first phase of these new courses will provide training places to over a hundred trainees.

The Vocational Training Council is also realigning its training efforts to respond to the current and future needs of the economy.

For example, it will upgrade the training and development centres for information technology and financial services, which currently provide training to over 20,000 trainees every year.

It will also update its training for in-service workers to keep pace with technological developments and the demand for a multi-skilled workforce.
