Photo 2: Mrs Betty Tung (third from left), wife of the Chief Executive; Mr David Lan (second from left), Secretary for Home Affairs; and Mr Paul Leung (fourth from left), Director of Leisure and Cultural Services, officiated at today's (March 10) opening ceremony of the "2000 Hong Kong Flower Show".
19990108_011.e:
1999 Hong Kong Kong Flower Show launched today

The following is issued on behalf of the 1999 Hong Kong Flower Show Organising Committee:

A wide variety of cosmopolitan blossoms and exotic plants will be on display in March at Sha Tin Park and Sha Tin Town Hall during the 1999 Hong Kong Flower Show.

Jointly presented by the Provisional Regional Council and the Provisional Urban Council, the 1999 Hong Kong Flower Show, the 13th of its kind, will be held between March 12 and 21.

Speaking at the launching ceremony of the Show today (Friday), the Chairman of the Provisional Regional Council, Mr Lau Wong-fat noted that the theme of this year's Show is 'Bouncing Rabbits Blooming Blossoms' and Cyclamen persicum (alias Rabbit's ear) has been selected as the theme flower to tie in with the Year of the Rabbit, symbolizing a lively and energetic year to come.

"It is hoped that with the dynamic spirit of the rabbit, the economic downturn over the year can be put to an end and Hong Kong will soon be back on the road to growth and prosperity, " Mr Lau said.

"The Show has been growing in popularity since its debut in 1987 and has become a major annual international event.

Last year, the Show attracted over 460,000 visitors, " Mr Lau added.

Mr Lau said that local and overseas organisations have been invited to participate in the Show and a variety of fringe activities including horticultural seminar, floral arrangement demonstration, band concert, drawing competition and photographic competition will also be organised to provide visitors with an exceptionally enjoyable time.

Also addressing the ceremony, the Chairman of the Provisional Urban Council, Dr Ronald Leung Ding-bong said that in the previous Flower Shows, open competitions had been very popular among members of the public and there would be no exception this year.

There will be 16 competitive sections with 92 classes of exhibits this year.

Dr Leung reminded interested horticultural lovers to observe the entry deadline on January 31 so as to share with the public their horticultural experience and the exquisite end-products of their meticulous cultivation.

On display at the show will be special floral and landscape displays by horticultural organisations and government departments, as well as unique floral exhibits flown in from overseas by airline companies.

Commercial stalls will be set up to sell flowers, plants and horticultural products during the Show period.

To provide a better service to the general public, pre-sale service of admission tickets have been arranged from February 28 to March 14 at four KCR East Rail Customer Services Centres in Hung Hom Station, Sha Tin Station, Tai Po Market Station and Sheung Shui Station.

Admission fees of the Show are as follows: $14 each for adults; $7 each for children aged between 4 and 14 and students.

Special concession has been given to senior citizens and people with disabilities to be admitted free of charge from Monday to Friday and $7 each on Saturday and Sunday.

This year's theme flower, Cyclamen persicum, is a lovely flowering plant with vivid appeals.

Its flowers are elegant and sharp.

They appear to dance on the silver-green leaves which draw on people's attention.

As its popularity is growing fast in recent years, many nursed and hybrid species with flowers of peach red, scarlet and dual colours (e.g. white/red) are available.

20000211_003.e:
FEHD blitz operations to ensure food hygiene

The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) mounted a blitz operation in Mong Kok today (Friday) against improper handling of food items by delivery workers.

The Mong Kok District Environmental Hygiene Superintendent, Mr Yeung Shun-kui said: "Our health inspectors conducted surprise inspections to some 20 food shops selling snacks and cooked food in the district early this morning to check whether delivery workers of food suppliers had properly handled the food items.

"We found that four of these shops, three in Dundas Street and one in Bute Street, had food items placed on the pavement in front of the shops, unattended, posing great health risk to customers.

"The food items included bean curd, 'pig blood' pudding, fish balls, fish meat and soya bean juice," he said.

All the food items, weighing 145 kilogrammes, were seized under Section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance.

One of the delivery workers was located and summonsed for failing to protect food from risk of contamination.

Warnings were also given to some shop operators against improper handling of food items.

Mr Yeung noted: "Under Section 10 of the Food Business Regulation, it is an offence for those engaged in food business to place any open food as to involve any risk of contamination or to wrap up or bring any open food into direct contact with any printed newspaper, unclean paper or wrapping material.

"Upon conviction, the maximum penalty is a fine of $10,000 and an imprisonment of three months plus a daily fine of $300."

Meanwhile, blitz operations are continuing in Mong Kok against unlicensed food shops selling snacks and cooked food.

Mr Yeung said: "Since January 10, 36 summary arrests were made against the unlicensed operators who were later charged with the offences of operating unlicensed food factories and exposing food to risk of contamination."

During a series of operations, a total of 468 kilogrammes of exposed cooked food were seized.

Among the 36 prosecutions so far, 25 of them had already been heard and sentenced in court.

The average fine of operating unlicensed food factories imposed is $3,000 while that of exposing food to risk of contamination is $1,000.

He stressed that FEHD would continue to take stringent enforcement actions against unhygienic food handlers and unlicensed food shops to safeguard public health and environmental hygiene.
19990305_027.e:
USD blitz operations against unlicensed food businesses

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

The Urban Services Department will step up law enforcement actions against operators of unlicensed food premises selling cooked food and snacks in the urban area.

A spokesman for the Department said today (Friday), "Recently, there has been concern over a proliferation of small food factories selling snacks and cooked food in sub-divided shop units which are mostly unlicensable.

Their hygiene standards are poor, tenancies are short and proprietors often change."

"Also, there have even been cases that 'cooked food hawkers' operate on private vacant building sites," he said.

The spokesman said that because of the transient nature of these businesses, the existing enforcement actions by way of summons and application for court orders might not be effective.

Therefore, in addition to normal proceedings and applications for Prohibition Order or Closure Order, USD will mount blitz summary arrest operations, starting next week, against operators of these types of food business, aiming at arresting any person on the spot, charging and bringing them to court as soon as possible.

"These operations will be carried out every day and such unlicensed food shops may be raided consecutively for a number of days," he said.

The maximum penalty for operating unlicensed food business is a fine of $50,000, an imprisonment of six months and a daily fine of $900.
19991125_007.e:
USD blitz operations against unlicensed food shops

The Urban Services Department has stepped up law enforcement action against operators of unlicensed food factories selling cooked food and snacks in urban blackspots, aiming at bringing them to court as soon as possible.

A spokesman for the Department said today (Thursday) that blitz summary arrest operations against these operators were launched today in the urban area, resulting in the arrest of three operators.

They were charged with the offences of operating unlicensed food factories and exposing food to risk of contamination.

A total of 80 kilograms of cooked food exposed to risk of contamination were also seized for disposal under Section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance, Cap 132.

Recently, there has been a proliferation of small scale food factories selling snacks and cooked food in sub-divided shop units.

Most of these premises are not qualified for a food licence and their hygiene standards are poor.

"Very often, their tenancies are short and proprietors change frequently, making prosecution action difficult to stop this illegal food business," the spokesman said.

To speed up the prosecution procedures and the application for prohibition and closure orders, arrest actions were taken in addition to normal prosecution by summonses.

As a result, the defendants can be taken to court in a couple of days.

The maximum penalty for operating unlicensed food premises is a fine of $50,000, an imprisonment of six months and a daily fine of $900.

"Besides, USD health inspectors will also take stringent enforcement action against improper storage of open food in these food premises," the spokesman said.

Under the Food Business (Urban Council) By-laws, those who are convicted of improper storage of cooked food are subject to a maximum fine of $10,000, an imprisonment of three months plus a daily fine of $300.

"USD will continue to step up blitz operations against unlicensed and unhygienic food premises to ensure public health and safety," the spokesman stressed.
20000128_012.e:
Blitz operations against unlicensed food shops continued

The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) is determined to stem out unlicensed food factories selling snacks and cooked food to ensure public health and environmental hygiene.

The Yau Tsim Mong District Senior Superintendent, Mr Wong Siu-wing said today (Friday): "In view of the increased number of shoppers in the run-up to Lunar New Year, a new round of blitz operations are launched against these unlicensed operators in Mong Kok and Yau Tsim districts.

"In addition to daytime operations, we will also conduct raids in the late evenings to crack down on these illegal food factories.

"Summary arrests will be made against the unlicensed operators while open food exposed to risk of contamination will be seized under Section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance, Cap 132."

During the first round of raids mounted earlier in Mong Kok, 21 operators were arrested and charged with the offences of operating unlicensed food factories and exposing food to risk of contamination.

In addition, six operators of licensed food premises were summonsed for sale of cooked food exposed to risk of contamination.

A total of 315 kilogrammes of exposed food were seized.

Mr Wong called on members of the public to cooperate with the Department by not patronising these unlicensed food shops for the benefit of their own health.
19991130_004.e:
Stepped up actions against unlicensed food factories

The Urban Services Department has mounted blitz operations against unlicensed food factories selling cooked food and snacks in a vacant site in Causeway Bay to safeguard public health and food safety.

A spokesman for the Department said today (Tuesday) that it has come to the department's attention that the vacant site situated at Russell Street opposite Times Square had been turned into a flea market and opened for business since last Sunday.

Among the stalls, 22 were found operating in the some 560-square-meter site, selling cooked food and snacks such as fish balls, cuttlefish, dim sum and pork intestine.

In the last two days, special summary arrest operations were mounted, resulting in the arrest of 12 operators who were later charged with running food factories without a licence.

Under the Food Business (Urban Council) By-laws, the maximum penalty for operating unlicensed food premises is a fine of $50,000, an imprisonment of six months and a daily fine of $900.

"We will not tolerate the existence of such unlicensed food factories and will continue our enforcement actions until all these illegal premises have stopped business, " the spokesman said.

Meanwhile, as a result of the blitz summary arrest operations, launched in urban blackspots between November 25 and 27, USD has arrested 12 operators for running unlicensed food premises and three for breaching prohibition order.

Some 150 kilograms of cooked food exposed to risk of contamination were seized for disposal.
20000225_007.e:
Two unlicensed food factory operators arrested in Mong Kok

The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) continued its blitz operations in Mong Kok this (Friday) afternoon against unlicensed food factories selling snacks and cooked food.

Today's operation, led by Senior Health Inspector Mr Lee Tse-wah, resulted in the arrest of two operators who were later charged with running an unlicensed food factory and breaching prohibition order respectively.

In addition, two operators of licensed food factories were summonsed for exposing food to risk of contamination.

About 50 kilogrammes of open food were seized under Section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance, Cap 132.

Mr Lee said: "To safeguard public health and maintain environmental hygiene, we have stepped up enforcement action since January this year by carrying out daily summary arrest operations against illegal food factories selling snacks and cooked food in the district."

Since January 10, 45 summary arrests have been made against operators of unlicensed food factories in Mong Kok while a total of 573 kilogrammes of exposed food were seized.

Among the 45 prosecutions so far, 38 of them had already been heard and convicted in court.

The average fine of operating unlicensed food factories imposed is $3,000 while that of exposing food to risk of contamination is $1,000.

"The Department will continue to launch stringent summary arrest operations against unlicensed food factories in the district until the situation has improved," Mr Lee added.
19980821_003.e:
USD takes action against cholera

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

The Urban Services Department (USD) has stepped up measures to help prevent the spread of cholera.

A Department spokesman said today (Friday) that these measures included increasing the frequency of inspections to restaurants and food premises and stepping up prosecution actions against irregularities found on these premises.

Such irregularities included storing food in open space and preparing food on the pavement in front of their shops.

For the sake of public health, the Department has also taken stringent enforcement actions against unlicensable food premises by summary arrest operations and increased raids against illegal hawkers selling cooked food and restricted food, in particular, shellfish, non-bottled drinks and Siu Mei and Lo Mei.

USD today completed the first round of inspection to 1,405 licensed food premises of grade C under the Departments selective inspection system.

Forty-eight of them were prosecuted for, among other things, exposing food in open space, preparing food on the pavement at shop fronts, failing to keep the food room clean and causing obstructions in public places.

During the period between August 14 and 21, USD had arrested 43 unlicensed hawkers selling cooked food and restricted food and taken out 47 summonses against unlicensable food premises for operating without a licence.

The Department had also carried out 12 summary arrest operations in the urban area and arrested eight operators of unlicensable food premises for unlicensed operation.

The spokesman said that to further improve hygiene in food premises, the Department would conduct another round of blitz operations from August 24 to September 19.

The operations will cover all licensed food premises of grade B and C, cooked food stalls in markets, hawker bazaars and public housing estates, and all unlicensed food premises including those applying for licence.

Apart from giving advice on food, personal and environmental hygiene in preventing cholera, USD health inspectors will during the inspection focus on inadequate cooking of seafood, cross-contamination of raw and cooked food and inadequate reheating of food.

"USD will not tolerate such unhygienic practices by food premises and will prosecute the operators to safeguard public health," the spokesman said.
19991104_004.e:
Blitz operations stepped up against cooked food exposure

The Urban Services Department has stepped up enforcement action in Mong Kok district against exposure of cooked food by food factories selling snacks.

A USD spokesman said today (Thursday) that a series of blitz operations were conducted in the district to prevent further proliferation of unlicensed food factories selling snacks and to ensure the proper storage of cooked food items to safeguard public health.

Last month, nine prosecutions were taken out against food factories selling snacks for display of food without cover.

Another nine prosecutions were also taken out against operators for running unlicensed food factories selling snacks.

All the exposed cooked food found at these premises were seized under section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance, Cap 132.

Under the Food Business (Urban Council) By-laws, those who are convicted of improper storage of cooked food are liable to a maximum fine of $10,000, an imprisonment of three months as well as a daily fine of $300.

Those who operate unlicensed food premises are subject to a maximum fine of $50,000, an imprisonment of six months as well as a daily fine of $900.

"USD will continue to mount blitz operations to safeguard public health and safety," he said.
19980422_006.e:
USD blitz operations against unlicensed food stalls

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

The Urban Services Department (USD) has stepped up law enforcement action operations against unlicensable food factories selling cooked food in the urban areas.

A spokesman for the Department said today (Wednesday) that blitz summary arrest operations were launched on both sides of the harbour today against operators of unlicensable food premises, aiming at prosecuting them as soon as possible.

The first round of the operation is expected to be completed in two weeks, he added.

On the first day of operation, a total of 17 operators of unlicensed food factories selling cooked food were arrested, 15 in Mong Kok, one in Wan Chai and one in Aberdeen.

Upon the conviction of the summary arrest case, the spokesman said, the Department may apply to the court for a Prohibition Order under Section 128 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance against the continued operation of the unlicensed food business.

The maximum penalty for operating unlicensed food businesses is a fine of $50,000, an imprisonment of six months and a daily fine of $900.

Any person who contravenes the Prohibition Order and continues to operate the food business will be prosecuted and is liable to a maximum fine of $100,000, an imprisonment of 12 months plus a daily fine of $1,750.

In a related development, USD executed a Closure Order to physically close down an unlicensed restaurant in Tse Wan Shan.

The restaurant located on the ground floor of Wan Wah Building, 26 Yuk Wah Crescent, Tse Wan Shan had been prosecuted for operating without a licence since September 1994.

Since then, it had a record of 26 convictions and accumulated a total fine of $295,020.

This is the second Closure Order executed by USD within a week since last Friday when an unlicensed restaurant in Kwun Tong was closed down.

The spokesman stressed that to safeguard public health, the Department would not tolerate the operation of unlicensed food businesses and would prosecute the operators.
20000110_005.e:
FEHD blitz operations against unlicensed food shops

The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) launched a blitz operation in Mong Kok today (Monday) against operators of unlicensed food factories selling snacks and cooked food.

The Mong Kok Environmental Hygiene Superintendent, Mr Yeung Shun-kui said: "To safeguard public health and environmental hygiene, blitz summary arrest operations against these operators were launched today in the district, resulting in the arrest of six operators.

They have been charged with the offences of operating unlicensed food factories, breaching prohibition order and exposing food to risk of contamination."

A total of 93 kilogrammes of cooked food exposed to risk of contamination were also seized for disposal under Section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance, Cap 132.

Mr Yeung noted: "Recently, there has been a proliferation of small scale food factories selling snacks and cooked food in sub-divided shop units in Mong Kok district without a licence.

"Most of these premises are not qualified for a food licence because of poor hygiene standards.

The food items sold by these premises are not properly covered, posing health hazards to customers.

Besides, unlicensed food businesses also caused environmental nuisance to nearby residents," he added.

He said: "To speed up the prosecution procedures, summary arrest actions were taken against these operators in addition to normal prosecution by summonses.

As a result, the defendants can be taken to court in a couple of days."

In 1999, a total of 112 summary arrests were made and 243 summonses issued in Mong Kok district in relation to unlicensed food shops.

The maximum penalty for operating unlicensed food premises is a fine of $50,000 and an imprisonment of six months plus a daily fine of $900.

Mr Yeung reiterated that the FEHD would continue to take stringent enforcement actions against these illegal food factories until the situation has improved.

"It is our duty to safeguard public health and environmental hygiene," he added.

"Members of the public are urged not to patronise these illegal premises for the benefit of their own health.

They are also encouraged to report such illegal food business to the Department through our hotline 2868 0000."

19980611_010.e:
Students reminded to join Health Education Programme

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Regional Council :

Secondary Two to Four students studying in schools in the New Territories and outlying islands, who intend to join the "Know More about Environmental Hygiene Facilities cum Lifeskill Training Camp", are reminded to submit their applications before the deadline for entry on Wednesday (June 17).

Admission is free.

Organised by the Provisional Regional Council in association with the Education Department, the activity aims to encourage students to make good use of their environmental hygiene facilities and services, and then disseminate the message to their schoolmates, friends and family members.

A spokesman for the Health Education Unit of the Regional Services Department(RSD) said today(Thursday): "I would like to urge students who are interested to participate in the training camp to take their chances and send in their entry forms before Wednesday."

He added: "Entrants have to attend a quiz about the environmental hygiene facilities and services provided by the Council as well as basic food and environmental hygiene.

"Sixty students with highest scores will be invited to visit a number of environmental hygiene facilities and take part in a three-day lifeskill training camp from July 28 to 30.

"Each entrant will receive a souvenir during the quiz."

The spokesman said: "Students who have completed the programme will be awarded a Certificate of Award.

In addition, they can have an opportunity to take part in the Food Hygiene Carnival to be held in February 1999 and other health education activities."

Interested students can obtain programme leaflets and entry forms from their schools.

For enquiries and details, please call the Health Education Unit of the RSD at 2687 5947.
19990728_005.e:
PUC Ambassador of Hygiene Scheme invites entries

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

The Provisional Urban Council (PUC) is now inviting primary and secondary students to submit entries for the 1999/2000 Ambassador of Hygiene Scheme Competition.

The 24-winning students of the Competition will be appointed as "PUC Ambassadors of Hygiene" with the mission to promote food, personal and environmental hygiene in their families and at schools.

They will also be awarded a free study-cum-pleasure trip to Japan during the Christmas holidays in December this year.

During the visit to Japan, they will meet with officials to gain an insight into Japan's hygiene services and facilities, and share with Japanese students on their views in promoting health education in schools.

Upon their return to Hong Kong, they will then share experience with their relatives, friends and fellow students.

Entrants of this year's competition are required to work in pairs and submit a written project on the topic of "Promoting Food Safety into the New Millennium" through their schools on or before October 15, 1999.

In their projects, students should demonstrate their knowledge on food safety and the current monitoring systems on food safety in Hong Kong.

Also, they should propose an action plan on a health education activity to promote food safety in school.

The Competition is divided into three groups, namely Primary Group (P.5 to P.6), Junior Secondary Group (F.1 to F.3) and Senior Secondary Group (F.4 to F.6).

Thirty finalists in each of the three groups will be short-listed for a final interview during which a total of 24 winners, eight students from each group, will be selected to win the title and invited to join the PUC Ambassador of Hygiene Club.

The Club, comprising winners of the Competition in the past five years, has from time to time organised different kinds of activities to enhance its members' knowledge on food safety and food hygiene.

Today (Wednesday), some 20 Club members visited the Man Kam To Food Control Centre and were briefed by health inspectors on how chemical and radioactive tests were conducted to ensure vegetables imported from China were free from contamination and suitable for consumption.

The fellow members then continued their visit to a food factory in Tai Po where they saw how lunchboxes were prepared and how factory workers adopted food hygiene practices.

Students who wish to join the Ambassador of Hygiene Scheme Competition can obtain pamphlets at Urban Services Department's district environmental hygiene offices and libraries or call the department's Health Education Unit at 2867 5702 for enquiries.
19990805_011.e:
Health Promoting Students Awarded Certificates

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Regional Council:

The Vice-Chairman of the Provisional Regional Council's Environmental Hygiene Select Committee, Mr Leung Kwong-cheong, today (Thursday) urged students taking part in the Health Promoting School Scheme to play an active role in improving the environmental hygiene condition of Hong Kong.

Mr Leung was speaking at the Certificate Presentation Ceremony of the scheme at the Sai Kung Outdoor Recreation Centre.

Some 60 students who have completed a visit programme to hygiene facilities and a three-day lifeskill training camp were awarded certificates of appreciation.

The scheme was organised by the Provisional Regional Council to enable students to gain in-depth environmental hygiene knowledge through visits and training and to disseminate these messages to schoolmates by organising health promotion activities in their schools.

Mr Leung said: "The students will put what they have learned into practice and organise activities to promote environmental health among their schoolmates during the forthcoming academic year.

"To encourage active participation of the students, the Health Education Unit of the Regional Services Department will arrange a series of follow-up activities to provide further training, expert advice and resources to them," he said.

Also officiating at the ceremony was the Assistant Director (Environmental Health Policy) of the Regional Services Department, Mr Lai Kwok-tung.
19990527_022.e:
Health Promoting School Scheme Invites Participation

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Regional Council:

Secondary Two to Four students studying in schools in the New Territories and outlying islands now have a chance to gain more environmental hygiene knowledge through visits to a number of Provisional Regional Council (Pro RC)'s hygiene facilities and participation in a lifeskill training camp during the summer holiday.

Organised by the Health Education Unit of the Regional Services Department (RSD), the Health Promoting School Scheme is now inviting students to submit their applications before the closing date on June 12.

Admission is free.

A spokesman of the RSD said today (Thursday): "The programme encourages students to make good use of the environmental hygiene facilities, and to disseminate the messages to their schoolmates by organising health promotion activities in their schools with the assistance of the Health Education Unit.

"Entrants have to attend a quiz on June 29 to test their knowledge on environmental hygiene facilities and services provided by the Pro RC as well as basic food and environmental hygiene.

"Sixty students with highest scores will be invited to visit a number of environmental hygiene facilities and take part in a three-day lifeskill training camp at the Sai Kung Outdoor Recreation Centre from August 3 to 5."

The spokesman said: "Those who have completed the visits and the training programme in the camp will receive a Certificate of Award.

In addition, they will be provided with expert advice and resources by the Health Education Unit to organise health promotion activities in their schools during the forthcoming academic year.

Each entrant will receive a set of souvenirs during the quiz."

"Training programme in the camp includes imparting knowledge on food and environmental hygiene as well as lifeskill training such as communication skills, leadership and building up of self-confidence.

"It is expected that through visits and training, participating students will be more aware of the importance of environmental hygiene, be able to understand more about themselves and have their lifeskills further enhanced," the spokesman added.

Leaflets and application forms have already been distributed to the schools.

For details or entry procedures, please contact the Health Education Unit of the RSD at 2691 5681.
19980601_013.e:
Health Education Programme Invites Participation

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Regional Council :

Secondary Two to Four students studying in schools in the New Territories and outlying islands can now have a chance to gain more knowledge on their environmental hygiene facilities and at the same time take part in a challenging lifeskill training camp during this summer holiday.

The "Know More about Environmental Hygiene Facilities cum Lifeskill Training Camp" is now inviting participation and the closing date for entry is June 17, 1998.

Admission is free.

Organised by the Provisional Regional Council in association with the Education Department, the activity is a new health education programme aimed at encouraging students to make good use of their environmental hygiene facilities and service, and then disseminate the message to their schoolmates, friends and family members.

A spokesman for the Health Education Unit of the Regional Services Department (RSD) said today (Monday): "Entrants have to attend a quiz on July 2 to test their knowledge on food and environmental hygiene as well as the environmental hygiene facilities and services provided by the Council.

"Sixty students with highest scores will be invited to visit a number of environmental hygiene facilities and participate in a three-day lifeskill training camp at the Sai Kung Outdoor Recreation Centre from July 28 to 30."

The Spokesman said: "Students who have completed the programme will be issued a Certificate of Award.

Furthermore, they will have an opportunity to take part in the Food Hygiene Carnival to be held in February 1999 and other education activities.

Each entrant will receive a set of souvenirs during the quiz.

"Activities in the training camp include imparting knowledge on basic food and environmental hygiene; lifeskill training such as communication skills, leadership, leading small groups and building up self-confidence.

"It is expected that through visits and training, participating students will be more aware of the importance of environmental hygiene, be able to understand more about themselves and have their lifeskills further enhanced," the spokesman added.

Leaflets and application forms have already been distributed to the schools.

For enquiries or details, please call the Health Education Unit of the RSD at 2687 5947.
19981222_008.e:
PUC Ambassadors of Hygiene appointed

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

Twenty-four outstanding students were appointed as the Provisional Urban Council Ambassadors of Hygiene at a flag and prize presentation ceremony today (Tuesday).

The students, aged between 11 and 18, are winners of the 1998/99 Provisional Urban Council Ambassadors of Hygiene Scheme Competition.

Held for the fifth year, this year's Competition has attracted more than 350 written projects on 'Public health is a public concern' submitted by some 100 schools throughout the territory.

Each submission is prepared by students worked in pairs.

Officiating at today's ceremony, Chairman of the PUC's Public Health Select Committee Mr Joseph Chan Yuek-sut said that the written projects were not only rich in content but also attractive in presentation.

"Many students have undertaken field studies at various PUC venues, some of them even conducted street polls.

They have also demonstrated creativity by making use of songs, stories and games to convey their messages and make their projects as lively as possible."

Another officiating guest, Chairman of the PUC's Health Education Sub-Committee Mr Albert Lai Wing-lin said that the newly-appointed Ambassadors would visit Japan during the forthcoming Lunar New Year holidays in February to study hygiene services and health education activities there, and to exchange views with local students.

"After their return to Hong Kong, the Ambassadors are expected to share their knowledge and experience with their relatives, friends and fellow students and actively take part in the promotion of health education."

The Ambassadors will be invited to join the PUC Ambassador of Hygiene Club to participate in a series of health education activities such as hygiene training camp and visits to voluntary organisations.

Also attending today's ceremony were PUC members Mr Chan Noi-yue and Mr Cheung Yu-yan; Assistant Director (Environmental Health) of Urban Services Mr Po Pui-leong; Senior Staff Officer (Public Health) of the Urban Services Department Mr Tsang Nim-tong; Deputy Chief Inspector of Schools, Advisory Inspectorate Division of the Education Department, Mrs Ip Tsang Chui-hing.

The Scheme is organised by the PUC in association with the Education Department and the Japan National Tourist Organisation.

The visit to Japan is sponsored by the All Nippon Airways Company Limited and the Package Tours (Hong Kong) Limited.
19990605_020.e:
Students reminded to join Health Promoting School Scheme

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Regional Council:

Secondary Two to Four students studying in schools in the New Territories and outlying islands, who intend to join the Health Promoting School Scheme, are reminded to submit their applications before the deadline on June 12.

Organised by the Health Education Unit of the Regional Services Department (RSD), the Scheme offers students a chance to gain more environmental hygiene knowledge through visits to a number of Provisional Regional Council (Pro RC)'s hygiene facilities and participation in a lifeskill training camp.

Admission is free.

The programme encourages students to make good use of the environmental hygiene facilities, and to disseminate the messages to their schoolmates by organising health promotion activities in their schools with the assistance of the Health Education Unit.

A spokesman of the RSD said today (Saturday): "Entrants have to attend a quiz on June 29 to test their knowledge on environmental hygiene facilities and services provided by the Pro RC as well as basic food and environmental hygiene.

Each entrant will receive a set of souvenirs during the quiz.

"Sixty students with highest scores will be invited to visit a number of environmental hygiene facilities and take part in a three-day lifeskill training camp at the Sai Kung Outdoor Recreation Centre from August 3 to 5."

The spokesman said: "Those who have completed the visits and the training programme in the camp will receive a Certificate of Award.

In addition, they will be provided with expert advice and resources by the Health Education Unit to organise health promotion activities in their schools during the forthcoming academic year. "

Interested students can obtain leaflets and application forms from their schools.

For enquiries, please contact the Health Education Unit of the RSD at 2691 5681.
19980710_010.e:
PUC invites students to participate in hygiene competition

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

The Provisional Urban Council (PUC) is now inviting Primary 5 to Form 6 students to participate in its 1998/99 Ambassador of Hygiene Scheme Competition.

The top 24 students emerging from the Competition will be appointed as "PUC Ambassadors of Hygiene" and awarded a free study-cum-pleasure trip to Japan during the Easter holidays in April next year.

A PUC spokesman said today (Friday) that the scheme, held for the fifth year, is an annual health education programme for primary and secondary students.

It is hoped that the students, through their studies leading to the submission of a written project, will gain in-depth knowledge on the importance of public health and health education, participate in health education programmes organised by the Council, and help promote the messages in schools and at home.

Entrants of the 1998/99 Competition are required to work in pairs and submit a written project with the theme "Public Health is a Public Concern" on or before October 30, 1998.

The Competition will be divided into the Primary Group (P.5 to P.6), the Junior Secondary Group (F.1 to F.3) and the Senior Secondary Group (F.4 to F.6).

In the projects, students should demonstrate their knowledge on the facilities and services provided by PUC, especially in the area of public health.

Also, they should suggest ways to improve the Council's existing environmental health facilities and services and propose programmes or activities to promote personal, environmental and food hygiene.

Their work is to be judged according to the content, presentation and creativity of their projects.

Fifteen pairs of finalists from each of the three groups will be short-listed for the final interview.

Four pairs from each group, i.e. a total of 24 students, will then be selected and awarded a visit to Japan, where they will meet officials and students to exchange views on public health promotion.

This year's Provisional Urban Council Ambassador of Hygiene Scheme is organised in association with the Education Department and the Japan National Tourist Organisation, and sponsored by the All Nippon Airways Company Limited and the Package Tours (Hong Kong) Limited.
19981124_011.e:
PUC Ambassador of Hygiene Competition enters final round

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

A panel of judges started interviewing students today (Tuesday) to select 24 1998/99 Provisional Urban Council (PUC) Ambassadors of Hygiene.

The Ambassadors will be awarded an all-expenses-paid visit to Japan during the Lunar New Year holidays next year to study the hygiene services and health education activities there, and exchange views with local students.

A PUC spokesman said, "The Scheme, now in its fifth year, is an annual health education programme for primary and secondary students.

It is hoped that through their studies leading to the submission of a written project, they will gain in-depth knowledge on the importance of public health and health education."

"The Ambassadors are expected to actively take part in health education programmes organised by the PUC and help promote public health messages in their schools and families."

This year's Competition has attracted more than 350 written projects on "Public health is a public concern" submitted by over 100 schools throughout the territory.

Each submission is prepared by students worked in pairs.

The Competition is divided into three groups -- the Primary, Junior Secondary and Senior Secondary.

Writers of 15 submissions from each group, i.e. 90 students, are shortlisted for interviews.

Eight winners will be selected from each group for the appointment of Ambassador of Hygiene.

The Scheme is organised by PUC in association with the Education Department and the Japan National Tourist Organisation, and sponsored by the All Nippon Airways and the Package Tours (Hong Kong) Limited.
19980407_030.e:
Ambassadors of Hygiene set off to Japan

The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

A group of 24 Provisional Urban Council Ambassadors of Hygiene departed for Japan today (Tuesday) with a special mission of exchanging views and experiences with Japanese officials and students on environmental and food hygiene.

The young Ambassadors, aged between 10 to 18, are winners of the 1997/98 PUC Ambassador of Hygiene Scheme Competition in which a record number of 672 students took part.

Led by PUC members Mr Wong King-cheung and Ms Grace Au Yuk-har, the delegation will meet public health officials and students in Japan to exchange views on how to promote health messages in schools and at home.

During their six-day visit, the Ambassadors will visit the Bureau of Public Cleansing, Tokyo Environmental Centre, and Tokyo Food and Residential Hygiene Centre to see environmental health facilities, particularly on refuse collection and waste disposal.

They will also have a chance to present to Japanese students their winning reports entitled "If we are Provisional Urban Council Ambassadors of Hygiene ...".

Upon their return to Hong Kong, the Ambassadors will share their experiences with their friends, schoolmates and family members and actively take part in the promotion of health education.

19990624_010.e:
Memorandum of Understanding between MPFA and SFC

The following is issued on behalf of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority:

The Management Board of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority (MPFA) today (Thursday) endorsed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between the MPFA and the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) concerning their roles in the regulation of MPF products.

At its meeting today, the Board also endorsed the appointment of additional co-opted members to the MPFA's Guidelines Committee, the last two sets of MPF guidelines to facilitate service providers to comply with the MPF legislation, and a timetable for processing of applications for approval.

Hon Charles Lee Yeh-kwong, Chairman of the MPFA, said, "The MOU sets out in broad terms the respective responsibilities of the MPFA and the SFC in the enforcement of the MPFA's 'Code on MPF Investment Funds' and the SFC's 'SFC Code on MPF Products'."

"The MPFA will be responsible for the overall approval of MPF trustees and products and ensuring that the provisions stipulated in the MPF legislation are properly observed.

"The SFC will be responsible for vetting and authorizing the offering documents and marketing materials of MPF products.

It will also be responsible for approving investment managers and continued monitoring of their conduct in the investment management of MPF products," he said.

"The MPFA has worked out a timetable for the processing of applications for approval.

The MPFA and the SFC will work closely together to ensure the proper regulation of MPF products and their operators to safeguard public interest," added Mr. Lee.

The newly appointed members to the Guidelines Committee comprise representatives from The Law Society of Hong Kong, The Hong Kong Retirement Scheme Association and the Hong Kong Society of Accountants respectively.

Mr Lee said, "The appointment of three additional members to the Committee will broaden the consultation base in the preparation of MPF guidelines.

This would help to ensure that the guidelines prepared would adhere to the best industry practice and the requirements of the various professions."

The two sets of guidelines endorsed today are concerned with interface arrangements between existing retirement schemes and the MPF -

(a) Guidelines on MPF Exempted ORSO Schemes - Application for Approval of Appointment of Trustees; and

(b) Guidelines on MPF Exempted ORSO Schemes - Application for Approval of Appointment of Directors of Trustees

Mr Lee said the guidelines would be printed and made available shortly.

He added that the making of guidelines for MPF service providers (37 sets in total) had been completed.

The complete sets of guidelines will be available at the homepage of the MPFA for downloading (http://www.mpfahk.org).

20000406_011.e:
MPF contributions to start on December 1, 2000 as scheduled

The commencement date for MPF contributions should remain unchanged on December 1, 2000 as previously scheduled, members of the MPFA Management Board agreed at a meeting today (April 6).

The MPFA Chairman, the Hon.

Charles Lee Yeh-kwong, said the MPFA had reviewed the readiness of the community, the industry and the MPFA itself and the conclusion was that all the parties concerned would be ready for the full implementation of the MPF System in December 2000.

The MPFA will recommend to the Executive Council on the commencement date and will propose to bring into effect all the other legislative provisions necessary for the smooth operation of the MPF System.

"Our economy is rebounding steadily from the economic downturn caused by the Asian financial turmoil.

Assuming the economic recovery will continue as forecast, the economy would have experienced seven consecutive quarters of positive growth by the time when the MPF contributions start," said Mr. Lee.

Addressing the concern about the impact on the operating costs of the business sectors, the Chairman expected that most employers would be able to make suitable adjustments to their cost structures to absorb the impact by adopting more efficient production techniques and management practices.

And with 45 master trust schemes comprising 253 constituent funds available in the market, Mr. Lee believed that there were adequate choices in both service providers and MPF products for employers, employees and self-employed persons.

On the MPFA's readiness, the Board was confident that it would be fully ready to perform its regulatory functions by December this year.

The MPFA has put in place an effective regulatory framework for both MPF schemes and MPF intermediaries together with the other financial regulators in Hong Kong, namely the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the Securities and Futures Commission and the Insurance Authority.

It has established working relationships with the Department of Justice and the Police as part of its preparatory work for undertaking law enforcement actions after the launching of the MPF System.

On the public education front, the MPFA has started a multi-facet campaign with the assistance of various Government bureaux and departments to raise public awareness and understanding of the MPF System and pave the way for the smooth implementation of the System by December.

A territory-wide operation will be conducted in June to reach out to more than 50,000 shops in 18 districts.

Shop owners will be given a package of publicity materials to help them understand the MPF System.

By mid-August, the MPFA will join hands with the Trade Development Council to mount a large-scale exhibition at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre, bringing together all major MPF service providers to display their products.

Board members were also updated on the latest progress of the processing of MPF exemption applications from employers operating retirement schemes under the Occupational Retirement Schemes Ordinance.

As at April 5, the MPFA received a total of 2,129 such applications for schemes covering 112,000 employees.

It is expected that there will be a surge of applications in the run-up to the May 3 deadline.
19990309_020.e:
MPF contribution date set on December 1, 2000

The Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority (MPFA) has decided to set December 1, 2000 as the target date for commencing MPF contributions.

The Executive Council was informed of the MPF implementation timetable at its meeting today (Tuesday).

Chairman of the MPFA, Mr Charles Lee Yeh-kwong, said: "To achieve the target of launching MPF on December 1, 2000, one of MPFA's most important tasks is to conduct the licensing exercise in the second half of this year.

This will include the approval of trustees and investment products and the registration of provident fund schemes."

According to the timetable, the MPFA will receive formal applications for licensing in August this year and complete vetting of all licensing applications by year end.

This should leave sufficient time for employers to apply for MPF exemption in respect of eligible schemes governed by the Occupational Retirement Schemes Ordinance (ORSO).

The MPFA will receive exemption applications from January 3, 2000 to May 3, 2000 and aim to complete vetting of all the applications before July 2000.

The timetable also allows an 11-month period for employers to enrol their staff into MPF schemes before the commencement of contributions in December 2000.

Mr Lee said, "The implementation timetable was based on the results of a recent progress review of the necessary preparatory work and extensive consultation with the industry, employer groups as well as the MPF Schemes Advisory Committee.

"The overall progress of the preparatory work has been satisfactory.

We believe that the timetable is realistic and should be achievable by all parties concerned."

He added that since the launching of MPF would affect many parties including the industry, employers and employees, the MPFA would monitor closely all aspects of the preparatory work, particularly the development of the MPFA's Information Management System, and keep the implementation timetable under constant review.

At its meeting this morning, the Executive Council endorsed a Commencement Notice which will bring into effect further provisions in the MPF Schemes Ordinance, enabling the MPFA to make financial arrangements for its operation as from March 12, 1999, commence the licensing exercise on August 3, 1999 and start processing exemption applications of ORSO schemes from MPF requirements from January 3, 2000.

The Executive Council also endorsed the making of the MPF Schemes (Fees) Regulation which will be submitted to the Legislative Council for approval shortly.

In the light of the current economic situation, the MPFA proposed in the Fees Regulation not to charge the annual registration fee of MPF schemes for the first two years and to fix the applications fees on the basis of comparable fees charged by other financial services regulators.

END/Tuesday, March 9, 1999
20000103_012.e:
Application for MPF exemption for ORSO Schemes starts today

The following is issued on behalf of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority:

The Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority (MPFA) announced that starting today (Monday), Occupational Retirement Schemes (ORSO schemes) can submit applications for MPF exemption.

There are currently about 19,800 ORSO schemes governed by the Occupational Retirement Schemes Ordinance (ORS Ordinance).

These schemes cover about 940,000 employees which constitute approximately one-third of the workforce.

The MPF legislation has set out the arrangements for the interface of ORSO schemes with the new MPF system and has specified the criteria required for exemption.

For an ORSO scheme which is registered under the ORS Ordinance to be exempted, it must:

* be governed by trust;

* be established on or before October 15, 1995, and

* have lodged its application for exemption or registration under the ORS Ordinance with the Registrar of Occupational Retirement Schemes on or before January 15, 1996.

The Hon Charles Lee Yeh-kwong, Chairman of the MPFA, said, "About 14,000 of the existing ORSO schemes are eligible for MPF exemption.

Employers of these schemes should make decision as soon as possible whether to apply for MPF exemption."

"The deadline for lodging application is May 3, 2000.

The MPFA will process applications once they are submitted and we will notify the applicants of the results by the end of July 2000" added Mr Lee.
19991007_007.e:
Regulation of MPF Intermediaries

The following is issued on behalf of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority:

The Management Board of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority (MPFA) endorsed at its meeting today (Thursday) a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) Concerning the Regulation of MPF Intermediaries to be signed among the Monetary Authority (MA), the Insurance Authority (IA), the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) and the MPFA.

Chairman of the MPFA, Hon.

Charles Lee Yeh-kwong, said, "The MOU to be signed among the four regulators sets out in broad terms their respective responsibilities in the enforcement of the Code of Conduct for MPF Intermediaries, and other related matters concerning the regulation of MPF intermediaries."

"The MPFA will act as the lead regulator and co-ordinator, and rely on the SFC, the IA and the MA for the licensing and supervision of MPF intermediaries.

An MPF Intermediaries Regulation Co-ordinating Committee has been set up to co-ordinate the regulation of MPF intermediaries among the regulators, " he added.

All MPF intermediaries must be qualified under one or more of the existing regulatory regimes, namely, the SFC regime, the IA regime and the MA regime.

MPF intermediaries who intend to give advice on both securities and insurance policies will need to comply with the licensing requirements of both the SFC and IA regimes.

They are also required to pass an MPF intermediaries examination recognized by the MPFA.

The MPFA has also begun the registration of MPF intermediaries.

MPF intermediaries cards will be issued to registered MPF intermediaries with clear identification of their qualification.

A register of registered MPF intermediaries will be made available to the public for inspection.

As at the end of September, more than 8,000 persons have passed the MPF intermediaries examination.

Mr Lee urged the service providers to submit their applications for MPF intermediaries cards to the MPFA as early as possible, so that the MPFA could issue the cards to the intermediaries before February 2000, when the approved service providers would be permitted to start marketing approved MPF products.

Mr Lee also announced that the MPFA had worked out a tendering timetable for the MPF Industry Schemes.

"We will start inviting all the approved corporate trustees to submit applications for registration of Industry Schemes in November this year, " said Mr Lee.

"Our plan is to complete the tendering exercise by March 2000 to allow sufficient time for the selected scheme operators to prepare for marketing and enrolment," he added.

The following is a timetable for the registration of MPF Industry Schemes:

Major Issues Schedule

Submission of applications First week of November 1999

Deadline for submission of November 30, 1999

applications

Review of applications December 1999 - February 2000

Announcement of selection March 2000

results

Setting up of the Industry March/April 2000

20000203_006.e:
MPFA Set Out Objectives and Tasks For 2000-2001

The Management Board of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority (MPFA) endorsed at its meeting today (Thursday) the MPFA Corporate Plan 2000-2001 and proposed amendments to the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes (General) Regulation.

Programmes and activities outlined in the MPFA Corporate Plan 2000 - 2001 were constructed with the mission and target of the MPFA in mind.

"Our mission is to ensure the provision of retirement protection for Hong Kong's workforce and our target is to implement the MPF System in December.

Everybody in the MPFA is devoted to work towards this mission and target," said The Hon.

Charles Lee Yeh-kwong.

During the year 2000-2001, the MPFA will continue to perform its function as the registration authority and the regulator of ORSO schemes and MPF schemes.

It will set up the Industry Schemes Committee in April after the tendering results of the Industry Schemes are announced in March.

The MPFA will complete the approval of the first batch of pooled investment funds, the processing of MPF exemption of ORSO schemes and registration of first batch of employer sponsored schemes by 31 July 2000.

To ensure a smooth implementation of the MPF System, the MPFA will carry out its Public Education & Publicity Campaign in full swing in order to raise public awareness and acceptance of the MPF System.

Apart from launching media advertisement, exhibitions, seminars and promotional activities, the MPFA will conduct various exercises to reach out to tens of thousands of shops and business establishments.

Temporary local enquiry points will be set up at regional offices of the Labour Department and District Offices later in the year to handle public enquiries.

The Management Board also endorsed the proposed amendments to the MPF Schemes (General) Regulation at the meeting.

The amendments include redefining terms used in the Regulation and providing further clarifications to certain technical aspects.

The purpose of these amendments is to clarify a number of issues concerning the operation of the MPF system and the interpretation of the Regulation in order to ensure smooth operation of the MPF system and proper protection of scheme members' interests.

END/Thursday, February 3, 2000
20000302_025.e:
MPF Exemption Applications Update

Four hundred employers who are offering retirement schemes for their employees on a voluntary basis have submitted applications to the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority (MPFA) for MPF exemption, members of the MPFA Management Board were told today (Thursday).

As at last Friday (February 25, 2000), the MPFA has received a total of 331 MPF exemption applications for schemes covering 23,000 employees.

"We learned that three out of the 331 schemes are large schemes with a total of about 15,000 members, while 90 per cent of the rest are schemes with less than 50 members," the Hon.

Charles Lee Yeh-kwong, Chairman of the MPFA said.

In vetting the documents, the MPFA noted that only 1 scheme had introduced late last year reductions in its benefits provisions.

Currently, there are about 19,000 retirement schemes covering 900,000 employees.

If an employer decides to continue the operation of its existing scheme after the launch of the MPF System, he is required to submit an exemption application on or before May 3, 2000.

Registered schemes that were established on or before October 15, 1995 and have lodged applications for exemption or registration under the Occupational Retirement Schemes Ordinance (ORSO) on or before January 15, 1996 are eligible to apply for MPF exemption.

It is estimated that about 13,000 schemes are eligible for MPF exemption application.

The MPFA has sent a letter to all employers who operate ORSO schemes to remind them of the deadline.

"The MPFA will send out a second round of letters to these employers, urging them to act in the best interests of their employees and not to take the implementation of the MPF System as an opportunity to reduce the benefits given to their employees under the existing schemes," said Mr Lee.

The Commissioner for Labor has also issued a letter to all ORSO employers, calling upon them to take a long-term perspective on the retirement issue and not to reduce their employees' retirement benefits in considering the various options in implementing the MPF System.

The Management Board also endorsed the revised guidelines on Disclosure of Annual Fees.

It serves to clarify that the annual fees to be prescribed in the illustrative example should include the fees of the underlying approved pooled investment funds of the scheme.

At today's Board meeting, Mr Lee also reported to Members that the Chief Executive has approved the appointment of Mr Rafael Hui as the MPFA's Managing Director.
19990831_010.e:
First batch of MPF trustee applications ended

The following is issued on behalf of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority:

As at today (Tuesday), the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority (MPFA) received 21 applications for approval of MPF corporate trustees from insurance companies, banks and investment houses.

A total of 44 master trust schemes comprising 257 constituent funds have also been submitted for approval by the MPFA.

Today is the cut-off date for the submission of the first batch of applications from companies wishing to become approved MPF trustees and product promoters wishing to launch MPF products and services early next year.

The Hon.

Charles Lee Yeh-kwong, Chairman of the MPFA, said: "We will accord top priority to process the first batch of applications received before the deadline and will count on the full cooperation of applicants in complying with the MPF requirements.

"According to the implementation timetable, the target date for completing the approval of corporate trustees will be October 29 this year while the registration of the first batch of master trust schemes will be released on January 31, 2000."

Approved MPF trustees will be allowed to start selling and marketing their MPF schemes and products from February next year.

"This timetable will allow a 10-month period for employers to enrol their staff into approved MPF schemes before the commencement of contributions in December 2000," added Mr Lee.
20000427_022.e:
Launching of MPF on December 1, 2000 as scheduled

The Chief Executive in Council have appointed December 1, 2000 as the commencement date of the full operation of the Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) System.

A Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Ordinance (80 of 1995) (Commencement) Notice 2000 (the Commencement Notice) has been made to effect the commencement.

The Commencement Notice is subject to the approval of the Legislative Council.

A government spokesman said today (April 27) that the Commencement Notice will bring into operation all remaining provisions in the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Ordinance (MPFSO) which have not yet come into operation.

This will enable the full implementation of the MPF System, and in particular, mandatory contributions will become payable.

"In March last year, the public was informed the key stages of implementing the MPF System and that collection of MPF contributions would commence on December 1, 2000 subject to a review on the readiness of all parties concerned for the full implementation of the MPF System," the spokesman said.

The Government and the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority (MPFA) have reviewed the readiness of the community, the industry and the MPFA.

The conclusion is that all the parties concerned would be ready for the full implementation of the MPF System in December 2000.

"Having suffered a severe downturn in 1998, the Hong Kong economy has staged a sharp rebound in the course of 1999 with real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) increased by 2.9%.

Growth is expected to be robust in 2000 at 5% and for 2000-2003, at an annual average of 4%.

Unemployment rate has probably peaked and is expected to come down gradually.

With steady growth, it is expected that the economy would have less difficulty in absorbing the slight dampening effect MPF might have on private consumption," the spokesman added.

The likely increase in the actual operating costs of most businesses arising from the implementation of the MPF system will be modest, estimated at around 0.7% overall.

It is expected that employers will seek to contain impact through adoption of more efficient production techniques and other management arrangements.

On public awareness, the Government and the MPFA have taken steps to ensure that the public would be fully aware of their duties and obligations under the System.

Towards this end, the Government accorded the MPF a Major Publicity Campaign status for 2000-2001, and the MPFA has started a $40 million public education and publicity campaign in January which will intensify in the run up to December 2000.

A territory-wide operation will be conducted in June to reach out to more than 50,000 shops in 18 districts.

Shop owners will be given a package of publicity materials to help them understand the MPF System.

By mid-August, the MPFA will join hands with the Hong Kong Trade Development Council to mount a large-scale exhibition at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre, bringing together all major MPF service providers to display their products.

"Our assessment is that by December 2000, public awareness of MPF should have been enhanced to sufficient level conducive to the launch of the MPF System," the spokesman said.

"There are adequate choices in terms of MPF service providers and products in the MPF market for employers, employees and self-employed persons to select, and service providers are geared up for the full operation of MPF schemes in December," the spokesman added.

One of the key tasks of the MPFA before the full implementation of the MPF System is the processing of applications for exemption from MPF requirements of existing retirement schemes under the Occupational Retirement Schemes Ordinance.

In this regard, as at April 26, the MPFA received a total of 4,691 such applications for schemes covering 332,000 employees.

It is expected that more applications will be received by the May 3 deadline.

The MPFA is ready to tackle this last minute surge.

It is envisaged that all such applications will have been processed by July 2000.

"The overall assessment is that all the concerned parties are ready for the full implementation of the MPF System in December 2000," the spokesman said.
19981210_012.e:
Guidelines for MPF service providers approved

The Management Board of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority (MPFA) endorsed at its meeting today (Thursday) six sets of guidelines to facilitate service providers in complying with the MPF legislation.

The guidelines, the first batch of its kind to be issued by the MPFA, have been finalised after extensive consultations with the retirement schemes industry and discussions at the MPFA's Guidelines Committee whose membership includes representatives from The Hong Kong Federation of Insurers, the Hong Kong Investment Funds Association and the Hong Kong Trustees' Association.

The guidelines approved by the MPFA include:

(a) Guidelines on Application for Approval as Trustees, which specify the forms for application for approval as MPF trustees and the information and documents to be submitted;

(b) Guidelines on Application for Registration of Provident Fund Schemes, which relate to the application for registration of employer sponsored schemes and master trust schemes under the MPF Schemes Ordinance; and

(c) four sets of guidelines relating to the criteria and requirements with respect to custodians of MPF assets and eligible insurers providing insurance cover for registered MPF schemes; and MPF approved funds.

The MPFA Chairman, Mr Charles Lee Yeh-kwong, said that the guidelines would be printed and made available to service providers shortly.

Details will be announced separately.

"Other guidelines to be issued in early 1999 would cover subjects relating to reporting requirements such as monthly and annual returns; investment-related issues; disclosure and other requirements on MPF trustees; application and other requirements relating to the exemption of ORSO schemes from MPF requirements," he added.

Mr Lee said that every effort has been made to ensure that the guidelines are effective.

They will be reviewed regularly and in the light of operational experience after MPF has been launched, so that the best international practices are continually adopted.

Mr Lee revealed that the Management Board had discussed the choices of premises to accommodate the future office of the MPFA.

Also on the agenda was the consultant's interim report on the study on MPFA organisational structure and remuneration package.

The consultancy study is expected to be completed by the end of this month and the MPFA would proceed to recruit its staff early next year.

Mr Lee also said that the MPFA would appoint professional designers to design a corporate logo for the Authority.

19990625_029.e:
Stricter control to protect endangered species

The Government has proposed to extend legislative control on the trade and possession of endangered species to include artificially propagated plants and medicines using endangered species as ingredients.

The proposed new controls will be contained in the amendments to the Animal and Plants (Protection of Endangered Species) Ordinance.

Speaking on the new arrangement today (Friday), a Government spokesman said: "The proposed amendments seek to meet the requirement of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).

"CITES control covers artificially propagated plants and medicines using endangered species as ingredients."

The more commonly traded artificially propagated CITES-listed plant species include cacti, aloes, pitcher plants, venus fly-trap, rosary vines, cycads, cyclamens and orchids.

The more usual types of endangered species parts and derivatives which can be used as ingredients of medicines include pangolin scales, bear gall bladder, seal penis, musk grain, saiga horn, crocodile meat, king cobra gall bladder, tuber of tall gastrodia, costas, dicksoniaceae species and aloes.

Trade in endangered animals and plants species and their products are already strictly regulated in Hong Kong.

Under existing regulation, endangered species of plants of artificially propagated origin and products made from them are not yet subjects to control.

In the case of medicines, only those containing tiger or rhino ingredients are currently subject to control.

The proposed control measures are expected to take effect early next year.

Import shipments must be accompanied by CITES export permits.

For export shipments, export licences issued in advance by the Agriculture and Fisheries Department (AFD) will be required.

Traders in possession of such goods for commercial purpose must apply in advance to AFD for a possession licence.

The Government is now considering exempting such licensing requirement for possession if these traders are able to maintain an accurate transaction record up to the standard set down by AFD.

Such records should clearly indicate the date and quantity of each transaction, with copies of invoices/ receipts attached and be available for inspection by the department.

AFD has consulted representatives of local traders, including plant and Chinese medicine dealers, for their views on the proposed amendment to the Animal and Plant (Protection of Endangered Species) Ordinance.

A reminder has been sent to related traders early this month urging them to make necessary preparation for the commencement of the proposed control measures.

However, the spokesman reminded traders that the new exemption arrangements would not be applied to medicines containing highly endangered species of wild origin as ingredients.

Their import, export and possession still require prior application of proper licences.

Local traders having further enquiries on the new measures can call AFD on tel: 2733 2379/ 2733 2282.
19970918_006.e:
Restaurant reminded not to serve endangered species dishes 

Restaurants are today (Thursday) reminded not to serve dishes of endangered species to customers.

The reminder was issued by an Agriculture and Fisheries Department (AFD) conservation officer, Mr Cheung Chi-sun, after a restaurant was convicted recently and fined $15,000 for possessing whale meat without a licence.

The case came to light in February this year when some whale meat (344 grams) was found in a Tsim Sha Tsui restaurant by AFD officers.

The case was heard in South Kowloon Magistracy earlier this month and the restaurant was fined for possessing meat of endangered species without licence.

"It has come to our attention that some restaurants in Hong Kong offer dishes of endangered species," said Mr Cheung.

"Under the Animals and Plants (Protection of Endangered Species) Ordinance, it is an offence to possess or to offer for sale any endangered species or their parts, including meat and skin, except under and in accordance with a licence issued by AFD."

He reiterated that the control applies to any item which is claimed or held out by any person or advertisement to be an endangered species.

An offender is liable to a maximum penalty of $5 million fine and two years' imprisonment upon conviction.

Mr Cheung pointed out that specimens such as crocodile meat, pangolin meat and owls might sometimes be offered illegally for food purpose.

Restaurant operators are therefore reminded that they should not serve any dish of endangered species without a licence and AFD had advised them on the matter through circular letters.

He took the opportunity to urge members of the public to refrain from ordering these dishes and to report any illegal activities on endangered species to AFD's Endangered Species Protection Section on 2733 2144.
